<h1 class="firstHeading mw-first-heading" id="firstHeading"><span class="mw-page-title-main">George Washington</span></h1>
<div class="vector-body" id="bodyContent">
<div class="noprint" id="siteSub">From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia</div>
<div id="contentSub"></div>
<div id="contentSub2"></div>
<div id="jump-to-nav"></div>

<a class="mw-jump-link" href="#searchInput">Jump to search</a>
<div class="mw-body-content mw-content-ltr" dir="ltr" id="mw-content-text" lang="en"><div class="mw-parser-output"><div class="shortdescription nomobile noexcerpt noprint searchaux" style="display:none">President of the United States from 1789 to 1797</div>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1033289096">.mw-parser-output .hatnote{font-style:italic}.mw-parser-output div.hatnote{padding-left:1.6em;margin-bottom:0.5em}.mw-parser-output .hatnote i{font-style:normal}.mw-parser-output .hatnote+link+.hatnote{margin-top:-0.5em}</style><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">"General Washington" redirects here. For other uses, see <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/General_Washington_(disambiguation)" title="General Washington (disambiguation)">General Washington (disambiguation)</a> and <a class="mw-disambig" href="/wiki/George_Washington_(disambiguation)" title="George Washington (disambiguation)">George Washington (disambiguation)</a>.</div>
<p class="mw-empty-elt">
</p>

<li><a href="/wiki/Northwest_Indian_War" title="Northwest Indian War">Northwest Indian War</a></li>

</div></td></tr><tr><td class="infobox-below" colspan="2" style="border-top: 1px solid right; font-size: 95%"><div></div></td></tr></tbody></table>
<p><b>George Washington</b> (February 22, 1732<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-calendar_11-0"><a href="#cite_note-calendar-11">[b]</a></sup> – <span class="nowrap">December 14</span>, 1799) was an American military officer, statesman, and <a href="/wiki/Founding_Fathers_of_the_United_States" title="Founding Fathers of the United States">Founding Father</a> who served as the first <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">president of the United States</a> from 1789 to 1797. Appointed by the <a href="/wiki/Continental_Congress" title="Continental Congress">Continental Congress</a> as commander of the <a href="/wiki/Continental_Army" title="Continental Army">Continental Army</a>, Washington led the <a href="/wiki/Patriot_(American_Revolution)" title="Patriot (American Revolution)">Patriot</a> forces to victory in the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">American Revolutionary War</a> and served as the president of the <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Convention_(United_States)" title="Constitutional Convention (United States)">Constitutional Convention</a> of 1787, which created the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_States" title="Constitution of the United States">Constitution of the United States</a> and the American federal government. Washington has been called the "<a href="/wiki/Father_of_the_Nation" title="Father of the Nation">Father of the Nation</a>" for his manifold leadership in the formative days of the country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-12"><a href="#cite_note-12">[10]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington's first public office was serving as the official <a href="/wiki/Surveying" title="Surveying">surveyor</a> of <a href="/wiki/Culpeper_County,_Virginia" title="Culpeper County, Virginia">Culpeper County, Virginia</a> from 1749 to 1750. Subsequently, he received his initial military training (as well as a command with the <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Regiment" title="Virginia Regiment">Virginia Regiment</a>) during the <a href="/wiki/French_and_Indian_War" title="French and Indian War">French and Indian War</a>. He was later elected to the Virginia <a href="/wiki/House_of_Burgesses" title="House of Burgesses">House of Burgesses</a> and was named a delegate to the <a href="/wiki/Continental_Congress" title="Continental Congress">Continental Congress</a> where he was appointed <a href="/wiki/Commanding_General_of_the_United_States_Army" title="Commanding General of the United States Army">Commanding General</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Continental_Army" title="Continental Army">Continental Army</a>. With this title, he commanded American forces (allied with <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_France" title="Kingdom of France">France</a>) in the defeat and surrender of the British at the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Yorktown" title="Siege of Yorktown">Siege of Yorktown</a> during the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">American Revolutionary War</a>. He <a href="/wiki/George_Washington%27s_resignation_as_commander-in-chief" title="George Washington's resignation as commander-in-chief">resigned his commission</a> after the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1783)" title="Treaty of Paris (1783)">Treaty of Paris</a> was signed in 1783.
</p><p>Washington played an indispensable role in adopting and ratifying the Constitution of the United States, which was a replacement of the original constitution, the <a href="/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation" title="Articles of Confederation">Articles of Confederation</a>. He was then twice elected president by the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Electoral_College" title="United States Electoral College">Electoral College</a> unanimously. As president, he implemented a strong, well-financed national government while remaining impartial in a fierce rivalry between cabinet members <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson" title="Thomas Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a> and <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a>. During the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a>, he <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_Neutrality" title="Proclamation of Neutrality">proclaimed a policy of neutrality</a> while sanctioning the <a href="/wiki/Jay_Treaty" title="Jay Treaty">Jay Treaty</a>. He set enduring precedents for the office of president, including the title "<a href="/wiki/President_(government_title)#In_the_United_States" title="President (government title)">Mr. President</a>", and swearing the <a href="/wiki/Oath_of_office_of_the_president_of_the_United_States" title="Oath of office of the president of the United States">Oath of Office</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Bible" title="Bible">Bible</a>. His <a href="/wiki/George_Washington%27s_Farewell_Address" title="George Washington's Farewell Address">Farewell Address</a> is widely regarded as a pre-eminent statement on <a href="/wiki/Republicanism" title="Republicanism">republicanism</a>.
</p><p><a href="/wiki/George_Washington_and_slavery" title="George Washington and slavery">Washington was a slave owner</a> who had a complicated relationship with <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States" title="Slavery in the United States">slavery</a>. During his lifetime he controlled a cumulative total of over 577 slaves, who were forced to work on his farms and wherever he lived, including the <a href="/wiki/President%27s_House_(Philadelphia)" title="President's House (Philadelphia)">President's House in Philadelphia</a>. As president, he signed laws passed by Congress that both protected and curtailed slavery. His will said that one of his slaves, <a href="/wiki/William_Lee_(valet)" title="William Lee (valet)">William Lee</a>, should be freed upon his death and that the other 123 slaves must work for his wife and be freed on her death. She freed them during her lifetime to remove the incentive for hastening her death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-13"><a href="#cite_note-13">[11]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-14"><a href="#cite_note-14">[12]</a></sup>
</p><p>He endeavored to assimilate <a href="/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States" title="Native Americans in the United States">Native Americans</a> into the <a href="/wiki/Anglo-Americans" title="Anglo-Americans">Anglo-American</a> culture. However, he waged military campaigns against hostile Native American nations during the Revolutionary War and the <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Indian_War" title="Northwest Indian War">Northwest Indian War</a>. He was a member of the <a href="/wiki/Anglicanism" title="Anglicanism">Anglican Church</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Freemasonry" title="Freemasonry">Freemasons</a>, and he urged broad religious freedom in his roles as general and president. Upon his death, he was eulogized by <a href="/wiki/Henry_Lee_III" title="Henry Lee III">Henry "Light-Horse Harry" Lee</a> as "first in war, first in peace, and first in the hearts of his countrymen".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-15"><a href="#cite_note-15">[13]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington has been <a href="/wiki/List_of_memorials_to_George_Washington" title="List of memorials to George Washington">memorialized</a> by monuments, a <a href="/wiki/Presidents%27_Day" title="Presidents' Day">federal holiday</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cultural_depictions_of_George_Washington" title="Cultural depictions of George Washington">various media depictions</a>, geographical locations, including <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">the national capital</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Washington_(state)" title="Washington (state)">State of Washington</a>, <a href="/wiki/Presidents_of_the_United_States_on_U.S._postage_stamps#George_Washington" title="Presidents of the United States on U.S. postage stamps">stamps</a>, and <a href="/wiki/United_States_dollar" title="United States dollar">currency</a>, and many scholars and ordinary Americans alike rank him among <a href="/wiki/Historical_rankings_of_presidents_of_the_United_States" title="Historical rankings of presidents of the United States">the greatest U.S. presidents</a>. In 1976, Washington was <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/posthumous" title="wikt:posthumous">posthumously</a> promoted to the rank of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_of_the_Armies_of_the_United_States" title="General of the Armies of the United States">General of the Armies of the United States</a>, the highest rank in the United States Army.
</p>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-39"><a href="#Slavery"><span class="tocnumber">10</span> <span class="toctext">Slavery</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-40"><a href="#Washington's_slaves"><span class="tocnumber">10.1</span> <span class="toctext">Washington's slaves</span></a></li>

</ul>
</li>
<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-42"><a href="#Historical_reputation_and_legacy"><span class="tocnumber">11</span> <span class="toctext">Historical reputation and legacy</span></a>
<ul>
<li class="toclevel-2 tocsection-43"><a href="#Memorials"><span class="tocnumber">11.1</span> <span class="toctext">Memorials</span></a>

</li>

<li class="toclevel-1 tocsection-55"><a href="#External_links"><span class="tocnumber">14</span> <span class="toctext">External links</span></a></li>

</div>
<h2><span id="Early_life_.281732.E2.80.931752.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_life_(1732–1752)">Early life (1732–1752)</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Washington_family" title="Washington family">Washington family</a> and <a href="/wiki/British_America" title="British America">British America</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Residence_of_the_Washington_Family_on_the_Rappahannock.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1389" data-file-width="2061" decoding="async" height="148" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Residence_of_the_Washington_Family_on_the_Rappahannock.jpg/220px-Residence_of_the_Washington_Family_on_the_Rappahannock.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Residence_of_the_Washington_Family_on_the_Rappahannock.jpg/330px-Residence_of_the_Washington_Family_on_the_Rappahannock.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c6/Residence_of_the_Washington_Family_on_the_Rappahannock.jpg/440px-Residence_of_the_Washington_Family_on_the_Rappahannock.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Residence_of_the_Washington_Family_on_the_Rappahannock.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Ferry_Farm" title="Ferry Farm">Ferry Farm</a>, the residence of the Washington family on the Rappahannock River</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Washington_family" title="Washington family">Washington family</a> was a wealthy Virginia <a href="/wiki/Planter_class" title="Planter class">planter</a> family that had made its fortune through <a href="/wiki/Speculation" title="Speculation">land speculation</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Cultivation_of_tobacco" title="Cultivation of tobacco">cultivation of tobacco</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnger2019100–101_16-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnger2019100–101-16">[14]</a></sup> Washington's great-grandfather <a href="/wiki/John_Washington" title="John Washington">John Washington</a> <a href="/wiki/Emigration" title="Emigration">emigrated</a> in 1656<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-17"><a href="#cite_note-17">[15]</a></sup> from <a href="/wiki/Sulgrave" title="Sulgrave">Sulgrave</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northamptonshire" title="Northamptonshire">Northamptonshire</a>, <a href="/wiki/Kingdom_of_England" title="Kingdom of England">England</a>, to the English <a href="/wiki/Colony_of_Virginia" title="Colony of Virginia">colony of Virginia</a> where he accumulated 5,000 acres (2,000 ha) of land, including <a href="/wiki/Little_Hunting_Creek" title="Little Hunting Creek">Little Hunting Creek</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Potomac_River" title="Potomac River">Potomac River</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow20106–10Ferling19884–5_18-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow20106–10Ferling19884–5-18">[16]</a></sup> George Washington was born on February 22, 1732,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-calendar_11-1"><a href="#cite_note-calendar-11">[b]</a></sup> at <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_Birthplace_National_Monument" title="George Washington Birthplace National Monument">Popes Creek</a> in <a href="/wiki/Westmoreland_County,_Virginia" title="Westmoreland County, Virginia">Westmoreland County</a>, in the British colony of Virginia,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow20103–6_19-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow20103–6-19">[17]</a></sup> and was the first of six children of <a href="/wiki/Augustine_Washington" title="Augustine Washington">Augustine</a> and <a href="/wiki/Mary_Ball_Washington" title="Mary Ball Washington">Mary Ball Washington</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling20023Chernow20105–7_20-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling20023Chernow20105–7-20">[18]</a></sup> His father was a <a href="/wiki/Justice_of_the_peace" title="Justice of the peace">justice of the peace</a> and a prominent public figure who had four additional children from his first marriage to Jane Butler.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling20099Chernow20106–8_21-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling20099Chernow20106–8-21">[19]</a></sup> The family moved to Little Hunting Creek in 1735. In 1738, they moved to <a href="/wiki/Ferry_Farm" title="Ferry Farm">Ferry Farm</a> near <a href="/wiki/Fredericksburg,_Virginia" title="Fredericksburg, Virginia">Fredericksburg, Virginia</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Rappahannock_River" title="Rappahannock River">Rappahannock River</a>. When Augustine died in 1743, Washington inherited Ferry Farm and ten slaves; his older half-brother <a href="/wiki/Lawrence_Washington_(1718%E2%80%931752)" title="Lawrence Washington (1718–1752)">Lawrence</a> inherited Little Hunting Creek and renamed it <a href="/wiki/Mount_Vernon" title="Mount Vernon">Mount Vernon</a>.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>Washington did not have the formal education his elder brothers received at <a href="/wiki/Appleby_Grammar_School" title="Appleby Grammar School">Appleby Grammar School</a> in England, but did attend the <a href="/wiki/Lower_Church" title="Lower Church">Lower Church</a> School in <a href="/wiki/Hartfield,_Virginia" title="Hartfield, Virginia">Hartfield</a>. He learned mathematics, trigonometry, and land <a href="/wiki/Surveying" title="Surveying">surveying</a> and became a talented draftsman and map-maker. By early adulthood, he was writing with "considerable force" and "precision";<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201010–12Ferling200214Ferling20105–6_22-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201010–12Ferling200214Ferling20105–6-22">[20]</a></sup> however, his writing displayed little wit or humor. In pursuit of admiration, status, and power, he tended to attribute his shortcomings and failures to someone else's ineffectuality.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling198857–58_23-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling198857–58-23">[21]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington often visited Mount Vernon and <a href="/wiki/Belvoir_(plantation)" title="Belvoir (plantation)">Belvoir</a>, the plantation that belonged to Lawrence's father-in-law <a href="/wiki/William_Fairfax" title="William Fairfax">William Fairfax</a>. Fairfax became Washington's patron and surrogate father, and Washington spent a month in 1748 with a team surveying Fairfax's <a href="/wiki/Shenandoah_Valley" title="Shenandoah Valley">Shenandoah Valley</a> property.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201010,_19Ferling200214–15Randall199736_24-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201010,_19Ferling200214–15Randall199736-24">[22]</a></sup> The following year he received a surveyor's license from the <a href="/wiki/College_of_William_%26_Mary" title="College of William &amp; Mary">College of William &amp; Mary</a> when he was 17 years old.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-26"><a href="#cite_note-26">[c]</a></sup> Even though Washington had not served the customary apprenticeship, Fairfax appointed him surveyor of <a href="/wiki/Culpeper_County,_Virginia" title="Culpeper County, Virginia">Culpeper County, Virginia</a>, and he appeared in Culpeper County to take his oath of office July 20, 1749.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE&quot;George_Washington's_Professional_Surveys&quot;2nd_prgh_25-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE&quot;George_Washington's_Professional_Surveys&quot;2nd_prgh-25">[23]</a></sup> He subsequently familiarized himself with the frontier region, and though he resigned from the job in 1750, he continued to do surveys west of the <a href="/wiki/Blue_Ridge_Mountains" title="Blue Ridge Mountains">Blue Ridge Mountains</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE&quot;George_Washington's_Professional_Surveys&quot;3rd_prgh_27-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE&quot;George_Washington's_Professional_Surveys&quot;3rd_prgh-27">[24]</a></sup> By 1752 he had bought almost 1,500 acres (600 ha) in the Valley and owned 2,315 acres (937 ha).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1936v._19,_p._510Chernow201022–23_28-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1936v._19,_p._510Chernow201022–23-28">[25]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1751, Washington made his only trip abroad when he accompanied Lawrence to <a href="/wiki/Barbados" title="Barbados">Barbados</a>, hoping the climate would cure his brother's tuberculosis.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201024_29-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201024-29">[26]</a></sup> Washington contracted <a href="/wiki/Smallpox" title="Smallpox">smallpox</a> during that trip, which immunized him and left his face slightly scarred.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlexner19748_30-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlexner19748-30">[27]</a></sup> Lawrence died in 1752, and Washington leased Mount Vernon from his widow Anne; he inherited it outright after her death in 1761.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201026,_98_31-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201026,_98-31">[28]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Colonial_military_career_.281752.E2.80.931758.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Colonial_military_career_(1752–1758)">Colonial military career (1752–1758)</span></h2>
<p>Lawrence Washington's service as adjutant general of the <a href="/wiki/Virginia_militia" title="Virginia militia">Virginia militia</a> inspired his half-brother George to seek a commission. Virginia's lieutenant governor, <a href="/wiki/Robert_Dinwiddie" title="Robert Dinwiddie">Robert Dinwiddie</a>, appointed George Washington as a major and commander of one of the four militia districts. The British and French were competing for control of the <a href="/wiki/Ohio_River" title="Ohio River">Ohio Valley</a>. While the British were constructing forts along the Ohio River, the French were doing the same—constructing forts between the Ohio River and Lake Erie.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAnderson200731–32Chernow201026–27,_31_32-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAnderson200731–32Chernow201026–27,_31-32">[29]</a></sup>
</p><p>In October 1753, Dinwiddie appointed Washington as a special envoy. He had sent George to demand French forces to vacate land that was being claimed by the British.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-34"><a href="#cite_note-34">[d]</a></sup> Washington was also appointed to make peace with the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Iroquois_Confederacy" title="Iroquois Confederacy">Iroquois Confederacy</a>, and to gather further intelligence about the French forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200915–16_35-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200915–16-35">[31]</a></sup> Washington met with Half-King <a href="/wiki/Tanacharison" title="Tanacharison">Tanacharison</a>, and other Iroquois chiefs, at <a href="/wiki/Logstown" title="Logstown">Logstown</a>, and gathered information about the numbers and locations of the French forts, as well as intelligence concerning individuals taken prisoner by the French. Washington was given the nickname <a href="/wiki/Town_Destroyer" title="Town Destroyer">Conotocaurius (town destroyer or devourer of villages)</a> by Tanacharison. The nickname had previously been given to his great-grandfather <a href="/wiki/John_Washington" title="John Washington">John Washington</a> in the late seventeenth century by the <a href="/wiki/Susquehannock" title="Susquehannock">Susquehannock</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-36"><a href="#cite_note-36">[32]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-37"><a href="#cite_note-37">[33]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington's party reached the Ohio River in November 1753, and were intercepted by a French patrol. The party was escorted to <a href="/wiki/Fort_Le_Boeuf" title="Fort Le Boeuf">Fort Le Boeuf</a>, where Washington was received in a friendly manner. He delivered the British demand to vacate to the French commander <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Legardeur_de_Saint-Pierre" title="Jacques Legardeur de Saint-Pierre">Saint-Pierre</a>, but the French refused to leave. Saint-Pierre gave Washington his official answer in a sealed envelope after a few days' delay, as well as food and extra winter clothing for his party's journey back to Virginia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200915–18Lengel200523–24Randall199774Chernow201026–27,_31_38-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200915–18Lengel200523–24Randall199774Chernow201026–27,_31-38">[34]</a></sup> Washington completed the precarious mission in 77 days, in difficult winter conditions, achieving a measure of distinction when his report was published in Virginia and in London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick193619,_pp._510–511Ferling200915–18_39-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick193619,_pp._510–511Ferling200915–18-39">[35]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="French_and_Indian_War">French and Indian War</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/French_and_Indian_War" title="French and Indian War">French and Indian War</a>, <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_in_the_French_and_Indian_War" title="George Washington in the French and Indian War">George Washington in the French and Indian War</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a></div>
<p>In February 1754, Dinwiddie promoted Washington to lieutenant colonel and second-in-command of the 300-strong <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Regiment" title="Virginia Regiment">Virginia Regiment</a>, with orders to confront French forces at the <a href="/wiki/Point_State_Park" title="Point State Park">Forks of the Ohio</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201031–32Ferling200918–19_40-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201031–32Ferling200918–19-40">[36]</a></sup> Washington set out for the Forks with half the regiment in April and soon learned a French force of 1,000 had begun construction of <a href="/wiki/Fort_Duquesne" title="Fort Duquesne">Fort Duquesne</a> there. In May, having set up a <a href="/wiki/Fort_Necessity_National_Battlefield" title="Fort Necessity National Battlefield">defensive position</a> at Great Meadows, he learned that the French had made camp seven miles (11 km) away; he decided to take the offensive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201041–42_41-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201041–42-41">[37]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:242px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Night_Council_At_Fort_Necessity_from_the_Darlington_Collection_of_Engraving-_detail.jpg"><img alt="Night scene depicting Washington at center, standing among officers and Indians, around a lamp, holding a war council" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="538" data-file-width="950" decoding="async" height="136" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/The_Night_Council_At_Fort_Necessity_from_the_Darlington_Collection_of_Engraving-_detail.jpg/240px-The_Night_Council_At_Fort_Necessity_from_the_Darlington_Collection_of_Engraving-_detail.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/The_Night_Council_At_Fort_Necessity_from_the_Darlington_Collection_of_Engraving-_detail.jpg/360px-The_Night_Council_At_Fort_Necessity_from_the_Darlington_Collection_of_Engraving-_detail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/The_Night_Council_At_Fort_Necessity_from_the_Darlington_Collection_of_Engraving-_detail.jpg/480px-The_Night_Council_At_Fort_Necessity_from_the_Darlington_Collection_of_Engraving-_detail.jpg 2x" width="240"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Night_Council_At_Fort_Necessity_from_the_Darlington_Collection_of_Engraving-_detail.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Lieutenant Colonel Washington holds night council at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Necessity" title="Battle of Fort Necessity">Fort Necessity</a></div></div></div>
<p>The French detachment proved to be only about fifty men, so Washington advanced on May 28 with a small force of Virginians and Indian allies to ambush them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201042_42-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201042-42">[38]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-44"><a href="#cite_note-44">[e]</a></sup> What took place, known as the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Jumonville_Glen" title="Battle of Jumonville Glen">Battle of Jumonville Glen</a> or the "Jumonville affair", was disputed, and French forces were killed outright with muskets and hatchets. French commander <a href="/wiki/Joseph_Coulon_de_Jumonville" title="Joseph Coulon de Jumonville">Joseph Coulon de Jumonville</a>, who carried a diplomatic message for the British to evacuate, was killed. French forces found Jumonville and some of his men dead and scalped and assumed Washington was responsible.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201042–43_45-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201042–43-45">[40]</a></sup> Washington blamed his translator for not communicating the French intentions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200924–25_46-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200924–25-46">[41]</a></sup> Dinwiddie congratulated Washington for his victory over the French.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201044–45_47-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201044–45-47">[42]</a></sup> This incident ignited the <a href="/wiki/French_and_Indian_War" title="French and Indian War">French and Indian War</a>, which later became part of the larger <a href="/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War" title="Seven Years' War">Seven Years' War</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200919–24Ellis200413Alden199613–15_48-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200919–24Ellis200413Alden199613–15-48">[43]</a></sup>
</p><p>The full Virginia Regiment joined Washington at Fort Necessity the following month with news that he had been promoted to command of the regiment and colonel upon the regimental commander's death. The regiment was reinforced by an <a href="/wiki/British_Army_Independent_Companies_in_South_Carolina" title="British Army Independent Companies in South Carolina">independent company of a hundred South Carolinians</a> led by Captain <a href="/wiki/James_Mackay_(British_Army_officer)" title="James Mackay (British Army officer)">James Mackay</a>, whose royal commission outranked that of Washington, and a conflict of command ensued. On July 3, a French force attacked with 900 men, and the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Necessity" title="Battle of Fort Necessity">ensuing battle</a> ended in Washington's surrender.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200923–25Ellis200415–17_49-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200923–25Ellis200415–17-49">[44]</a></sup> In the aftermath, Colonel <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_Innes_(North_Carolina)" title="James Innes (North Carolina)">James Innes</a> took command of intercolonial forces, the Virginia Regiment was divided, and Washington was offered a captaincy which he refused, with the resignation of his commission.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200926_50-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200926-50">[45]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Washington_the_soldier.jpg"><img alt="Washington on horseback in the middle of a battle scene with other soldiers" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4759" data-file-width="6917" decoding="async" height="151" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Washington_the_soldier.jpg/220px-Washington_the_soldier.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Washington_the_soldier.jpg/330px-Washington_the_soldier.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/01/Washington_the_soldier.jpg/440px-Washington_the_soldier.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Washington_the_soldier.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Washington the Soldier</i>: Lieutenant Colonel Washington on horseback during the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Monongahela" title="Battle of the Monongahela">Battle of the Monongahela</a> (oil, <i>Reǵnier</i>, 1834)</div></div></div>
<p>In 1755, Washington served voluntarily as an aide to General <a href="/wiki/Edward_Braddock" title="Edward Braddock">Edward Braddock</a>, who led a British <a href="/wiki/Braddock_Expedition" title="Braddock Expedition">expedition</a> to expel the French from Fort Duquesne and the Ohio Country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201053_51-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201053-51">[46]</a></sup> On Washington's recommendation, Braddock split the army into one main column and a lightly equipped "flying column".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden199637Ferling201035–36_52-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden199637Ferling201035–36-52">[47]</a></sup> Suffering from a severe case of <a href="/wiki/Dysentery" title="Dysentery">dysentery</a>, Washington was left behind, and when he rejoined Braddock at Monongahela the French and their Indian allies <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Monongahela" title="Battle of the Monongahela">ambushed</a> the divided army. Two-thirds of the British force became casualties, including the mortally wounded Braddock. Under the command of Lieutenant Colonel Thomas Gage, Washington, still very ill, rallied the survivors and formed a rear guard, allowing the remnants of the force to disengage and retreat.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden199637–46Ferling201035–36Chernow201057–58_53-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden199637–46Ferling201035–36Chernow201057–58-53">[48]</a></sup> During the engagement, he had two horses shot from under him, and his hat and coat were bullet-pierced.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1936511_54-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1936511-54">[49]</a></sup> His conduct under fire redeemed his reputation among critics of his command in the Battle of Fort Necessity,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200928–30_55-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200928–30-55">[50]</a></sup> but he was not included by the succeeding commander (Colonel Thomas Dunbar) in planning subsequent operations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden199637–46_56-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden199637–46-56">[51]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Virginia Regiment was reconstituted in August 1755, and Dinwiddie appointed Washington its commander, again with the rank of colonel. Washington clashed over seniority almost immediately, this time with <a href="/wiki/John_Dagworthy" title="John Dagworthy">John Dagworthy</a>, another captain of superior royal rank, who commanded a detachment of Marylanders at the regiment's headquarters in <a href="/wiki/Fort_Cumberland_(Maryland)" title="Fort Cumberland (Maryland)">Fort Cumberland</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllis200424Ferling200930–31_57-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllis200424Ferling200930–31-57">[52]</a></sup> Washington, impatient for an offensive against Fort Duquesne, was convinced Braddock would have granted him a royal commission and pressed his case in February 1756 with Braddock's successor as <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-Chief,_North_America" title="Commander-in-Chief, North America">Commander-in-Chief</a>, <a href="/wiki/William_Shirley" title="William Shirley">William Shirley</a>, and again in January 1757 with Shirley's successor, <a href="/wiki/John_Campbell,_4th_Earl_of_Loudoun" title="John Campbell, 4th Earl of Loudoun">Lord Loudoun</a>. Shirley ruled in Washington's favor only in the matter of Dagworthy; Loudoun humiliated Washington, refused him a royal commission and agreed only to relieve him of the responsibility of manning Fort Cumberland.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200931–32,_38–39_58-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200931–32,_38–39-58">[53]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1758, the Virginia Regiment was assigned to the British <a href="/wiki/Forbes_Expedition" title="Forbes Expedition">Forbes Expedition</a> to capture Fort Duquesne.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlexner1965194Fitzpatrick1936512_59-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlexner1965194Fitzpatrick1936512-59">[54]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-61"><a href="#cite_note-61">[f]</a></sup> Washington disagreed with General <a href="/wiki/John_Forbes_(British_Army_officer)" title="John Forbes (British Army officer)">John Forbes'</a> tactics and chosen route.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1936512Chernow201089–90Flexner1965194,_206–207_62-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1936512Chernow201089–90Flexner1965194,_206–207-62">[56]</a></sup> Forbes nevertheless made Washington a <a href="/wiki/Brevet_(military)" title="Brevet (military)">brevet</a> brigadier general and gave him command of one of the three brigades that would assault the fort. The French abandoned the fort and the valley before the assault was launched; Washington saw only a friendly fire incident which left 14 dead and 26 injured. The war lasted another four years, and Washington resigned his commission and returned to Mount Vernon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200943Chernow201090–91Lengel200575–76,_81_63-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200943Chernow201090–91Lengel200575–76,_81-63">[57]</a></sup>
</p><p>Under Washington, the Virginia Regiment had defended 300 miles (480 km) of frontier against twenty Indian attacks in ten months.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1936511–512Flexner1965138Fischer200415–16Ellis200438_64-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1936511–512Flexner1965138Fischer200415–16Ellis200438-64">[58]</a></sup> He increased the professionalism of the regiment as it increased from 300 to 1,000 men, and Virginia's frontier population suffered less than other colonies. Some historians have said this was Washington's "only unqualified success" during the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFischer200415–16Ellis200438_65-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFischer200415–16Ellis200438-65">[59]</a></sup> Though he failed to realize a royal commission, he did gain self-confidence, leadership skills, and invaluable knowledge of British military tactics. The destructive competition Washington witnessed among colonial politicians fostered his later support of a strong central government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201092–93Ferling200232–33_66-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201092–93Ferling200232–33-66">[60]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Marriage.2C_civilian.2C_and_political_life_.281755.E2.80.931775.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Marriage,_civilian,_and_political_life_(1755–1775)">Marriage, civilian, and political life (1755–1775)</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Washington_1772.jpg"><img alt="Painting of Washington, by Charles Wilson Peale, standing in a formal pose, in a colonel's uniform, right hand inserted in shirt." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3000" data-file-width="2418" decoding="async" height="223" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Washington_1772.jpg/180px-Washington_1772.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Washington_1772.jpg/270px-Washington_1772.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c7/Washington_1772.jpg/360px-Washington_1772.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Washington_1772.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Colonel George Washington, by <a href="/wiki/Charles_Willson_Peale" title="Charles Willson Peale">Charles Willson Peale</a>, 1772</div></div></div>
<p>On January 6, 1759, Washington, at age 26, married <a href="/wiki/Martha_Washington" title="Martha Washington">Martha Dandridge Custis</a>, the 27-year-old widow of wealthy plantation owner <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Parke_Custis" title="Daniel Parke Custis">Daniel Parke Custis</a>. The marriage took place at Martha's estate; she was intelligent, gracious, and experienced in managing a planter's estate, and the couple created a happy marriage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200233–34Wiencek200369_67-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200233–34Wiencek200369-67">[61]</a></sup> They raised <a href="/wiki/John_Parke_Custis" title="John Parke Custis">John Parke Custis</a> (Jacky) and <a href="/wiki/Martha_Parke_Custis" title="Martha Parke Custis">Martha Parke Custis</a> (Patsy), children from her previous marriage, and later Jacky's children <a href="/wiki/Eleanor_Parke_Custis_Lewis" title="Eleanor Parke Custis Lewis">Eleanor Parke Custis</a> (Nelly) and <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_Parke_Custis" title="George Washington Parke Custis">George Washington Parke Custis</a> (Washy). Washington's 1751 bout with smallpox is thought to have rendered him sterile, though it is equally likely that "Martha may have sustained injury during the birth of Patsy, her final child, making additional births impossible."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010103_68-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010103-68">[62]</a></sup> The couple lamented not having any children together.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010103Flexner197442–43_69-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010103Flexner197442–43-69">[63]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-72"><a href="#cite_note-72">[g]</a></sup> They moved to Mount Vernon, near <a href="/wiki/Alexandria,_Virginia" title="Alexandria, Virginia">Alexandria</a>, where he took up life as a planter of tobacco and wheat and emerged as a political figure.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201097–98Fischer200414_73-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201097–98Fischer200414-73">[66]</a></sup>
</p><p>The marriage gave Washington control over Martha's one-third <a href="/wiki/Dower" title="Dower">dower</a> interest in the 18,000-acre (7,300 ha) <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Parke_Custis#Estate" title="Daniel Parke Custis">Custis estate</a>, and he managed the remaining two-thirds for Martha's children; the estate also included 84 slaves. He became one of Virginia's wealthiest men, which increased his social standing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWiencek20039–10,_67–69,_80–81_74-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWiencek20039–10,_67–69,_80–81-74">[67]</a></sup>
</p><p>At Washington's urging, Governor <a href="/wiki/Norborne_Berkeley,_4th_Baron_Botetourt" title="Norborne Berkeley, 4th Baron Botetourt">Lord Botetourt</a> fulfilled Dinwiddie's 1754 promise of land bounties to all-volunteer militia during the French and Indian War.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERasmussenTilton1999100Chernow2010184_75-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERasmussenTilton1999100Chernow2010184-75">[68]</a></sup> In late 1770, Washington inspected the lands in the <a href="/wiki/Ohio_River" title="Ohio River">Ohio</a> and <a href="/wiki/Kanawha_River" title="Kanawha River">Great Kanawha</a> regions, and he engaged surveyor <a href="/wiki/William_Crawford_(soldier)" title="William Crawford (soldier)">William Crawford</a> to subdivide it. Crawford allotted 23,200 acres (9,400 ha) to Washington; Washington told the veterans that their land was hilly and unsuitable for farming, and he agreed to purchase 20,147 acres (8,153 ha), leaving some feeling they had been duped.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200244–45Grizzard2002135–137_76-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200244–45Grizzard2002135–137-76">[69]</a></sup> He also doubled the size of Mount Vernon to 6,500 acres (2,600 ha) and increased its slave population to more than a hundred by 1775.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllis200441–42,_48_77-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllis200441–42,_48-77">[70]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington's political activities included supporting the candidacy of his friend <a href="/wiki/George_William_Fairfax" title="George William Fairfax">George William Fairfax</a> in his 1755 bid to represent the region in the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Virginia_House_of_Burgesses" title="Virginia House of Burgesses">Virginia House of Burgesses</a>. This support led to a dispute which resulted in a physical altercation between Washington and another Virginia planter, <a href="/wiki/William_Payne_(sheriff)" title="William Payne (sheriff)">William Payne</a>. Washington defused the situation, including ordering officers from the <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Regiment" title="Virginia Regiment">Virginia Regiment</a> to stand down. Washington apologized to Payne the following day at a tavern. Payne had been expecting to be challenged to a duel.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-78"><a href="#cite_note-78">[71]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-79"><a href="#cite_note-79">[72]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-80"><a href="#cite_note-80">[73]</a></sup>
</p><p>As a respected military hero and large landowner, Washington held local offices and was elected to the Virginia provincial legislature, representing Frederick County in the House of Burgesses for seven years beginning in 1758.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllis200441–42,_48_77-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllis200441–42,_48-77">[70]</a></sup> He plied the voters with beer, brandy, and other beverages, although he was absent while serving on the Forbes Expedition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden199671_81-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden199671-81">[74]</a></sup> He won the election with roughly 40 percent of the vote, defeating three other candidates with the help of several local supporters. He rarely spoke in his early legislative career, but he became a prominent critic of Britain's taxation policy and mercantilist policies towards the American colonies starting in the 1760s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200949–54,_68_82-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200949–54,_68-82">[75]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Martha_Dandridge_Custis_crop.jpg"><img alt="A mezzotint of Martha Washington, standing, wearing a formal gown, based on a 1757 portrait by John Wollaston" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="409" data-file-width="287" decoding="async" height="242" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Martha_Dandridge_Custis_crop.jpg/170px-Martha_Dandridge_Custis_crop.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c4/Martha_Dandridge_Custis_crop.jpg/255px-Martha_Dandridge_Custis_crop.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c4/Martha_Dandridge_Custis_crop.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Martha_Dandridge_Custis_crop.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Martha Washington based on a 1757 portrait by <a href="/wiki/John_Wollaston_(painter)" title="John Wollaston (painter)">John Wollaston</a></div></div></div>
<p>By occupation, Washington was a planter, and he imported luxuries and other goods from England, paying for them by exporting tobacco.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBrown1976476_83-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrown1976476-83">[76]</a></sup> His profligate spending combined with low tobacco prices left him £1,800 in debt by 1764, prompting him to diversify his holdings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllis200449–50_84-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllis200449–50-84">[77]</a></sup> In 1765, because of erosion and other soil problems, he changed Mount Vernon's primary cash crop from tobacco to wheat and expanded operations to include corn <a href="/wiki/George_Washington%27s_Gristmill" title="George Washington's Gristmill">flour milling</a> and fishing.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010141_85-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010141-85">[78]</a></sup> Washington also took time for leisure with fox hunting, fishing, dances, theater, cards, backgammon, and billiards.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200243–44Ellis200444_86-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200243–44Ellis200444-86">[79]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington soon was counted among the political and social elite in Virginia. From 1768 to 1775, he invited some 2,000 guests to his Mount Vernon estate, mostly those whom he considered people of rank, and was known to be exceptionally cordial toward his guests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010122_87-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010122-87">[80]</a></sup> He became more politically active in 1769, presenting legislation in the <a href="/wiki/Virginia_General_Assembly" title="Virginia General Assembly">Virginia Assembly</a> to establish an embargo on goods from Great Britain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200273–76_88-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200273–76-88">[81]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington's step-daughter Patsy Custis suffered from epileptic attacks from age 12, and she died in his arms in 1773. The following day, he wrote to <a href="/wiki/Burwell_Bassett_Sr." title="Burwell Bassett Sr.">Burwell Bassett</a>: "It is easier to conceive, than to describe, the distress of this Family".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010161_89-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010161-89">[82]</a></sup> He canceled all business activity and remained with Martha every night for three months.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHigginbotham2001154_90-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHigginbotham2001154-90">[83]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Opposition_to_British_Parliament_and_Crown">Opposition to British Parliament and Crown</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a>, <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">American Revolutionary War</a>, and <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_in_the_American_Revolution" title="George Washington in the American Revolution">George Washington in the American Revolution</a></div>
<p>Washington played a central role before and during the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">American Revolution</a>. His disdain for the British military had begun when he was passed over for promotion into the Regular Army. Opposed to taxes imposed by the <a href="/wiki/Parliament_of_Great_Britain" title="Parliament of Great Britain">British Parliament</a> on the Colonies without <a href="/wiki/Virtual_representation" title="Virtual representation">proper representation</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010136_91-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010136-91">[84]</a></sup> he and other colonists were also angered by the <a href="/wiki/Royal_Proclamation_of_1763" title="Royal Proclamation of 1763">Royal Proclamation of 1763</a> which banned American settlement west of the <a href="/wiki/Allegheny_Mountains" title="Allegheny Mountains">Allegheny Mountains</a> and protected the <a href="/wiki/North_American_fur_trade" title="North American fur trade">British fur trade</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010137,_148Taylor201661,_75_92-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010137,_148Taylor201661,_75-92">[85]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington believed the <a href="/wiki/Stamp_Act_1765" title="Stamp Act 1765">Stamp Act of 1765</a> was an "Act of Oppression", and he celebrated its repeal the following year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-94"><a href="#cite_note-94">[h]</a></sup> In March 1766, Parliament passed the <a href="/wiki/Declaratory_Act" title="Declaratory Act">Declaratory Act</a> asserting that Parliamentary law superseded colonial law.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016103_95-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016103-95">[87]</a></sup> In the late 1760s, the interference of the British Crown in American lucrative western land speculation spurred on the American Revolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lehrman_Institute_(June_22,_2021)_96-0"><a href="#cite_note-Lehrman_Institute_(June_22,_2021)-96">[88]</a></sup> Washington himself was a prosperous land speculator, and in 1767, he encouraged "adventures" to acquire backcountry western lands.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lehrman_Institute_(June_22,_2021)_96-1"><a href="#cite_note-Lehrman_Institute_(June_22,_2021)-96">[88]</a></sup> Washington helped lead widespread protests against the <a href="/wiki/Townshend_Acts" title="Townshend Acts">Townshend Acts</a> passed by Parliament in 1767, and he introduced a proposal in May 1769 drafted by <a href="/wiki/George_Mason" title="George Mason">George Mason</a> which called Virginians to boycott British goods; the Acts were mostly repealed in 1770.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFreeman1968174–176Taylor201675_97-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFreeman1968174–176Taylor201675-97">[89]</a></sup>
</p><p>Parliament sought to punish Massachusetts colonists for their role in the <a href="/wiki/Boston_Tea_Party" title="Boston Tea Party">Boston Tea Party</a> in 1774 by passing the <a href="/wiki/Intolerable_Acts" title="Intolerable Acts">Coercive Acts</a>, which Washington referred to as "an invasion of our rights and privileges".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall1997262Chernow2010166Taylor2016119_98-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall1997262Chernow2010166Taylor2016119-98">[90]</a></sup> He said Americans must not submit to acts of tyranny since "custom and use shall make us as tame and abject slaves, as the blacks we rule over with such arbitrary sway".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996101_99-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996101-99">[91]</a></sup> That July, he and George Mason drafted a list of resolutions for the <a href="/wiki/Fairfax_County,_Virginia" title="Fairfax County, Virginia">Fairfax County</a> committee which Washington chaired, and the committee adopted the <a href="/wiki/Fairfax_Resolves" title="Fairfax Resolves">Fairfax Resolves</a> calling for a Continental Congress, and an end to the slave trade.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010167_100-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010167-100">[92]</a></sup> On August 1, Washington attended the <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Conventions" title="Virginia Conventions">First Virginia Convention</a>, where he was selected as a delegate to the <a href="/wiki/First_Continental_Congress" title="First Continental Congress">First Continental Congress</a>, September 5 to October 26, 1774, which he also attended.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2010100FordHuntFitzpatrick1904v._19,_p._11_101-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2010100FordHuntFitzpatrick1904v._19,_p._11-101">[93]</a></sup> As tensions rose in 1774, he helped train county militias in Virginia and organized enforcement of the <a href="/wiki/Continental_Association" title="Continental Association">Continental Association</a> boycott of British goods instituted by the Congress.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2010108Taylor2016126–127_102-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2010108Taylor2016126–127-102">[94]</a></sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">American Revolutionary War</a> began on April 19, 1775, with the <a href="/wiki/Battles_of_Lexington_and_Concord" title="Battles of Lexington and Concord">Battles of Lexington and Concord</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Boston" title="Siege of Boston">Siege of Boston</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016132_103-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016132-103">[95]</a></sup> The colonists were divided over breaking away from British rule and split into two factions: <a href="/wiki/Patriot_(American_Revolution)" title="Patriot (American Revolution)">Patriots</a> who rejected British rule, and <a href="/wiki/Loyalist_(American_Revolution)" title="Loyalist (American Revolution)">Loyalists</a> who desired to remain subject to the King.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor20163–9_104-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor20163–9-104">[96]</a></sup> General <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Gage" title="Thomas Gage">Thomas Gage</a> was commander of British forces in America at the beginning of the war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016121–123_105-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016121–123-105">[97]</a></sup> Upon hearing the shocking news of the onset of war, Washington was "sobered and dismayed",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010181_106-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010181-106">[98]</a></sup> and he hastily departed Mount Vernon on May 4, 1775, to join the <a href="/wiki/Second_Continental_Congress" title="Second Continental Congress">Second Continental Congress</a> in <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia" title="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010182_107-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010182-107">[99]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Commander_in_chief_.281775.E2.80.931783.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Commander_in_chief_(1775–1783)">Commander in chief (1775–1783)</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War#American_strategy" title="American Revolutionary War">American Revolutionary War § American strategy</a></div><link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Military_career_of_George_Washington" title="Military career of George Washington">Military career of George Washington</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_Washington,_1776.jpg"><img alt="Formal painting of General George Washington, standing in uniform, as commander of the Continental Army" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1536" data-file-width="1319" decoding="async" height="198" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/George_Washington%2C_1776.jpg/170px-George_Washington%2C_1776.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/George_Washington%2C_1776.jpg/255px-George_Washington%2C_1776.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/94/George_Washington%2C_1776.jpg/340px-George_Washington%2C_1776.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_Washington,_1776.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>General Washington, Commander of the <a href="/wiki/Continental_Army" title="Continental Army">Continental Army</a> by <a href="/wiki/Charles_Willson_Peale" title="Charles Willson Peale">Charles Willson Peale</a> (1776)</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Second_Continental_Congress" title="Second Continental Congress">Congress</a> created the <a href="/wiki/Continental_Army" title="Continental Army">Continental Army</a> on June 14, 1775, and <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Adams" title="Samuel Adams">Samuel</a> and <a href="/wiki/John_Adams" title="John Adams">John Adams</a> nominated Washington to become its <a href="/wiki/Commander-in-chief" title="Commander-in-chief">commander-in-chief</a>. Washington was chosen over <a href="/wiki/John_Hancock" title="John Hancock">John Hancock</a> because of his military experience and the belief that a Virginian would better unite the colonies. He was considered an incisive leader who kept his "ambition in check".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010185,_547_108-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010185,_547-108">[100]</a></sup> He was unanimously elected commander in chief by Congress the next day.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016132–133Ellis200467–68Chernow2010185–186Fitzpatrick1936514_109-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016132–133Ellis200467–68Chernow2010185–186Fitzpatrick1936514-109">[101]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington appeared before Congress in uniform and gave an acceptance speech on June 16, declining a salary—though he was later reimbursed expenses. He was commissioned on June 19 and was roundly praised by Congressional delegates, including John Adams, who proclaimed that he was the man best suited to lead and unite the colonies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-110"><a href="#cite_note-110">[102]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERasmussenTilton1999294Fitzpatrick1936514Taylor2016141–142Ferling200986–87_111-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERasmussenTilton1999294Fitzpatrick1936514Taylor2016141–142Ferling200986–87-111">[103]</a></sup> Congress appointed Washington "General &amp; Commander in chief of the army of the <a href="/wiki/United_Colonies" title="United Colonies">United Colonies</a> and of all the forces raised or to be raised by them", and instructed him to take charge of the siege of Boston on June 22, 1775.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-112"><a href="#cite_note-112">[104]</a></sup>
</p><p>Congress chose his primary staff officers, including Major General <a href="/wiki/Artemas_Ward" title="Artemas Ward">Artemas Ward</a>, Adjutant General <a href="/wiki/Horatio_Gates" title="Horatio Gates">Horatio Gates</a>, Major General <a href="/wiki/Charles_Lee_(general)" title="Charles Lee (general)">Charles Lee</a>, Major General <a href="/wiki/Philip_Schuyler" title="Philip Schuyler">Philip Schuyler</a>, Major General <a href="/wiki/Nathanael_Greene" title="Nathanael Greene">Nathanael Greene</a>, Colonel <a href="/wiki/Henry_Knox" title="Henry Knox">Henry Knox</a>, and Colonel <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010190–191Ferling2002108_113-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010190–191Ferling2002108-113">[105]</a></sup> Washington was impressed by Colonel <a href="/wiki/Benedict_Arnold" title="Benedict Arnold">Benedict Arnold</a> and gave him responsibility for launching an invasion of Canada. He also engaged French and Indian War compatriot Brigadier General <a href="/wiki/Daniel_Morgan" title="Daniel Morgan">Daniel Morgan</a>. Henry Knox impressed Adams with ordnance knowledge, and Washington promoted him to colonel and chief of artillery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2002109–110Puls200831_114-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2002109–110Puls200831-114">[106]</a></sup>
</p><p>At the start of the war, Washington opposed the recruiting of blacks, both free and enslaved, into the Continental Army. After his appointment, Washington banned their enlistment. The British saw an opportunity to divide the colonies, and the colonial governor of Virginia issued <a href="/wiki/Dunmore%27s_Proclamation" title="Dunmore's Proclamation">a proclamation</a>, which promised freedom to slaves if they joined the British.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000290–291_115-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000290–291-115">[107]</a></sup> Desperate for manpower by late 1777, Washington relented and overturned his ban.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-116"><a href="#cite_note-116">[108]</a></sup> By the end of the war, around one-tenth of Washington's army were blacks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016231_117-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016231-117">[109]</a></sup> Following the British surrender, Washington sought to enforce terms of the preliminary <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1783)" title="Treaty of Paris (1783)">Treaty of Paris (1783)</a> by reclaiming slaves freed by the British and returning them to servitude. He arranged to make this request to <a href="/wiki/Guy_Carleton,_1st_Baron_Dorchester" title="Guy Carleton, 1st Baron Dorchester">Sir Guy Carleton</a> on May 6, 1783. Instead, Carleton issued 3,000 freedom certificates and all former slaves in New York City were able to leave before the city was evacuated by the British in late November 1783.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-118"><a href="#cite_note-118">[110]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Siege_of_Boston">Siege of Boston</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Boston" title="Siege of Boston">Siege of Boston</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Washingtoncommandarmy.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1870" data-file-width="3228" decoding="async" height="127" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Washingtoncommandarmy.jpg/220px-Washingtoncommandarmy.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Washingtoncommandarmy.jpg/330px-Washingtoncommandarmy.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/25/Washingtoncommandarmy.jpg/440px-Washingtoncommandarmy.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Washingtoncommandarmy.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Washington taking command of the Continental Army, just before the siege.</div></div></div>
<p>Early in 1775, in response to the growing rebellious movement, London sent British troops, commanded by <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Gage" title="Thomas Gage">General Thomas Gage</a>, to occupy Boston. They set up fortifications about the city, making it impervious to attack. Various local militias surrounded the city and effectively trapped the British, resulting in a standoff.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016121–122,_143_119-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016121–122,_143-119">[111]</a></sup>
</p><p>As Washington headed for Boston, word of his march preceded him, and he was greeted everywhere; gradually, he became a symbol of the Patriot cause.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010193_120-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010193-120">[112]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-121"><a href="#cite_note-121">[i]</a></sup> Upon arrival on July 2, 1775, two weeks after the Patriot defeat at nearby <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Bunker_Hill" title="Battle of Bunker Hill">Bunker Hill</a>, he set up his <a href="/wiki/Cambridge,_Massachusetts" title="Cambridge, Massachusetts">Cambridge, Massachusetts</a> headquarters and inspected the new army there, only to find an undisciplined and badly outfitted militia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016143_122-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016143-122">[113]</a></sup> After consultation, he initiated <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin" title="Benjamin Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a>'s suggested reforms—drilling the soldiers and imposing strict discipline, floggings, and incarceration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIsaacson2003303Ferling2002112Taylor2016143Fitzpatrick1936514_123-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIsaacson2003303Ferling2002112Taylor2016143Fitzpatrick1936514-123">[114]</a></sup> Washington ordered his officers to identify the skills of recruits to ensure military effectiveness, while removing incompetent officers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2002112–113,_116_124-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2002112–113,_116-124">[115]</a></sup> He petitioned Gage, his former superior, to release captured Patriot officers from prison and treat them humanely.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201057,_160,_166,_201_125-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201057,_160,_166,_201-125">[116]</a></sup> In October 1775, King <a href="/wiki/George_III" title="George III">George III</a> declared that the colonies were in open rebellion and relieved General Gage of command for incompetence, replacing him with General <a href="/wiki/William_Howe,_5th_Viscount_Howe" title="William Howe, 5th Viscount Howe">William Howe</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010208Taylor2016133–135_126-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010208Taylor2016133–135-126">[117]</a></sup>
</p><p>The Continental Army, further diminished by expiring short-term enlistments, and by January 1776 reduced by half to 9,600 men, had to be supplemented with the militia, and was joined by <a href="/wiki/Noble_train_of_artillery" title="Noble train of artillery">Knox with heavy artillery</a> captured from <a href="/wiki/Capture_of_Fort_Ticonderoga" title="Capture of Fort Ticonderoga">Fort Ticonderoga</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELengel2005124–126Ferling2002116–119_127-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELengel2005124–126Ferling2002116–119-127">[118]</a></sup> When the <a href="/wiki/Charles_River" title="Charles River">Charles River</a> froze over, Washington was eager to cross and storm Boston, but General Gates and others were opposed to untrained militia striking well-garrisoned fortifications. Washington reluctantly agreed to <a href="/wiki/Fortification_of_Dorchester_Heights" title="Fortification of Dorchester Heights">secure the Dorchester Heights</a>, 100 feet above Boston, in an attempt to force the British out of the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009100_128-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009100-128">[119]</a></sup> On March 9, under cover of darkness, Washington's troops brought up Knox's big guns and bombarded British ships in Boston harbor. On <a href="/wiki/Evacuation_Day_(Massachusetts)" title="Evacuation Day (Massachusetts)">March 17</a>, 9,000 British troops and Loyalists began a chaotic ten-day evacuation of Boston aboard 120 ships. Soon after, Washington entered the city with 500 men, with explicit orders not to plunder the city. He ordered <a href="/wiki/Variolation" title="Variolation">variolation</a> against smallpox to great effect, as he did later in Morristown, New Jersey.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHenderson200947_129-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHenderson200947-129">[120]</a></sup> He refrained from exerting military authority in Boston, leaving civilian matters in the hands of local authorities.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010227–228Lengel2005124–126Ferling2002116–119Taylor2016144,_153–154_130-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010227–228Lengel2005124–126Ferling2002116–119Taylor2016144,_153–154-130">[121]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-132"><a href="#cite_note-132">[j]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Invasion_of_Quebec_.281775.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Invasion_of_Quebec_(1775)">Invasion of Quebec (1775)</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Invasion_of_Quebec_(1775)" title="Invasion of Quebec (1775)">Invasion of Quebec (1775)</a></div>
<p>The Invasion of Quebec (June 1775 – October 1776, French: Invasion du Québec) was the first major military initiative by the newly formed Continental Army during the American Revolutionary War. On June 27, 1775, Congress authorized General Philip Schuyler to investigate, and, if it seemed appropriate, begin an invasion.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-133"><a href="#cite_note-133">[123]</a></sup> Benedict Arnold, passed over for its command, went to Boston and convinced General George Washington to send a supporting force to Quebec City under his command.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall1990131,_138_134-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall1990131,_138-134">[124]</a></sup> The objective of the campaign was to seize the Province of Quebec (part of modern-day Canada) from Great Britain, and persuade French-speaking <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Canadiens" title="Canadiens">Canadiens</a> to join the revolution on the side of the Thirteen Colonies. One expedition left Fort Ticonderoga under Richard Montgomery, besieged and captured Fort St. Johns, and very nearly captured British General Guy Carleton when taking Montreal. The other expedition, under Benedict Arnold, left Cambridge, Massachusetts and traveled with great difficulty through the wilderness of Maine to Quebec City. The two forces joined there, but they were defeated at the Battle of Quebec in December 1775, where Montgomery lost his life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010210_135-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010210-135">[125]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Battle_of_Long_Island">Battle of Long Island</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Long_Island" title="Battle of Long Island">Battle of Long Island</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Battleoflongisland.jpg"><img alt="Painting by Alonzo Chappel, 1858, showing the frantic battle scene of the Battle of Long Island, with smoke in the background" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="622" data-file-width="800" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Battleoflongisland.jpg/220px-Battleoflongisland.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Battleoflongisland.jpg/330px-Battleoflongisland.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1f/Battleoflongisland.jpg/440px-Battleoflongisland.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Battleoflongisland.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Battle of Long Island</i><br/><a href="/wiki/Alonzo_Chappel" title="Alonzo Chappel">Alonzo Chappel</a> (1858)</div></div></div>
<p>Washington then proceeded to <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a>, arriving on April 13, 1776, and began constructing fortifications to thwart the expected British attack. He ordered his occupying forces to treat civilians and their property with respect, to avoid the abuses which Bostonian citizens suffered at the hands of British troops during their occupation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010229–230_136-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010229–230-136">[126]</a></sup> A plot to assassinate or capture him was discovered and thwarted, resulting in the arrest of 98 people involved or complicit (56 of which were from Long Island (<a href="/wiki/Brooklyn" title="Brooklyn">Kings (Brooklyn)</a> and <a href="/wiki/Queens" title="Queens">Queens</a> counties), including the Loyalist Mayor of New York <a href="/wiki/David_Mathews" title="David Mathews">David Mathews</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-137"><a href="#cite_note-137">[127]</a></sup> Washington's bodyguard, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Hickey_(soldier)" title="Thomas Hickey (soldier)">Thomas Hickey</a>, was hanged for mutiny and sedition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010232–233_138-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010232–233-138">[128]</a></sup> General Howe transported his resupplied army, with the British fleet, from <a href="/wiki/Halifax,_Nova_Scotia" title="Halifax, Nova Scotia">Halifax</a> to New York, knowing the city was key to securing the continent. <a href="/wiki/George_Germain,_1st_Viscount_Sackville" title="George Germain, 1st Viscount Sackville">George Germain</a>, who ran the British war effort in England, believed it could be won with one "decisive blow".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010235_139-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010235-139">[129]</a></sup> The British forces, including more than a hundred ships and thousands of troops, began arriving on <a href="/wiki/Staten_Island" title="Staten Island">Staten Island</a> on July<span class="nowrap"> </span>2 to lay siege to the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1936514–515Taylor2016162–163_140-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1936514–515Taylor2016162–163-140">[130]</a></sup> After the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence" title="United States Declaration of Independence">Declaration of Independence</a> was adopted on July 4, Washington informed his troops in his general orders of July<span class="nowrap"> </span>9 that Congress had declared the united colonies to be "free and independent states".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010237_141-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010237-141">[131]</a></sup>
</p><p>Howe's troop strength totaled 32,000 regulars and <a href="/wiki/Hessian_(soldier)" title="Hessian (soldier)">Hessian auxiliaries</a>, and Washington's consisted of 23,000, mostly raw recruits and militia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010244–245Taylor2016162–163_142-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010244–245Taylor2016162–163-142">[132]</a></sup> In August, Howe landed 20,000 troops at <a href="/wiki/Gravesend,_Brooklyn" title="Gravesend, Brooklyn">Gravesend, Brooklyn</a>, and approached Washington's fortifications, as George III proclaimed the rebellious American colonists to be traitors.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016144_143-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016144-143">[133]</a></sup> Washington, opposing his generals, chose to fight, based upon inaccurate information that Howe's army had only 8,000-plus troops.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllis200495–96Chernow2010244_144-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllis200495–96Chernow2010244-144">[134]</a></sup> In the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Long_Island" title="Battle of Long Island">Battle of Long Island</a>, Howe <a href="/wiki/New_York_and_New_Jersey_campaign" title="New York and New Jersey campaign">assaulted Washington's flank</a> and inflicted 1,500 Patriot casualties, the British suffering 400.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016164_145-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016164-145">[135]</a></sup> Washington retreated, instructing General <a href="/wiki/William_Heath" title="William Heath">William Heath</a> to acquisition river craft in the area. On August 30, General <a href="/wiki/William_Alexander,_Lord_Stirling" title="William Alexander, Lord Stirling">William Alexander</a> held off the British and gave cover while the army crossed the <a href="/wiki/East_River" title="East River">East River</a> under darkness to <a href="/wiki/Manhattan" title="Manhattan">Manhattan</a> Island without loss of life or materiel, although Alexander was captured.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMcCullough2005186–195_146-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcCullough2005186–195-146">[136]</a></sup>
</p><p>Howe, emboldened by his Long Island victory, dispatched Washington as "George Washington, Esq." in futility to negotiate peace. Washington declined, demanding to be addressed with diplomatic protocol, as general and fellow belligerent, not as a "rebel", lest his men are hanged as such if captured.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010240Davis197593–94Taylor2016164_147-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010240Davis197593–94Taylor2016164-147">[137]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Royal_Navy" title="Royal Navy">Royal Navy</a> bombarded the unstable earthworks on lower Manhattan Island.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016165_148-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016165-148">[138]</a></sup> Washington, with misgivings, heeded the advice of Generals Greene and <a href="/wiki/Israel_Putnam" title="Israel Putnam">Putnam</a> to defend <a href="/wiki/Fort_Washington_(Manhattan)" title="Fort Washington (Manhattan)">Fort Washington</a>.
