They were unable to hold it, and Washington abandoned it despite General <a href="/wiki/Charles_Lee_(general)" title="Charles Lee (general)">Lee</a>'s objections, as his army retired north to the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_White_Plains" title="Battle of White Plains">White Plains</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDavis1975136Chernow2010257_149-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDavis1975136Chernow2010257-149">[139]</a></sup> Howe's pursuit forced Washington to retreat across the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a> to <a href="/wiki/Fort_Lee_Historic_Park" title="Fort Lee Historic Park">Fort Lee</a> to avoid encirclement. Howe landed his troops on Manhattan in November and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Washington" title="Battle of Fort Washington">captured Fort Washington</a>, inflicting high casualties on the Americans. Washington was responsible for delaying the retreat, though he blamed Congress and General Greene. Loyalists in New York considered Howe a liberator and spread a rumor that Washington had set fire to the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996137Taylor2016165_150-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996137Taylor2016165-150">[140]</a></sup> Patriot morale reached its lowest when Lee was captured.<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016166–167Farner199624"Battle_of_Trenton"19769_151-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016166–167Farner199624"Battle_of_Trenton"19769-151'>[141]</a></sup> Now reduced to 5,400 troops, Washington's army retreated through <a href="/wiki/Province_of_New_Jersey" title="Province of New Jersey">New Jersey</a>, and Howe broke off pursuit, delaying his advance on Philadelphia, and set up winter quarters in New York.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFischer2004224–226Taylor2016166–169_152-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFischer2004224–226Taylor2016166–169-152">[142]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Crossing_the_Delaware.2C_Trenton.2C_and_Princeton"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Crossing_the_Delaware,_Trenton,_and_Princeton">Crossing the Delaware, Trenton, and Princeton</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/George_Washington%27s_crossing_of_the_Delaware_River" title="George Washington's crossing of the Delaware River">George Washington's crossing of the Delaware River</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Trenton" title="Battle of Trenton">Battle of Trenton</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Assunpink_Creek" title="Battle of the Assunpink Creek">Battle of the Assunpink Creek</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Princeton" title="Battle of Princeton">Battle of Princeton</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze,_MMA-NYC,_1851.jpg"><img alt="Famous 1851 painting by Emanuel Leutze, depicting Washington, standing in a boat with his troops, crossing the icy Delaware River, with soldiers pushing away chunks of ice" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3847" data-file-width="6004" decoding="async" height="141" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze%2C_MMA-NYC%2C_1851.jpg/220px-Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze%2C_MMA-NYC%2C_1851.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze%2C_MMA-NYC%2C_1851.jpg/330px-Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze%2C_MMA-NYC%2C_1851.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze%2C_MMA-NYC%2C_1851.jpg/440px-Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze%2C_MMA-NYC%2C_1851.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze,_MMA-NYC,_1851.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_(1851_painting)" title="Washington Crossing the Delaware (1851 painting)">Washington Crossing the Delaware</a></i>, <a href="/wiki/Emanuel_Leutze" title="Emanuel Leutze">Emanuel Leutze</a> (1851)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-154"><a href="#cite_note-154">[k]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<p>Washington crossed the <a href="/wiki/Delaware_River" title="Delaware River">Delaware River</a> into Pennsylvania, where Lee's replacement <a href="/wiki/John_Sullivan_(general)" title="John Sullivan (general)">John Sullivan</a> joined him with 2,000 more troops.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016166–167,_169_155-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016166–167,_169-155">[144]</a></sup> The future of the Continental Army was in doubt for lack of supplies, a harsh winter, expiring enlistments, and desertions. Washington was disappointed that many New Jersey residents were Loyalists or skeptical about the prospect of independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKetchum1999235Chernow2010264_156-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKetchum1999235Chernow2010264-156">[145]</a></sup>
</p><p>Howe split up his British Army and posted a <a href="/wiki/Hessian_(soldier)" title="Hessian (soldier)">Hessian</a> garrison at <a href="/wiki/Trenton,_New_Jersey" title="Trenton, New Jersey">Trenton</a> to hold western New Jersey and the east shore of the Delaware,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016169_157-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016169-157">[146]</a></sup> but the army appeared complacent, and Washington and his generals devised a surprise attack on the Hessians at Trenton, which he codenamed "Victory or Death".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010270–273_158-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010270–273-158">[147]</a></sup> The army was to cross the Delaware River to Trenton in three divisions: one led by Washington (2,400 troops), another by General <a href="/wiki/James_Ewing_(Pennsylvania_politician)" title="James Ewing (Pennsylvania politician)">James Ewing</a> (700), and the third by Colonel <a href="/wiki/John_Cadwalader_(general)" title="John Cadwalader (general)">John Cadwalader</a> (1,500). The force was to then split, with Washington taking the <a href="/wiki/Pennington,_New_Jersey" title="Pennington, New Jersey">Pennington</a> Road and General Sullivan traveling south on the river's edge.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010272_159-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010272-159">[148]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:1819_Passage_OfThe_Delaware_byThomasSully_MFABoston.jpeg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1452" data-file-width="2048" decoding="async" height="156" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/1819_Passage_OfThe_Delaware_byThomasSully_MFABoston.jpeg/220px-1819_Passage_OfThe_Delaware_byThomasSully_MFABoston.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/1819_Passage_OfThe_Delaware_byThomasSully_MFABoston.jpeg/330px-1819_Passage_OfThe_Delaware_byThomasSully_MFABoston.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c2/1819_Passage_OfThe_Delaware_byThomasSully_MFABoston.jpeg/440px-1819_Passage_OfThe_Delaware_byThomasSully_MFABoston.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:1819_Passage_OfThe_Delaware_byThomasSully_MFABoston.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/The_Passage_of_the_Delaware" title="The Passage of the Delaware">The Passage of the Delaware</a></i>, by <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Sully" title="Thomas Sully">Thomas Sully</a>, 1819 (<a href="/wiki/Museum_of_Fine_Arts,_Boston" title="Museum of Fine Arts, Boston">Museum of Fine Arts, Boston</a>)</div></div></div>
<p>Washington first ordered a 60-mile search for <a href="/wiki/Durham_boat" title="Durham boat">Durham boats</a> to transport his army, and he ordered the destruction of vessels that could be used by the British.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010270–272Randall1997319_160-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010270–272Randall1997319-160">[149]</a></sup> Washington <a href="/wiki/George_Washington%27s_crossing_of_the_Delaware_River" title="George Washington's crossing of the Delaware River">crossed the Delaware River</a> on <a href="/wiki/Christmas" title="Christmas">Christmas</a> night,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillcoxArnstein1988164_161-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillcoxArnstein1988164-161">[150]</a></sup> December 25, 1776, while he personally risked capture staking out the Jersey shoreline. His men followed across the ice-obstructed river in sleet and snow from <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/McConkey%27s_Ferry" title="McConkey's Ferry">McConkey's Ferry</a>, with 40 men per vessel. The wind churned up the waters, and they were pelted with hail, but by 3:00<span class="nowrap"> </span>a.m. on December 26, they made it across with no losses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010273_162-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010273-162">[151]</a></sup> Henry Knox was delayed, managing frightened horses and about 18 field guns on flat-bottomed ferries. Cadwalader and Ewing failed to cross due to the ice and heavy currents, and awaiting Washington doubted his planned attack on Trenton. Once Knox arrived, Washington proceeded to Trenton to take only his troops against the Hessians, rather than risk being spotted returning his army to Pennsylvania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010273–274Fischer2004215–219Taylor2016171_163-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010273–274Fischer2004215–219Taylor2016171-163">[152]</a></sup>
</p><p>The troops spotted Hessian positions a mile from Trenton, so Washington split his force into two columns, rallying his men: "Soldiers keep by your officers. For God's sake, keep by your officers." The two columns were separated at the Birmingham crossroads. General Nathanael Greene's column took the upper Ferry Road, led by Washington, and General John Sullivan's column advanced on River Road. (<a href="/wiki/File:Battle_of_Trenton.Dean.USMA.edu.history.gif" title="File:Battle of Trenton.Dean.USMA.edu.history.gif">See map</a>.)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFischer2004228–230_164-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFischer2004228–230-164">[153]</a></sup> The Americans marched in sleet and snowfall. Many were shoeless with bloodied feet, and two died of exposure. Meanwhile, Hessian Commander <a href="/wiki/Johann_Rall" title="Johann Rall">Johann Rall</a> was held up at the home of <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Hunt" title="Abraham Hunt">Abraham Hunt</a>, of Trenton, who had placated Rall and some of his officers with plenty of food and drink into the late hours of the evening and morning. At sunrise, Washington, aided by Major General Knox and artillery, led his men in a surprise attack on an unsuspecting Rall. The Hessians had 22 killed, including Colonel Rall, 83 wounded, and 850 captured with supplies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010270,_275–276Ferling2002146–147Fischer2004170,_232–234,_254,_405_165-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010270,_275–276Ferling2002146–147Fischer2004170,_232–234,_254,_405-165">[154]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:The_Capture_of_the_Hessians_at_Trenton_December_26_1776.jpeg"><img alt="Painting showing Washington on horseback, accepting the surrender of Hessian troops after the Battle at Trenton" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1992" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/The_Capture_of_the_Hessians_at_Trenton_December_26_1776.jpeg/220px-The_Capture_of_the_Hessians_at_Trenton_December_26_1776.jpeg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/The_Capture_of_the_Hessians_at_Trenton_December_26_1776.jpeg/330px-The_Capture_of_the_Hessians_at_Trenton_December_26_1776.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/31/The_Capture_of_the_Hessians_at_Trenton_December_26_1776.jpeg/440px-The_Capture_of_the_Hessians_at_Trenton_December_26_1776.jpeg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:The_Capture_of_the_Hessians_at_Trenton_December_26_1776.jpeg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/The_Capture_of_the_Hessians_at_Trenton,_December_26,_1776" title="The Capture of the Hessians at Trenton, December 26, 1776">The Capture of the Hessians at Trenton, December 26, 1776</a></i><br/>by <a href="/wiki/John_Trumbull" title="John Trumbull">John Trumbull</a></div></div></div>
<p>Washington retreated across the Delaware River to Pennsylvania and returned to New Jersey on January 3, 1777, launching <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Princeton" title="Battle of Princeton">an attack</a> on British regulars at <a href="/wiki/Princeton,_New_Jersey" title="Princeton, New Jersey">Princeton</a>, with 40 Americans killed or wounded and 273 British killed or captured.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFischer2004254Ketchum1999306–307Alden1996146_166-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFischer2004254Ketchum1999306–307Alden1996146-166">[155]</a></sup> American Generals <a href="/wiki/Hugh_Mercer" title="Hugh Mercer">Hugh Mercer</a> and John Cadwalader were being driven back by the British when Mercer was mortally wounded, then Washington arrived and led the men in a counterattack which advanced to within 30 yards (27 m) of the British line.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996145_167-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996145-167">[156]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some British troops retreated after a brief stand, while others took refuge in <a href="/wiki/Nassau_Hall" title="Nassau Hall">Nassau Hall</a>, which became the target of Colonel <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a>'s cannons. Washington's troops charged, the British surrendered in less than an hour, and 194 soldiers laid down their arms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKetchum1999361–364Fischer2004339Chernow2010276–278_168-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKetchum1999361–364Fischer2004339Chernow2010276–278-168">[157]</a></sup> Howe retreated to New York City where his army remained inactive until early the next year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016172_169-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016172-169">[158]</a></sup> Washington's depleted Continental Army took up winter headquarters in <a href="/wiki/Morristown,_New_Jersey" title="Morristown, New Jersey">Morristown, New Jersey</a> while disrupting British supply lines and expelling them from parts of New Jersey. Washington later said the British could have successfully counterattacked his encampment before his troops were dug in.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010285–286_170-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010285–286-170">[159]</a></sup> The victories at Trenton and Princeton by Washington revived Patriot morale and changed the course of the war. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillcoxArnstein1988164_161-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillcoxArnstein1988164-161">[150]</a></sup>
</p><p>The British still controlled New York, and many Patriot soldiers did not re-enlist or deserted after the harsh winter campaign. Congress instituted greater rewards for re-enlisting and punishments for desertion to effect greater troop numbers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFischer2004151_171-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFischer2004151-171">[160]</a></sup> Strategically, Washington's victories were pivotal for the Revolution and quashed the British strategy of showing overwhelming force followed by offering generous terms.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016172Fischer2004367_172-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016172Fischer2004367-172">[161]</a></sup> In February 1777, word reached London of the American victories at Trenton and Princeton, and the British realized the Patriots were in a position to demand unconditional independence.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2007188_173-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2007188-173">[162]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Brandywine.2C_Germantown.2C_and_Saratoga"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Brandywine,_Germantown,_and_Saratoga">Brandywine, Germantown, and Saratoga</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Brandywine" title="Battle of Brandywine">Battle of Brandywine</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Germantown" title="Battle of Germantown">Battle of Germantown</a>, and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Battle_of_Saratoga" title="Battle of Saratoga">Battle of Saratoga</a></div>
<p>In July 1777, British General <a href="/wiki/John_Burgoyne" title="John Burgoyne">John Burgoyne</a> led the <a href="/wiki/Saratoga_campaign" title="Saratoga campaign">Saratoga campaign</a> south from Quebec through <a href="/wiki/Lake_Champlain" title="Lake Champlain">Lake Champlain</a> and <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Fort_Ticonderoga_(1777)" title="Siege of Fort Ticonderoga (1777)">recaptured Fort Ticonderoga</a> intending to divide <a href="/wiki/New_England" title="New England">New England</a>, including control of the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>. However, General Howe in British-occupied New York blundered, taking his army south to Philadelphia rather than up the Hudson River to join Burgoyne near <a href="/wiki/Albany,_New_York" title="Albany, New York">Albany</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010300–301_174-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010300–301-174">[163]</a></sup> Meanwhile, Washington and <a href="/wiki/Gilbert_du_Motier,_Marquis_de_Lafayette" title="Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette">Gilbert du Motier, Marquis de Lafayette</a> rushed to Philadelphia to engage Howe and were shocked to learn of Burgoyne's progress in upstate New York, where the Patriots were led by General <a href="/wiki/Philip_Schuyler" title="Philip Schuyler">Philip Schuyler</a> and successor <a href="/wiki/Horatio_Gates" title="Horatio Gates">Horatio Gates</a>. Washington's army of less experienced men were defeated in the <a href="/wiki/Philadelphia_campaign" title="Philadelphia campaign">pitched battles</a> at Philadelphia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall1997340–341Chernow2010301–304_175-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall1997340–341Chernow2010301–304-175">[164]</a></sup>
</p><p>Howe outmaneuvered Washington at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Brandywine" title="Battle of Brandywine">Battle of Brandywine</a> on September 11, 1777, and marched unopposed into the nation's capital at Philadelphia. A Patriot <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Germantown" title="Battle of Germantown">attack</a> failed against the British at <a href="/wiki/Germantown,_Philadelphia" title="Germantown, Philadelphia">Germantown</a> in October. Major General <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Conway" title="Thomas Conway">Thomas Conway</a> prompted some members of Congress (referred to as the <a href="/wiki/Conway_Cabal" title="Conway Cabal">Conway Cabal</a>) to consider removing Washington from command because of the losses incurred at Philadelphia. Washington's supporters resisted, and the matter was finally dropped after much deliberation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHeydt200550–73_176-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHeydt200550–73-176">[165]</a></sup> Once the plot was exposed, Conway wrote an apology to Washington, resigned, and returned to France.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlexner1965138Randall1997354–355_177-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlexner1965138Randall1997354–355-177">[166]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington was concerned with Howe's movements during the Saratoga campaign to the north, and he was also aware that Burgoyne was moving south toward Saratoga from Quebec. Washington took some risks to support Gates' army, sending reinforcements north with Generals <a href="/wiki/Benedict_Arnold" title="Benedict Arnold">Benedict Arnold</a>, his most aggressive field commander, and <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Lincoln" title="Benjamin Lincoln">Benjamin Lincoln</a>. On October 7, 1777, Burgoyne tried to take <a href="/wiki/Battles_of_Saratoga" title="Battles of Saratoga">Bemis Heights</a> but was isolated from support by Howe. He was forced to retreat to Saratoga and ultimately surrendered after the <a href="/wiki/Battles_of_Saratoga" title="Battles of Saratoga">Battles of Saratoga</a>. As Washington suspected, Gates' victory emboldened his critics.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010312–313_178-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010312–313-178">[167]</a></sup> Biographer John Alden maintains, "It was inevitable that the defeats of Washington's forces and the concurrent victory of the forces in upper New York should be compared." The admiration for Washington was waning, including little credit from John Adams.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996163_179-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996163-179">[168]</a></sup> British commander Howe resigned in May 1778, left America forever, and was replaced by <a href="/wiki/Henry_Clinton_(British_Army_officer,_born_1730)" title="Henry Clinton (British Army officer, born 1730)">Sir Henry Clinton</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2007296_180-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2007296-180">[169]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Valley_Forge_and_Monmouth">Valley Forge and Monmouth</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Valley_Forge" title="Valley Forge">Valley Forge</a> and <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Monmouth" title="Battle of Monmouth">Battle of Monmouth</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Washington_and_Lafayette_at_Valley_Forge.jpg"><img alt="Painting showing Washington and Lafayette on horseback in a winter setting, at Valley Forge" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2664" data-file-width="3362" decoding="async" height="174" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Washington_and_Lafayette_at_Valley_Forge.jpg/220px-Washington_and_Lafayette_at_Valley_Forge.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Washington_and_Lafayette_at_Valley_Forge.jpg/330px-Washington_and_Lafayette_at_Valley_Forge.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/55/Washington_and_Lafayette_at_Valley_Forge.jpg/440px-Washington_and_Lafayette_at_Valley_Forge.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Washington_and_Lafayette_at_Valley_Forge.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Washington and Lafayette at Valley Forge</i>, by John Ward Dunsmore (1907)</div></div></div>
<p>Washington's army of 11,000 went into winter quarters at <a href="/wiki/Valley_Forge" title="Valley Forge">Valley Forge</a> north of Philadelphia in December 1777. They suffered between 2,000 and 3,000 deaths in the extreme cold over six months, mostly from disease and lack of food, clothing, and shelter.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2002186Alden1996165,_167Freedman200830_181-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2002186Alden1996165,_167Freedman200830-181">[170]</a></sup> Meanwhile, the British were comfortably quartered in Philadelphia, paying for supplies in <a href="/wiki/Pound_sterling" title="Pound sterling">pounds sterling</a>, while Washington struggled with a devalued <a href="/wiki/Early_American_currency" title="Early American currency">American paper currency</a>. The woodlands were soon exhausted of game, and by February, lowered morale and increased desertions ensued.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996165_182-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996165-182">[171]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington made repeated petitions to the Continental Congress for provisions. He received a congressional delegation to check the Army's conditions and expressed the urgency of the situation, proclaiming: "Something must be done. Important alterations must be made." He recommended that Congress expedite supplies, and Congress agreed to strengthen and fund the army's supply lines by reorganizing the commissary department. By late February, supplies began arriving.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFreedman200842_131-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFreedman200842-131">[122]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:BattleofMonmouth.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1367" data-file-width="2000" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/BattleofMonmouth.jpg/220px-BattleofMonmouth.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/BattleofMonmouth.jpg/330px-BattleofMonmouth.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/BattleofMonmouth.jpg/440px-BattleofMonmouth.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:BattleofMonmouth.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Washington Rallying the Troops at Monmouth</i>, <a href="/wiki/Emanuel_Leutze" title="Emanuel Leutze">Emanuel Leutze</a> (1851–1854)</div></div></div>
<p>Baron <a href="/wiki/Friedrich_Wilhelm_von_Steuben" title="Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben">Friedrich Wilhelm von Steuben</a>'s incessant drilling soon transformed Washington's recruits into a disciplined fighting force,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall1997342,_359Ferling2009172_183-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall1997342,_359Ferling2009172-183">[172]</a></sup> and the revitalized army emerged from Valley Forge early the following year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996168Randall1997342,_356_184-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996168Randall1997342,_356-184">[173]</a></sup> Washington promoted Von Steuben to Major General and made him chief of staff.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010336_185-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010336-185">[174]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early 1778, the French responded to Burgoyne's defeat and entered into a <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Alliance_(1778)" title="Treaty of Alliance (1778)">Treaty of Alliance</a> with the Americans. The Continental Congress ratified the treaty in May, which amounted to a French declaration of war against Britain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016188_186-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016188-186">[175]</a></sup>
</p><p>The British evacuated Philadelphia for New York that June and Washington summoned a war council of American and French Generals. He chose a partial attack on the retreating British at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Monmouth" title="Battle of Monmouth">Battle of Monmouth</a>; the British were commanded by Howe's successor General <a href="/wiki/Henry_Clinton_(British_Army_officer,_born_1730)" title="Henry Clinton (British Army officer, born 1730)">Henry Clinton</a>. Generals <a href="/wiki/Charles_Lee_(general)" title="Charles Lee (general)">Charles Lee</a> and Lafayette moved with 4,000 men, without Washington's knowledge, and bungled their first attack on June 28. Washington relieved Lee and achieved a draw after an expansive battle. At nightfall, the British continued their retreat to New York, and Washington moved his army outside the city.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996176–177Ferling2002195–198_187-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996176–177Ferling2002195–198-187">[176]</a></sup> Monmouth was Washington's last battle in the North; he valued the safety of his army more than towns with little value to the British.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010344_188-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010344-188">[177]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="West_Point_espionage">West Point espionage</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_Point" title="West Point">West Point</a> and <a href="/wiki/Military_career_of_Benedict_Arnold,_1777%E2%80%931779" title="Military career of Benedict Arnold, 1777–1779">Military career of Benedict Arnold, 1777–1779</a></div>
<p>Washington became "America's first spymaster" by designing an espionage system against the British.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENagy2016274_189-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENagy2016274-189">[178]</a></sup> In 1778, Major <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Tallmadge" title="Benjamin Tallmadge">Benjamin Tallmadge</a> formed the <a href="/wiki/Culper_Ring" title="Culper Ring">Culper Ring</a> at Washington's direction to covertly collect information about the British in New York.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERose200675,_224,_258–261_190-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERose200675,_224,_258–261-190">[179]</a></sup> Washington had disregarded incidents of disloyalty by <a href="/wiki/Benedict_Arnold" title="Benedict Arnold">Benedict Arnold</a>, who had distinguished himself in many battles.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010378–387Philbrick201635_191-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010378–387Philbrick201635-191">[180]</a></sup>
</p><p>During mid-1780, Arnold began supplying British spymaster <a href="/wiki/John_Andr%C3%A9" title="John André">John André</a> with sensitive information intended to compromise Washington and capture <a href="/wiki/West_Point,_New_York" title="West Point, New York">West Point</a>, a key American defensive position on the <a href="/wiki/Hudson_River" title="Hudson River">Hudson River</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAdams1928365–366Philbrick2016250–251_192-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAdams1928365–366Philbrick2016250–251-192">[181]</a></sup> Historians<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions" title="Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch"><span title="The material near this tag possibly uses too-vague attribution or weasel words. (March 2021)">who?</span></a></i>]</sup> have noted as possible reasons for Arnold's defection to be his anger at losing promotions to junior officers, or repeated slights<sup class="noprint Inline-Template" style="margin-left:0.1em; white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Please_clarify" title="Wikipedia:Please clarify"><span title="The text near this tag may need clarification or removal of jargon. (March 2021)">clarification needed</span></a></i>]</sup> from Congress. He was also deeply in debt, profiteering from the war, and disappointed by Washington's lack of support during his eventual <a href="/wiki/Court-martial" title="Court-martial">court-martial</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010380Palmer2010203Flexner1991119–221Rose2006196_193-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010380Palmer2010203Flexner1991119–221Rose2006196-193">[182]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_washington.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="279" data-file-width="300" decoding="async" height="205" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d5/George_washington.jpg/220px-George_washington.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/d5/George_washington.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_washington.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>An engraving of Washington, likely made after his tenure in the army.</div></div></div>
<p>Arnold repeatedly asked for command of West Point, and Washington finally agreed in August.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010378,_380–381Lengel2005322Adams1928366Philbrick2016280–282_194-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010378,_380–381Lengel2005322Adams1928366Philbrick2016280–282-194">[183]</a></sup> Arnold met André on September 21, giving him plans to take over the garrison.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAdams1928365Palmer2010306,_315,_319,_320_195-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAdams1928365Palmer2010306,_315,_319,_320-195">[184]</a></sup> Militia forces captured André and discovered the plans, but Arnold escaped to New York.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVan_Doren1941194–195Adams1928366Palmer2010410_196-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVan_Doren1941194–195Adams1928366Palmer2010410-196">[185]</a></sup> Washington recalled the commanders positioned under Arnold at key points around the fort to prevent any complicity, but he did not suspect Arnold's wife <a href="/wiki/Peggy_Shippen" title="Peggy Shippen">Peggy</a>. Washington assumed personal command at West Point and reorganized its defenses.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEPalmer2010370–371Middlekauff2015232_197-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPalmer2010370–371Middlekauff2015232-197">[186]</a></sup> André's trial for espionage ended in a death sentence, and Washington offered to return him to the British in exchange for Arnold, but <a href="/wiki/Henry_Clinton_(British_Army_officer,_born_1730)" title="Henry Clinton (British Army officer, born 1730)">Clinton</a> refused. André was hanged on October 2, 1780, despite his last request being to face a firing squad, to deter other spies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlexner1991386Rose2006212_198-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlexner1991386Rose2006212-198">[187]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Southern_theater_and_Yorktown">Southern theater and Yorktown</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Southern_theater_of_the_American_Revolutionary_War" title="Southern theater of the American Revolutionary War">Southern theater of the American Revolutionary War</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Antoine-Fran%C3%A7ois_Callet_-_Louis_XVI,_roi_de_France_et_de_Navarre_(1754-1793),_rev%C3%AAtu_du_grand_costume_royal_en_1779_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg"><img alt="Painting showing French King Louis XVI, standing, wearing formal King's robe" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5062" data-file-width="3592" decoding="async" height="240" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Antoine-Fran%C3%A7ois_Callet_-_Louis_XVI%2C_roi_de_France_et_de_Navarre_%281754-1793%29%2C_rev%C3%AAtu_du_grand_costume_royal_en_1779_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/170px-Antoine-Fran%C3%A7ois_Callet_-_Louis_XVI%2C_roi_de_France_et_de_Navarre_%281754-1793%29%2C_rev%C3%AAtu_du_grand_costume_royal_en_1779_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Antoine-Fran%C3%A7ois_Callet_-_Louis_XVI%2C_roi_de_France_et_de_Navarre_%281754-1793%29%2C_rev%C3%AAtu_du_grand_costume_royal_en_1779_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/255px-Antoine-Fran%C3%A7ois_Callet_-_Louis_XVI%2C_roi_de_France_et_de_Navarre_%281754-1793%29%2C_rev%C3%AAtu_du_grand_costume_royal_en_1779_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ce/Antoine-Fran%C3%A7ois_Callet_-_Louis_XVI%2C_roi_de_France_et_de_Navarre_%281754-1793%29%2C_rev%C3%AAtu_du_grand_costume_royal_en_1779_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg/340px-Antoine-Fran%C3%A7ois_Callet_-_Louis_XVI%2C_roi_de_France_et_de_Navarre_%281754-1793%29%2C_rev%C3%AAtu_du_grand_costume_royal_en_1779_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Antoine-Fran%C3%A7ois_Callet_-_Louis_XVI,_roi_de_France_et_de_Navarre_(1754-1793),_rev%C3%AAtu_du_grand_costume_royal_en_1779_-_Google_Art_Project.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>French King <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Louis_XVI_of_France" title="Louis XVI of France">Louis XVI</a> allied with Washington and Patriot American colonists</div></div></div>
<p>In late 1778, General Clinton shipped 3,000 troops from New York to Georgia and launched a Southern invasion against <a href="/wiki/Savannah,_Georgia" title="Savannah, Georgia">Savannah</a>, reinforced by 2,000 British and Loyalist troops. They repelled an attack by Patriots and <a href="/wiki/French_Navy" title="French Navy">French naval forces</a>, which bolstered the British war effort.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016230_199-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016230-199">[188]</a></sup>
</p><p>In June 1778, <a href="/wiki/Iroquois" title="Iroquois">Iroquois</a> warriors joined with <a href="/wiki/Loyalist_(American_Revolution)" title="Loyalist (American Revolution)">Loyalist</a> rangers led by <a href="/wiki/Walter_Butler_(Loyalist)" title="Walter Butler (Loyalist)">Walter Butler</a> and killed more than 200 frontiersmen in June, laying waste to the <a href="/wiki/Wyoming_Valley" title="Wyoming Valley">Wyoming Valley</a> in Pennsylvania.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996184_200-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996184-200">[189]</a></sup> In mid-1779, in response to this and other attacks on New England towns, Washington ordered General John Sullivan to lead an expedition to force the Iroquois out of New York by effecting "the total destruction and devastation" of their villages and by taking their women and children hostage.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrizzard2002303_201-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrizzard2002303-201">[190]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010360_202-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010360-202">[191]</a></sup> The expedition systematically destroyed Iroquois villages and food stocks, and forced at least 5,036 Iroquois to flee to British Canada. The campaign directly killed a few hundred Iroquois, but according to anthropologist <a href="/wiki/Anthony_F._C._Wallace" title="Anthony F. C. Wallace">Anthony F. C. Wallace</a>, the net effect of the campaign was to reduce the Iroquois by half, who became unable to support themselves or survive the harsh winter of 1779–1780. Rhiannon Koehler estimates that as many as 5,500 Iroquois, around 55.5% of the population, may have perished as a result of the campaign, which some historians have described as genocidal.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-203"><a href="#cite_note-203">[192]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-204"><a href="#cite_note-204">[193]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington's troops went into quarters at Morristown, New Jersey during the winter of 1779–1780 and suffered their worst winter of the war, with temperatures well below freezing. <a href="/wiki/New_York_Harbor" title="New York Harbor">New York Harbor</a> was frozen over, snow and ice covered the ground for weeks, and the troops again lacked provisions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMann2008108_205-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMann2008108-205">[194]</a></sup>
</p><p>Clinton assembled 12,500 troops and attacked <a href="/wiki/Charleston,_South_Carolina" title="Charleston, South Carolina">Charlestown, South Carolina</a> in January 1780, defeating General <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Lincoln" title="Benjamin Lincoln">Benjamin Lincoln</a> who had only 5,100 Continental troops.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016234_206-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016234-206">[195]</a></sup> The British went on to occupy the <a href="/wiki/South_Carolina" title="South Carolina">South Carolina</a> <a href="/wiki/Piedmont_(United_States)" title="Piedmont (United States)">Piedmont</a> in June, with no Patriot resistance. Clinton returned to New York and left 8,000 troops commanded by General <a href="/wiki/Charles_Cornwallis,_1st_Marquess_Cornwallis" title="Charles Cornwallis, 1st Marquess Cornwallis">Charles Cornwallis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016234–235_207-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016234–235-207">[196]</a></sup> Congress replaced Lincoln with Horatio Gates; he failed in South Carolina and was replaced by Washington's choice of Nathaniel Greene, but the British already had the South in their grasp. Washington was reinvigorated, however, when Lafayette returned from France with more ships, men, and supplies,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996187–188_208-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996187–188-208">[197]</a></sup> and 5,000 veteran French troops led by Marshal <a href="/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Donatien_de_Vimeur,_comte_de_Rochambeau" title="Jean-Baptiste Donatien de Vimeur, comte de Rochambeau">Rochambeau</a> arrived at <a href="/wiki/Newport,_Rhode_Island" title="Newport, Rhode Island">Newport, Rhode Island</a> in July 1780.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELancasterPlumb1985311_209-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELancasterPlumb1985311-209">[198]</a></sup> French naval forces then landed, led by Admiral <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Joseph_Paul_de_Grasse" title="François Joseph Paul de Grasse">Grasse</a>, and Washington encouraged Rochambeau to move his fleet south to launch a joint land and naval attack on Arnold's troops.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996197–199,_206_210-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996197–199,_206-210">[199]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington's army went into winter quarters at <a href="/wiki/New_Windsor,_New_York" title="New Windsor, New York">New Windsor, New York</a> in December 1780, and Washington urged Congress and state officials to expedite provisions in hopes that the army would not "continue to struggle under the same difficulties they have hitherto endured".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996193_211-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996193-211">[200]</a></sup> On March 1, 1781, Congress ratified the <a href="/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation" title="Articles of Confederation">Articles of Confederation</a>, but the government that took effect on March<span class="nowrap"> </span>2 did not have the power to levy taxes, and it loosely held the states together.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016339_212-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016339-212">[201]</a></sup>
</p><p>General Clinton sent Benedict Arnold, now a British Brigadier General with 1,700 troops, to Virginia to capture <a href="/wiki/Portsmouth,_Virginia" title="Portsmouth, Virginia">Portsmouth</a> and conduct raids on Patriot forces from there; Washington responded by sending Lafayette south to counter Arnold's efforts.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010403_213-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010403-213">[202]</a></sup> Washington initially hoped to bring the fight to New York, drawing off British forces from Virginia and ending the war there, but Rochambeau advised Grasse that <a href="/wiki/Charles_Cornwallis,_1st_Marquess_Cornwallis" title="Charles Cornwallis, 1st Marquess Cornwallis">Cornwallis</a> in Virginia was the better target. Grasse's fleet arrived off the Virginia coast, and Washington saw the advantage. He made a feint towards Clinton in New York, then headed south to Virginia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996198–199Chernow2010403–404_214-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996198–199Chernow2010403–404-214">[203]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Couder_Yorktown_Versailles.JPG"><img alt="Generals Washington and Rochambeau, standing in front of HQ tent, giving last orders before the attack on Yorktown" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2592" data-file-width="3872" decoding="async" height="147" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Couder_Yorktown_Versailles.JPG/220px-Couder_Yorktown_Versailles.JPG" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Couder_Yorktown_Versailles.JPG/330px-Couder_Yorktown_Versailles.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/86/Couder_Yorktown_Versailles.JPG/440px-Couder_Yorktown_Versailles.JPG 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Couder_Yorktown_Versailles.JPG" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Yorktown" title="Siege of Yorktown">Siege of Yorktown</a>, Generals Washington and <a href="/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_Donatien_de_Vimeur,_comte_de_Rochambeau" title="Jean-Baptiste Donatien de Vimeur, comte de Rochambeau">Rochambeau</a> give last orders before the attack</div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/wiki/Siege_of_Yorktown" title="Siege of Yorktown">Siege of Yorktown</a> was a decisive Allied victory by the combined forces of the Continental Army commanded by General Washington, the French Army commanded by the General Comte de Rochambeau, and the French Navy commanded by Admiral <a href="/wiki/Fran%C3%A7ois_Joseph_Paul_de_Grasse" title="François Joseph Paul de Grasse">de Grasse</a>, in the defeat of Cornwallis' British forces. On August 19, the march to Yorktown led by Washington and Rochambeau began, which is known now as the <a href="/wiki/Washington%E2%80%93Rochambeau_Revolutionary_Route" title="Washington–Rochambeau Revolutionary Route">"celebrated march"</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELengel2005335_215-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELengel2005335-215">[204]</a></sup> Washington was in command of an army of 7,800 Frenchmen, 3,100 militia, and 8,000 Continentals. Not well experienced in siege warfare, Washington often referred to the judgment of General Rochambeau and used his advice about how to proceed; however, Rochambeau never challenged Washington's authority as the battle's commanding officer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010413_216-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010413-216">[205]</a></sup>
</p><p>By late September, Patriot-French forces surrounded Yorktown, trapped the British army, and prevented British reinforcements from Clinton in the North, while the French navy emerged victorious at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_the_Chesapeake" title="Battle of the Chesapeake">Battle of the Chesapeake</a>. The final American offensive was begun with a shot fired by Washington.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERiley1948375–395_217-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERiley1948375–395-217">[206]</a></sup> The siege ended with a British surrender on October 19, 1781; over 7,000 British soldiers were made <a href="/wiki/Prisoner_of_war" title="Prisoner of war">prisoners of war</a>, in the last major land battle of the American Revolutionary War.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996198,_201Chernow2010372–373,_418Lengel2005337_218-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996198,_201Chernow2010372–373,_418Lengel2005337-218">[207]</a></sup> Washington negotiated the terms of surrender for two days, and the official signing ceremony took place on October 19; Cornwallis claimed illness and was absent, sending General <a href="/wiki/Charles_O%27Hara" title="Charles O'Hara">Charles O'Hara</a> as his proxy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMann200838LancasterPlumb1985254Chernow2010419_219-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMann200838LancasterPlumb1985254Chernow2010419-219">[208]</a></sup> As a gesture of goodwill, Washington held a dinner for the American, French, and British generals, all of whom fraternized on friendly terms and identified with one another as members of the same professional military <a href="/wiki/Caste" title="Caste">caste</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010419_220-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010419-220">[209]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Asgill_Affair">Asgill Affair</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Asgill_Affair" title="Asgill Affair">Asgill Affair</a></div>
<p>After the surrender at Yorktown, a situation developed that threatened relations between the newly independent America and Britain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHenriques2020chpt._4_221-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHenriques2020chpt._4-221">[210]</a></sup> Following a series of retributive executions between <a href="/wiki/Patriot_(American_Revolution)" title="Patriot (American Revolution)">Patriots</a> and <a href="/wiki/Loyalists_fighting_in_the_American_Revolution" title="Loyalists fighting in the American Revolution">Loyalists</a>, Washington, on May 18, 1782, wrote in a letter to General <a href="/wiki/Moses_Hazen" title="Moses Hazen">Moses Hazen</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vernon_encyc_asgill_affair_222-0"><a href="#cite_note-vernon_encyc_asgill_affair-222">[211]</a></sup> that a British captain would be executed in retaliation for the execution of <a href="/wiki/Joshua_Huddy" title="Joshua Huddy">Joshua Huddy</a>, a popular Patriot leader, who was <a href="/wiki/Hanging" title="Hanging">hanged</a> at the direction of the Loyalist <a href="/wiki/Richard_Lippincott_(Loyalist)" title="Richard Lippincott (Loyalist)">Richard Lippincott</a>. Washington wanted Lippincott himself to be executed but was rebuffed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlexner1967479_223-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlexner1967479-223">[212]</a></sup> Subsequently, <a href="/wiki/Sir_Charles_Asgill,_2nd_Baronet" title="Sir Charles Asgill, 2nd Baronet">Charles Asgill</a> was chosen instead, by a drawing of lots from a hat. This was a violation of the 14th article of the Yorktown Articles of Capitulation, which protected prisoners of war from acts of retaliation.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vernon_encyc_asgill_affair_222-1"><a href="#cite_note-vernon_encyc_asgill_affair-222">[211]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-224"><a href="#cite_note-224">[213]</a></sup> Later, Washington's feelings on matters changed and in a letter of November 13, 1782, to Asgill, he acknowledged Asgill's letter and situation, expressing his desire not to see any harm come to him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-225"><a href="#cite_note-225">[214]</a></sup> After much consideration between the <a href="/wiki/Continental_Congress" title="Continental Congress">Continental Congress</a>, <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a>, Washington, and appeals from the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Louis_XVI_of_France" title="Louis XVI of France">French Crown</a>, Asgill was finally released,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFreeman1952414–415Randall1997394–395Chernow2010426–427_226-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFreeman1952414–415Randall1997394–395Chernow2010426–427-226">[215]</a></sup> where Washington issued Asgill a pass that allowed his passage to New York.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010427_227-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010427-227">[216]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-vernon_encyc_asgill_affair_222-2"><a href="#cite_note-vernon_encyc_asgill_affair-222">[211]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Demobilization_and_resignation">Demobilization and resignation</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:General_George_Washington_Resigning_his_Commission.jpg"><img alt="Painting by John Trumbull, depicting General Washington, standing in Maryland State House hall, surrounded by statesmen and others, resigning his commission" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1962" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="144" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/General_George_Washington_Resigning_his_Commission.jpg/220px-General_George_Washington_Resigning_his_Commission.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/General_George_Washington_Resigning_his_Commission.jpg/330px-General_George_Washington_Resigning_his_Commission.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/General_George_Washington_Resigning_his_Commission.jpg/440px-General_George_Washington_Resigning_his_Commission.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:General_George_Washington_Resigning_his_Commission.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/General_George_Washington_Resigning_His_Commission" title="General George Washington Resigning His Commission">General George Washington Resigning His Commission</a></i>, by <a href="/wiki/John_Trumbull" title="John Trumbull">John Trumbull</a>, 1824</div></div></div>
<p>When peace negotiations began in April 1782, both the British and French began gradually evacuating their forces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016313–315_228-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016313–315-228">[217]</a></sup> The American treasury was empty, unpaid, and mutinous soldiers forced the adjournment of Congress, and Washington dispelled unrest by suppressing the <a href="/wiki/Newburgh_Conspiracy" title="Newburgh Conspiracy">Newburgh Conspiracy</a> in March 1783; Congress promised officers a five-year bonus.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKohn1970187–220_229-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKohn1970187–220-229">[218]</a></sup> Washington submitted an account of $450,000 in expenses which he had advanced to the army. The account was settled, though it was allegedly vague about large sums and included expenses his wife had incurred through visits to his headquarters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996209_230-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996209-230">[219]</a></sup>
</p><p>The following month, a Congressional committee led by <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a> began adapting the army for peacetime. In August 1783, Washington gave the Army's perspective to the committee in his <i>Sentiments on a Peace Establishment</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWashington1783_231-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWashington1783-231">[220]</a></sup> He advised Congress to keep a standing army, create a "national militia" of separate state units, and establish a navy and a national military academy.<sup class="noprint Inline-Template Template-Fact" style="white-space:nowrap;">[<i><a href="/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed" title="Wikipedia:Citation needed"><span title="This claim needs references to reliable sources. (September 2022)">citation needed</span></a></i>]</sup>
</p><p>The <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Paris_(1783)" title="Treaty of Paris (1783)">Treaty of Paris</a> was signed on September 3, 1783, and Great Britain officially recognized the independence of the United States. Washington then disbanded his army, giving a farewell address to his soldiers on November 2.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWashington1799343_232-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWashington1799343-232">[221]</a></sup> During this time, Washington oversaw the <a href="/wiki/Evacuation_Day_(New_York)" title="Evacuation Day (New York)">evacuation of British forces in New York</a> and was greeted by parades and celebrations. There he announced that Colonel Henry Knox had been promoted commander-in-chief.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010446,_448–449,_451Puls2008184–186_233-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010446,_448–449,_451Puls2008184–186-233">[222]</a></sup> Washington and Governor <a href="/wiki/George_Clinton_(vice_president)" title="George Clinton (vice president)">George Clinton</a> took formal possession of the city on November 25.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall1997405_234-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall1997405-234">[223]</a></sup>
</p><p>In early December 1783, Washington bade farewell to his officers at <a href="/wiki/Fraunces_Tavern" title="Fraunces Tavern">Fraunces Tavern</a> and <a href="/wiki/George_Washington%27s_resignation_as_commander-in-chief" title="George Washington's resignation as commander-in-chief">resigned as commander-in-chief</a> soon thereafter, refuting Loyalist predictions that he would not relinquish his military command.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016319_235-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016319-235">[224]</a></sup> In a final appearance in uniform, he gave a statement to the Congress: "I consider it an indispensable duty to close this last solemn act of my official life, by commending the interests of our dearest country to the protection of Almighty God, and those who have the superintendence of them, to his holy keeping."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996210Chernow2010451–452,_455_236-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996210Chernow2010451–452,_455-236">[225]</a></sup> Washington's resignation was acclaimed at home and abroad and showed a skeptical world that the new republic would not degenerate into chaos.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010454–455_237-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010454–455-237">[226]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-239"><a href="#cite_note-239">[l]</a></sup>
</p><p>The same month, Washington was appointed president-general of the <a href="/wiki/Society_of_the_Cincinnati" title="Society of the Cincinnati">Society of the Cincinnati</a>, a newly established hereditary fraternity of Revolutionary War officers. He served in this capacity for the remainder of his life.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010444_240-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010444-240">[228]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-242"><a href="#cite_note-242">[m]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Early_republic_.281783.E2.80.931789.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Early_republic_(1783–1789)">Early republic (1783–1789)</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Confederation_Period" title="Confederation Period">Confederation Period</a> and <a href="/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation" title="Articles of Confederation">Articles of Confederation</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Return_to_Mount_Vernon">Return to Mount Vernon</span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1062260506">.mw-parser-output .quotebox{background-color:#F9F9F9;border:1px solid #aaa;box-sizing:border-box;padding:10px;font-size:88%;max-width:100%}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft{margin:.5em 1.4em .8em 0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright{margin:.5em 0 .8em 1.4em}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.centered{overflow:hidden;position:relative;margin:.5em auto .8em auto}.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatleft span,.mw-parser-output .quotebox.floatright span{font-style:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox>blockquote{margin:0;padding:0;border-left:0;font-family:inherit;font-size:inherit}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-title{background-color:#F9F9F9;text-align:center;font-size:110%;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote>:first-child{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote:last-child>:last-child{margin-bottom:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:before{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" “ ";vertical-align:-45%;line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox-quote.quoted:after{font-family:"Times New Roman",serif;font-weight:bold;font-size:large;color:gray;content:" ” ";line-height:0}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .left-aligned{text-align:left}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .right-aligned{text-align:right}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .center-aligned{text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .quotebox .quote-title,.mw-parser-output .quotebox .quotebox-quote{display:block}.mw-parser-output .quotebox cite{display:block;font-style:normal}@media screen and (max-width:640px){.mw-parser-output .quotebox{width:100%!important;margin:0 0 .8em!important;float:none!important}}</style><div class="quotebox pullquote floatright" style="width:20%; ;">
<blockquote class="quotebox-quote left-aligned" style="">
<p>I am not only retired from all public employments but I am retiring within myself, and shall be able to view the solitary walk and tread the paths of private life with heartfelt satisfaction ... I will move gently down the stream of life, until I sleep with my fathers.
</p>
</blockquote>
<p><cite class="right-aligned" style="">George Washington<br/>Letter to Lafayette<br/>February 1, 1784<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall1997410Flexner1974182–183DalzellDalzell1998112_243-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall1997410Flexner1974182–183DalzellDalzell1998112-243">[230]</a></sup></cite>
</p>
</div>
<p>Washington was longing to return home after spending just ten days at Mount Vernon out of <style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1020198016">.mw-parser-output .frac{white-space:nowrap}.mw-parser-output .frac .num,.mw-parser-output .frac .den{font-size:80%;line-height:0;vertical-align:super}.mw-parser-output .frac .den{vertical-align:sub}.mw-parser-output .sr-only{border:0;clip:rect(0,0,0,0);height:1px;margin:-1px;overflow:hidden;padding:0;position:absolute;width:1px}</style><span class="frac" role="math">8<span class="sr-only">+</span><span class="num">1</span>⁄<span class="den">2</span></span> years of war. He arrived on Christmas Eve, delighted to be "free of the bustle of a camp and the busy scenes of public life".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009246_244-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009246-244">[231]</a></sup> He was a celebrity and was <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/feted" title="wiktionary:feted">fêted</a> during a visit to his mother at Fredericksburg in February 1784, and he received a constant stream of visitors wishing to pay their respects to him at Mount Vernon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010462Ferling2009255–256_245-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010462Ferling2009255–256-245">[232]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington reactivated his interests in the <a href="/wiki/Great_Dismal_Swamp" title="Great Dismal Swamp">Great Dismal Swamp</a> and <a href="/wiki/Potomac_Company" title="Potomac Company">Potomac canal</a> projects begun before the war, though neither paid him any dividends, and he undertook a 34-day, 680-mile (1090 km) trip to check on his land holdings in the Ohio Country.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009247–255_246-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009247–255-246">[233]</a></sup> He oversaw the completion of the remodeling work at Mount Vernon, which transformed his residence into the mansion that survives to this day—although his financial situation was not strong. Creditors paid him in depreciated wartime currency, and he owed significant amounts in taxes and wages. Mount Vernon had made no profit during his absence, and he saw persistently poor crop yields due to pestilence and poor weather. His estate recorded its eleventh year running at a deficit in 1787, and there was little prospect of improvement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009246–247Chernow2010552–553Ellis2004167_247-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009246–247Chernow2010552–553Ellis2004167-247">[234]</a></sup> Washington undertook a new landscaping plan and succeeded in cultivating a range of fast-growing trees and shrubs that were native to North America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWulf201252Subak201843–44_248-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWulf201252Subak201843–44-248">[235]</a></sup> He also began <a href="/wiki/Animal_husbandry" title="Animal husbandry">breeding</a> <a href="/wiki/Mule" title="Mule">mules</a> after having been gifted a Spanish <a href="/wiki/Donkey" title="Donkey">jack</a> by <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/King_Charles_III_of_Spain" title="King Charles III of Spain">King Charles III of Spain</a> in 1784. There were few mules in the United States at that time, and he believed that properly bred mules would revolutionize <a href="/wiki/Agriculture" title="Agriculture">agriculture</a> and <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Transportation" title="Transportation">transportation</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-249"><a href="#cite_note-249">[236]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Constitutional_Convention_of_1787">Constitutional Convention of 1787</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Convention_(United_States)" title="Constitutional Convention (United States)">Constitutional Convention (United States)</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Shays%27_Rebellion.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="2215" data-file-width="2290" decoding="async" height="213" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Shays%27_Rebellion.jpg/220px-Shays%27_Rebellion.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Shays%27_Rebellion.jpg/330px-Shays%27_Rebellion.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e4/Shays%27_Rebellion.jpg/440px-Shays%27_Rebellion.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Shays%27_Rebellion.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Shays%27_Rebellion" title="Shays' Rebellion">Shays' Rebellion</a> confirmed for Washington the need to overhaul the Articles of Confederation.</div></div></div>
<p>Before returning to private life in June 1783, Washington called for a strong union. Though he was concerned that he might be criticized for meddling in civil matters, he sent a circular letter to all the states, maintaining that the <a href="/wiki/Articles_of_Confederation" title="Articles of Confederation">Articles of Confederation</a> was no more than "a rope of sand" linking the states. He believed the nation was on the verge of "anarchy and confusion", was vulnerable to foreign intervention, and that a national constitution would unify the states under a strong central government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996221Chernow2010518Ferling2009266_250-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996221Chernow2010518Ferling2009266-250">[237]</a></sup> When <a href="/wiki/Shays%27_Rebellion" title="Shays' Rebellion">Shays' Rebellion</a> erupted in Massachusetts on August 29, 1786, over taxation, Washington was further convinced that a national constitution was needed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010517–519_251-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010517–519-251">[238]</a></sup> Some nationalists feared that the new republic had descended into lawlessness, and they met together on September 11, 1786, at <a href="/wiki/Annapolis_Convention_(1786)" title="Annapolis Convention (1786)">Annapolis</a> to ask Congress to revise the Articles of Confederation. One of their biggest efforts, however, was getting Washington to attend.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016373–374Ferling2009266_252-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016373–374Ferling2009266-252">[239]</a></sup> Congress agreed to a Constitutional Convention to be held in Philadelphia in Spring 1787, and each state was to send delegates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010523Taylor2016373–374_253-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010523Taylor2016373–374-253">[240]</a></sup>
</p><p>On December 4, 1786, Washington was chosen to lead the Virginia delegation, but he declined on December 21. He had concerns about the legality of the convention and consulted <a href="/wiki/James_Madison" title="James Madison">James Madison</a>, <a href="/wiki/Henry_Knox" title="Henry Knox">Henry Knox</a>, and others. They persuaded him to attend it, however, as his presence might induce reluctant states to send delegates and smooth the way for the ratification process.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010220–221Ferling2009266_254-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010220–221Ferling2009266-254">[241]</a></sup> On March 28, Washington told Governor <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Randolph" title="Edmund Randolph">Edmund Randolph</a> that he would attend the convention but made it clear that he was urged to attend.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009266Chernow2010218,_220–224,_520–526_255-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009266Chernow2010218,_220–224,_520–526-255">[242]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Scene_at_the_Signing_of_the_Constitution_of_the_United_States.jpg"><img alt="Painting by Howard Chandler Christy, depicting the signing of the Constitution of the United States, with Washington as the presiding officer standing at right" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1933" data-file-width="3000" decoding="async" height="180" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Scene_at_the_Signing_of_the_Constitution_of_the_United_States.jpg/280px-Scene_at_the_Signing_of_the_Constitution_of_the_United_States.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Scene_at_the_Signing_of_the_Constitution_of_the_United_States.jpg/420px-Scene_at_the_Signing_of_the_Constitution_of_the_United_States.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/Scene_at_the_Signing_of_the_Constitution_of_the_United_States.jpg/560px-Scene_at_the_Signing_of_the_Constitution_of_the_United_States.jpg 2x" width="280"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Scene_at_the_Signing_of_the_Constitution_of_the_United_States.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/Scene_at_the_Signing_of_the_Constitution_of_the_United_States" title="Scene at the Signing of the Constitution of the United States">Scene at the Signing of the Constitution of the United States</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Howard_Chandler_Christy" title="Howard Chandler Christy">Howard Chandler Christy</a>, 1940. Washington is the presiding officer standing at right.</div></div></div>
<p>Washington arrived in Philadelphia on May 9, 1787, though a quorum was not attained until Friday, May 25. Benjamin Franklin nominated Washington to preside over the convention, and he was unanimously elected to serve as president general.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010520–521,_523,_526,_529Unger201333_256-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010520–521,_523,_526,_529Unger201333-256">[243]</a></sup> The convention's state-mandated purpose was to revise the Articles of Confederation with "all such alterations and further provisions" required to improve them, and the new government would be established when the resulting document was "duly confirmed by the several states".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElliot182725–36_257-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElliot182725–36-257">[244]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Randolph" title="Edmund Randolph">Governor Edmund Randolph of Virginia</a> introduced Madison's <a href="/wiki/Virginia_Plan" title="Virginia Plan">Virginia Plan</a> on May 27, the third day of the convention. It called for an entirely new constitution and a sovereign national government, which Washington highly recommended.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2010359–360_258-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2010359–360-258">[245]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington wrote <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a> on July 10: "I almost despair of seeing a favorable issue to the proceedings of our convention and do therefore repent having had any agency in the business."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996226–227_259-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996226–227-259">[246]</a></sup> Nevertheless, he lent his prestige to the goodwill and work of the other delegates. He unsuccessfully lobbied many to support ratification of the <a href="/wiki/Constitution_of_the_United_States" title="Constitution of the United States">Constitution</a>, such as anti-federalist <a href="/wiki/Patrick_Henry" title="Patrick Henry">Patrick Henry</a>; Washington told him "the adoption of it under the present circumstances of the Union is in my opinion desirable" and declared the alternative would be anarchy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996229_260-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996229-260">[247]</a></sup> Washington and Madison then spent four days at Mount Vernon evaluating the new government's transition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010545–546_261-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010545–546-261">[248]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Chancellor_of_William_.26_Mary"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Chancellor_of_William_&amp;_Mary">Chancellor of William &amp; Mary</span></h3>
<p>In 1788, the Board of Visitors of the <a href="/wiki/College_of_William_%26_Mary" title="College of William &amp; Mary">College of William &amp; Mary</a> decided to re-establish the position of Chancellor, and elected Washington to the office on January 18.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chancellor_262-0"><a href="#cite_note-chancellor-262">[249]</a></sup> The College Rector Samuel Griffin wrote to Washington inviting him to the post, and in a letter dated April 30, 1788, Washington accepted the position of the 14th <a href="/wiki/Chancellor_of_the_College_of_William_%26_Mary" title="Chancellor of the College of William &amp; Mary">Chancellor of the College of William &amp; Mary</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chancellor_262-1"><a href="#cite_note-chancellor-262">[249]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWashington1788a_263-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWashington1788a-263">[250]</a></sup> He continued to serve in the post through his presidency until his death on December 14, 1799.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-chancellor_262-2"><a href="#cite_note-chancellor-262">[249]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="First_presidential_election">First presidential election</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/1788%E2%80%9389_United_States_presidential_election" title="1788–89 United States presidential election">1788–89 United States presidential election</a></div>
<p>The delegates to the Convention anticipated a Washington presidency and left it to him to define the office once elected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAlden1996226–227_259-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAlden1996226–227-259">[246]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-265"><a href="#cite_note-265">[n]</a></sup> The state electors under the Constitution voted for the president on February 4, 1789, and Washington suspected that most republicans had not voted for him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010559–560Ferling2009361_266-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010559–560Ferling2009361-266">[252]</a></sup> The mandated March<span class="nowrap"> </span>4 date passed without a Congressional quorum to count the votes, but a quorum was reached on April 5. The votes were tallied the next day,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010551_267-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010551-267">[253]</a></sup> and Congressional Secretary <a href="/wiki/Charles_Thomson" title="Charles Thomson">Charles Thomson</a> was sent to Mount Vernon to tell Washington he had been elected president. Washington won the majority of every state's electoral votes; John Adams received the next highest number of votes and therefore became vice president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009274_268-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009274-268">[254]</a></sup> Washington had "anxious and painful sensations" about leaving the "domestic felicity" of Mount Vernon, but departed for <a href="/wiki/New_York_City" title="New York City">New York City</a> on April 16 to be inaugurated.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009274–275Chernow2010559–561Washington1789_269-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009274–275Chernow2010559–561Washington1789-269">[255]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Presidency_.281789.E2.80.931797.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Presidency_(1789–1797)">Presidency (1789–1797)</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_George_Washington" title="Presidency of George Washington">Presidency of George Washington</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:202px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_Washington_1795.jpg"><img alt="Painting by Gilbert Stuart (1795), formal portrait of President George Washington" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3710" data-file-width="3105" decoding="async" height="239" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/George_Washington_1795.jpg/200px-George_Washington_1795.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/George_Washington_1795.jpg/300px-George_Washington_1795.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/dd/George_Washington_1795.jpg/400px-George_Washington_1795.jpg 2x" width="200"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_Washington_1795.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>President George Washington</i>, Gilbert Stuart (1795)</div></div></div>
<p>Washington was <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_George_Washington" title="Presidency of George Washington">inaugurated</a> on April 30, 1789, taking the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Oath_of_office_of_the_President_of_the_United_States" title="Oath of office of the President of the United States">oath of office</a> at <a href="/wiki/Federal_Hall" title="Federal Hall">Federal Hall</a> in New York City.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke20024Chernow2010550–551Fitzpatrick1936522_270-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke20024Chernow2010550–551Fitzpatrick1936522-270">[256]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-272"><a href="#cite_note-272">[o]</a></sup> His coach was led by militia and a marching band and followed by statesmen and foreign dignitaries in an inaugural parade, with a crowd of 10,000.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010566–567Randall1997448_273-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010566–567Randall1997448-273">[258]</a></sup> Chancellor <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Robert_R._Livingston_(chancellor)" title="Robert R. Livingston (chancellor)">Robert R.
