Livingston</a> administered the oath, using a <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_Inaugural_Bible" title="George Washington Inaugural Bible">Bible provided by the Masons</a>, after which the militia fired a 13-gun salute.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke20024Chernow2010568_274-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke20024Chernow2010568-274">[259]</a></sup> Washington read a speech in the Senate Chamber, asking "that Almighty Being who rules over the universe, who presides in the councils of nations—and whose providential aids can supply every human defect, consecrate the liberties and happiness of the people of the United States".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall1997448Alden1996236_275-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall1997448Alden1996236-275">[260]</a></sup> Though he wished to serve without a salary, Congress insisted adamantly that he accept it, later providing Washington $25,000 per year to defray costs of the presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010552Fitzpatrick1936v._19,_p._522_276-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010552Fitzpatrick1936v._19,_p._522-276">[261]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington wrote to James Madison: "As the first of everything in our situation will serve to establish a precedent, it is devoutly wished on my part that these precedents be fixed on true principles."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnger201376_277-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnger201376-277">[262]</a></sup> To that end, he preferred the title "Mr. President" over more majestic names proposed by the Senate, including "His Excellency" and "His Highness the President".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBassett1906155_278-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBassett1906155-278">[263]</a></sup> His executive precedents included the inaugural address, messages to Congress, and the <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_States" title="Cabinet of the United States">cabinet form</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Federal_government_of_the_United_States" title="Federal government of the United States">executive branch</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnger2013236–237_279-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnger2013236–237-279">[264]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington had planned to resign after his first term, but the political strife in the nation convinced him he should remain in office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010674–675_280-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010674–675-280">[265]</a></sup> He was an able administrator and a judge of talent and character, and he regularly talked with department heads to get their advice.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllis2004197–198Unger2013236–237_281-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllis2004197–198Unger2013236–237-281">[266]</a></sup> He tolerated opposing views, despite fears that a democratic system would lead to political violence, and he conducted a smooth transition of power to his successor.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGenovese2009589Unger2013236–237_282-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGenovese2009589Unger2013236–237-282">[267]</a></sup> He remained non-partisan throughout his presidency and opposed the divisiveness of political parties, but he favored a strong central government, was sympathetic to a Federalist form of government, and leery of the Republican opposition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010696–698Randall1997478_283-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010696–698Randall1997478-283">[268]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington dealt with major problems. The old <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Confederation_Period" title="Confederation Period">Confederation</a> lacked the powers to handle its workload and had weak leadership, no executive, a small bureaucracy of clerks, a large debt, worthless paper money, and no power to establish taxes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke20025_284-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke20025-284">[269]</a></sup> He had the task of assembling an executive department and relied on <a href="/wiki/Tobias_Lear" title="Tobias Lear">Tobias Lear</a> for advice selecting its officers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010575_285-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010575-285">[270]</a></sup> Great Britain refused to relinquish its forts in the American West,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke20025_284-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke20025-284">[269]</a></sup> and <a href="/wiki/Barbary_pirates#18th–19th_centuries" title="Barbary pirates">Barbary pirates</a> preyed on American merchant ships in the Mediterranean before the United States even had a navy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010514_286-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010514-286">[271]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Cabinet_and_executive_departments">Cabinet and executive departments</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">See also: <a href="/wiki/Cabinet_of_the_United_States" title="Cabinet of the United States">Cabinet of the United States</a></div>
<table class="infobox" style="width:auto;text-align:left;line-height:1.2em;margin-left:1em; margin-right:0; float:right; clear:right;"><tbody><tr><th colspan="3" style="line-height:1.5em;font-size:110%;background:#DCDCDC;text-align:center">The Washington cabinet</th></tr><tr><th>Office</th><th>Name</th><th>Term</th></tr><tr><td colspan="3" style="background:#000"></td></tr><tr><td><a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">President</a></td><th style="font-weight:bold">George Washington</th><td>1789–1797</td></tr><tr><td colspan="3" style="background:#D1D1D1"></td></tr><tr><td><a href="/wiki/Vice_President_of_the_United_States" title="Vice President of the United States">Vice President</a></td><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/John_Adams" title="John Adams">John Adams</a></th><td>1789–1797</td></tr><tr><td colspan="3" style="background:#D1D1D1"></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="4"><a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_State" title="United States Secretary of State">Secretary of State</a></td><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/John_Jay" title="John Jay">John Jay</a> (acting)</th><td>1789–1790</td></tr><tr class="mw-empty-elt"></tr><tr><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson" title="Thomas Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a></th><td>1790–1793</td></tr><tr class="mw-empty-elt"></tr><tr><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/Edmund_Randolph" title="Edmund Randolph">Edmund Randolph</a></th><td>1794–1795</td></tr><tr class="mw-empty-elt"></tr><tr><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/Timothy_Pickering" title="Timothy Pickering">Timothy Pickering</a></th><td>1795–1797</td></tr><tr><td colspan="3" style="background:#D1D1D1"></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="2"><a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_the_Treasury" title="United States Secretary of the Treasury">Secretary of the Treasury</a></td><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a></th><td>1789–1795</td></tr><tr class="mw-empty-elt"></tr><tr><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/Oliver_Wolcott_Jr." title="Oliver Wolcott Jr.">Oliver Wolcott Jr.</a></th><td>1795–1797</td></tr><tr><td colspan="3" style="background:#D1D1D1"></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="3"><a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_War" title="United States Secretary of War">Secretary of War</a></td><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/Henry_Knox" title="Henry Knox">Henry Knox</a></th><td>1789–1794</td></tr><tr class="mw-empty-elt"></tr><tr><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/Timothy_Pickering" title="Timothy Pickering">Timothy Pickering</a></th><td>1795</td></tr><tr class="mw-empty-elt"></tr><tr><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/James_McHenry" title="James McHenry">James McHenry</a></th><td>1796–1797</td></tr><tr><td colspan="3" style="background:#D1D1D1"></td></tr><tr><td rowspan="3"><a href="/wiki/United_States_Attorney_General" title="United States Attorney General">Attorney General</a></td><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/Edmund_Randolph" title="Edmund Randolph">Edmund Randolph</a></th><td>1789–1794</td></tr><tr class="mw-empty-elt"></tr><tr><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/William_Bradford_(Attorney_General)" title="William Bradford (Attorney General)">William Bradford</a></th><td>1794–1795</td></tr><tr class="mw-empty-elt"></tr><tr><th style="font-weight:bold"><a href="/wiki/Charles_Lee_(Attorney_General)" title="Charles Lee (Attorney General)">Charles Lee</a></th><td>1795–1797</td></tr></tbody></table>
<p>Congress created executive departments in 1789, including the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_State" title="United States Department of State">State Department</a> in July, the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_War" title="United States Department of War">Department of War</a> in August, and the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Department_of_the_Treasury" title="United States Department of the Treasury">Treasury Department</a> in September. Washington appointed fellow Virginian <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Randolph" title="Edmund Randolph">Edmund Randolph</a> as Attorney General, <a href="/wiki/Samuel_Osgood" title="Samuel Osgood">Samuel Osgood</a> as Postmaster General, <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson" title="Thomas Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a> as Secretary of State, and <a href="/wiki/Henry_Knox" title="Henry Knox">Henry Knox</a> as <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_War" title="United States Secretary of War">Secretary of War</a>. Finally, he appointed <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a> as <a href="/wiki/United_States_Secretary_of_the_Treasury" title="United States Secretary of the Treasury">Secretary of the Treasury</a>. Washington's cabinet became a consulting and advisory body, not mandated by the Constitution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009281–282Cooke20024–5_287-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009281–282Cooke20024–5-287">[272]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington's cabinet members formed rival parties with sharply opposing views, most fiercely illustrated between Hamilton and Jefferson.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke20025Banning19745_288-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke20025Banning19745-288">[273]</a></sup> Washington restricted cabinet discussions to topics of his choosing, without participating in the debate. He occasionally requested cabinet opinions in writing and expected department heads to agreeably carry out his decisions.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke20025_284-2"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke20025-284">[269]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Domestic_issues">Domestic issues</span></h3>
<p>Washington was apolitical and opposed the formation of parties, suspecting that conflict would undermine republicanism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElkinsMcKitrick1995290_289-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElkinsMcKitrick1995290-289">[274]</a></sup> He exercised great restraint in using <a href="/wiki/List_of_United_States_presidential_vetoes" title="List of United States presidential vetoes">his veto power</a>, writing that "I give my Signature to many Bills with which my Judgment is at variance…."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-290"><a href="#cite_note-290">[275]</a></sup>
</p><p>His closest advisors formed two factions, portending the <a href="/wiki/First_Party_System" title="First Party System">First Party System</a>. Secretary of the Treasury <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a> formed the <a href="/wiki/Federalist_Party" title="Federalist Party">Federalist Party</a> to promote national credit and a financially powerful nation. Secretary of State <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson" title="Thomas Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a> opposed Hamilton's agenda and founded the <a href="/wiki/Democratic-Republican_Party" title="Democratic-Republican Party">Jeffersonian Republicans</a>. Washington favored Hamilton's agenda, however, and it ultimately went into effect—resulting in bitter controversy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke20027_291-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke20027-291">[276]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington proclaimed November 26 as a day of <a href="/wiki/Thanksgiving_(United_States)" title="Thanksgiving (United States)">Thanksgiving</a> to encourage national unity. "It is the duty of all nations to acknowledge the providence of Almighty God, to obey His will, to be grateful for His benefits, and humbly to implore His protection and favor." He spent that day fasting and visiting debtors in prison to provide them with food and beer.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010585,_609Henriques200665Novak2007144–146_292-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010585,_609Henriques200665Novak2007144–146-292">[277]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="African_Americans">African Americans</span></h4>
<p>In response to two antislavery petitions that were presented to Congress in 1790, slaveholders in Georgia and South Carolina objected and threatened to "blow the trumpet of civil war". Washington and Congress responded with a series of racist measures: <a href="/wiki/Naturalization_Act_of_1790" title="Naturalization Act of 1790">naturalized citizenship was denied</a> to black immigrants; <a href="/wiki/Militia_Acts_of_1792" title="Militia Acts of 1792">blacks were barred from serving</a> in state militias; the <a href="/wiki/Southwest_Territory" title="Southwest Territory">Southwest Territory</a> that would soon become the state of Tennessee was permitted to maintain slavery; and two more slave states were admitted (Kentucky in 1792, and Tennessee in 1796). On February 12, 1793, Washington signed into law the <a href="/wiki/Fugitive_Slave_Act_of_1793" title="Fugitive Slave Act of 1793">Fugitive Slave Act</a>, which overrode state laws and courts, allowing agents to cross state lines to capture and return escaped slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010758Taylor2016399–400_293-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010758Taylor2016399–400-293">[278]</a></sup> Many free blacks in the north decried the law believing it would allow bounty hunting and the kidnappings of blacks.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016399–400_294-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016399–400-294">[279]</a></sup> The Fugitive Slave Act gave effect to the Constitution's <a href="/wiki/Fugitive_Slave_Clause" title="Fugitive Slave Clause">Fugitive Slave Clause</a>, and the Act was passed overwhelmingly in Congress (e.g. the vote was 48 to 7 in the House).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-295"><a href="#cite_note-295">[280]</a></sup>
</p><p>On the anti-slavery side of the ledger, in 1789 Washington signed a reenactment of the <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Ordinance" title="Northwest Ordinance">Northwest Ordinance</a> which had freed all slaves brought after 1787 into a vast expanse of federal territory north of the <a href="/wiki/Ohio_River" title="Ohio River">Ohio River</a>, except for slaves escaping from slave states.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-296"><a href="#cite_note-296">[281]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-297"><a href="#cite_note-297">[282]</a></sup> That 1787 law lapsed when the new U.S. Constitution was ratified in 1789.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-298"><a href="#cite_note-298">[283]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Slave_Trade_Act_of_1794" title="Slave Trade Act of 1794">Slave Trade Act of 1794</a>, which sharply limited American involvement in the <a href="/wiki/Atlantic_slave_trade" title="Atlantic slave trade">Atlantic slave trade</a>, was also signed by Washington. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBassett1906187–189_299-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBassett1906187–189-299">[284]</a></sup> And, Congress acted on February 18, 1791, to admit the free state of Vermont into the Union as the 14th state as of March 4, 1791.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-300"><a href="#cite_note-300">[285]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="National_Bank">National Bank</span></h4>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Philadelphia_Presidents_house.jpg"><img alt="Engraving of President Washington's House in Philadelphia, his residence from 1790 to 1797" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="816" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="150" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Philadelphia_Presidents_house.jpg/220px-Philadelphia_Presidents_house.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Philadelphia_Presidents_house.jpg/330px-Philadelphia_Presidents_house.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/Philadelphia_Presidents_house.jpg/440px-Philadelphia_Presidents_house.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Philadelphia_Presidents_house.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The President's House in Philadelphia was Washington's residence from 1790 to 1797</div></div></div>
<p>Washington's first term was largely devoted to economic concerns, in which Hamilton had devised various plans to address matters.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2005345_301-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2005345-301">[286]</a></sup> The establishment of public credit became a primary challenge for the federal government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBanning19745–7_302-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBanning19745–7-302">[287]</a></sup> Hamilton submitted a report to a deadlocked Congress, and he, Madison, and Jefferson reached the <a href="/wiki/Compromise_of_1790" title="Compromise of 1790">Compromise of 1790</a> in which Jefferson agreed to Hamilton's debt proposals in exchange for moving the nation's capital temporarily to Philadelphia and then south near <a href="/wiki/Georgetown_(Washington,_D.C.)" title="Georgetown (Washington, D.C.)">Georgetown</a> on the <a href="/wiki/Potomac_River" title="Potomac River">Potomac River</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke20027_291-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke20027-291">[276]</a></sup> The terms were legislated in the <a href="/wiki/Funding_Act_of_1790" title="Funding Act of 1790">Funding Act of 1790</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Residence_Act" title="Residence Act">Residence Act</a>, both of which Washington signed into law. Congress authorized the assumption and payment of the nation's debts, with funding provided by customs duties and excise taxes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke20027–8_303-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke20027–8-303">[288]</a></sup>
</p><p>Hamilton created controversy among Cabinet members by advocating establishing the <a href="/wiki/First_Bank_of_the_United_States" title="First Bank of the United States">First Bank of the United States</a>. Madison and Jefferson objected, but the bank easily passed Congress. Jefferson and <a href="/wiki/Edmund_Randolph" title="Edmund Randolph">Randolph</a> insisted that the new bank was beyond the authority granted by the constitution, as Hamilton believed. Washington sided with Hamilton and signed the legislation on February 25, and the rift became openly hostile between Hamilton and Jefferson.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke20028_304-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke20028-304">[289]</a></sup>
</p><p>The nation's <a href="/wiki/Panic_of_1792" title="Panic of 1792">first financial crisis</a> occurred in March 1792. Hamilton's Federalists exploited large loans to gain control of U.S. debt securities, causing a run on the national bank;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESobel196827_305-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESobel196827-305">[290]</a></sup> the markets returned to normal by mid-April.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBanning19749Sobel196830_306-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBanning19749Sobel196830-306">[291]</a></sup> Jefferson believed Hamilton was part of the scheme, despite Hamilton's efforts to ameliorate, and Washington again found himself in the middle of a feud.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010673–674_307-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010673–674-307">[292]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span id="Jefferson.E2.80.93Hamilton_feud"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Jefferson–Hamilton_feud">Jefferson–Hamilton feud</span></h4>

class="thumbimage"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Alexander_Hamilton_portrait_by_John_Trumbull_1806,_detail.jpg"><img alt="Formal portrait of Alexander Hamilton, part of a dual image of Jefferson and Hamilton" data-file-height="1959" data-file-width="1650" decoding="async" height="192" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Alexander_Hamilton_portrait_by_John_Trumbull_1806%2C_detail.jpg/162px-Alexander_Hamilton_portrait_by_John_Trumbull_1806%2C_detail.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Alexander_Hamilton_portrait_by_John_Trumbull_1806%2C_detail.jpg/243px-Alexander_Hamilton_portrait_by_John_Trumbull_1806%2C_detail.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/Alexander_Hamilton_portrait_by_John_Trumbull_1806%2C_detail.jpg/324px-Alexander_Hamilton_portrait_by_John_Trumbull_1806%2C_detail.jpg 2x" width="162"/></a></div><div class="thumbcaption text-align-center"><a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>Jefferson and Hamilton adopted diametrically opposed political principles. Hamilton believed in a strong national government requiring a national bank and foreign loans to function, while Jefferson believed the states and the farm element should primarily direct the government; he also resented the idea of banks and foreign loans. To Washington's dismay, the two men persistently entered into disputes and infighting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010515,_627–630,_648–650Randall1997452,_463,_468–471_308-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010515,_627–630,_648–650Randall1997452,_463,_468–471-308">[293]</a></sup> Hamilton demanded that Jefferson resign if he could not support Washington, and Jefferson told Washington that Hamilton's fiscal system would lead to the overthrow of the Republic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBanning19748Cooke20029_309-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBanning19748Cooke20029-309">[294]</a></sup> Washington urged them to call a truce for the nation's sake, but they ignored him.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke20029Fitzpatrick1936v._19,_p._523_310-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke20029Fitzpatrick1936v._19,_p._523-310">[295]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington reversed his decision to retire after his first term to minimize party strife, but the feud continued after his re-election.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBanning19748Cooke20029_309-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBanning19748Cooke20029-309">[294]</a></sup> Jefferson's political actions, his support of Freneau's <i>National Gazette</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElkinsMcKitrick1995240,_285,_290,_361_311-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElkinsMcKitrick1995240,_285,_290,_361-311">[296]</a></sup> and his attempt to undermine Hamilton nearly led Washington to dismiss him from the cabinet; Jefferson ultimately resigned his position in December 1793, and Washington forsook him from that time on.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke20029Chernow2005427_312-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke20029Chernow2005427-312">[297]</a></sup>
</p><p>The feud led to the well-defined Federalist and Republican parties, and party affiliation became necessary for election to Congress by 1794.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2013222,_283–284,_301–302_313-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2013222,_283–284,_301–302-313">[298]</a></sup> Washington remained aloof from congressional attacks on Hamilton, but he did not publicly protect him, either. The <a href="/wiki/Hamilton%E2%80%93Reynolds_affair" title="Hamilton–Reynolds affair">Hamilton–Reynolds sex scandal</a> opened Hamilton to disgrace, but Washington continued to hold him in "very high esteem" as the dominant force in establishing federal law and government.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2013301–302_314-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2013301–302-314">[299]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Whiskey_Rebellion">Whiskey Rebellion</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Whiskey_Rebellion" title="Whiskey Rebellion">Whiskey Rebellion</a></div>
<p>In March 1791, at Hamilton's urging, with support from Madison, Congress imposed an excise tax on distilled spirits to help curtail the national debt, which took effect in July.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2005342–343_315-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2005342–343-315">[300]</a></sup> Grain farmers strongly protested in Pennsylvania's frontier districts; they argued that they were unrepresented and were shouldering too much of the debt, comparing their situation to excessive British taxation before the Revolutionary War. On August 2, Washington assembled his cabinet to discuss how to deal with the situation. Unlike Washington, who had reservations about using force, Hamilton had long waited for such a situation and was eager to suppress the rebellion by using federal authority and force.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKohn1972567–568,_570_316-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKohn1972567–568,_570-316">[301]</a></sup> Not wanting to involve the federal government if possible, Washington called on Pennsylvania state officials to take the initiative, but they declined to take military action. On August 7, Washington issued his first proclamation for calling up state militias. After appealing for peace, he reminded the protestors that, unlike the rule of the British crown, the Federal law was issued by state-elected representatives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010719–721Puls2008219_317-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010719–721Puls2008219-317">[302]</a></sup>
</p><p>Threats and violence against tax collectors, however, escalated into defiance against federal authority in 1794 and gave rise to the <a href="/wiki/Whiskey_Rebellion" title="Whiskey Rebellion">Whiskey Rebellion</a>. Washington issued a final proclamation on September 25, threatening the use of military force to no avail.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010719–721Puls2008219_317-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010719–721Puls2008219-317">[302]</a></sup> The federal army was not up to the task, so Washington invoked the <a href="/wiki/Militia_Acts_of_1792" title="Militia Acts of 1792">Militia Act of 1792</a> to summon state militias.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECoakley199643–49_318-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECoakley199643–49-318">[303]</a></sup> Governors sent troops, initially commanded by Washington, who gave the command to <a href="/wiki/Henry_Lee_III" title="Henry Lee III">Light-Horse Harry Lee</a> to lead them into the rebellious districts. They took 150 prisoners, and the remaining rebels dispersed without further fighting. Two of the prisoners were condemned to death, but Washington exercised his Constitutional authority for the first time and pardoned them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010721,_726Kohn1972567–584_319-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010721,_726Kohn1972567–584-319">[304]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington's forceful action demonstrated that the new government could protect itself and its tax collectors. This represented the first use of federal military force against the states and citizens,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKohn1972567–584_320-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKohn1972567–584-320">[305]</a></sup> and remains the only time an incumbent president has commanded troops in the field. Washington justified his action against "certain self-created societies", which he regarded as "subversive organizations" that threatened the national union. He did not dispute their right to protest, but he insisted that their dissent must not violate federal law. Congress agreed and extended their congratulations to him; only Madison and Jefferson expressed indifference.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllis2004225–226_321-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllis2004225–226-321">[306]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Foreign_affairs">Foreign affairs</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Gilbert_Stuart,_John_Jay,_1794,_NGA_75023.jpg"><img alt="Gilbert Stuart portrait of Chief Justice John Jay in robes, seated and holding a law book" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="4000" data-file-width="3091" decoding="async" height="220" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Gilbert_Stuart%2C_John_Jay%2C_1794%2C_NGA_75023.jpg/170px-Gilbert_Stuart%2C_John_Jay%2C_1794%2C_NGA_75023.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Gilbert_Stuart%2C_John_Jay%2C_1794%2C_NGA_75023.jpg/255px-Gilbert_Stuart%2C_John_Jay%2C_1794%2C_NGA_75023.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Gilbert_Stuart%2C_John_Jay%2C_1794%2C_NGA_75023.jpg/340px-Gilbert_Stuart%2C_John_Jay%2C_1794%2C_NGA_75023.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Gilbert_Stuart,_John_Jay,_1794,_NGA_75023.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/John_Jay" title="John Jay">John Jay</a>, negotiator of the <a href="/wiki/Jay_Treaty" title="Jay Treaty">Jay Treaty</a></div></div></div>
<p>In April 1792, the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolutionary_Wars" title="French Revolutionary Wars">French Revolutionary Wars</a> began between Great Britain and France, and Washington declared America's neutrality. The revolutionary government of France sent diplomat <a href="/wiki/Edmond-Charles_Gen%C3%AAt" title="Edmond-Charles Genêt">Citizen Genêt</a> to America, and he was welcomed with great enthusiasm. He created a network of new <a href="/wiki/Democratic-Republican_Societies" title="Democratic-Republican Societies">Democratic-Republican Societies</a> promoting France's interests, but Washington denounced them and demanded that the French recall Genêt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElkinsMcKitrick1995335–354_322-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElkinsMcKitrick1995335–354-322">[307]</a></sup> The National Assembly of France granted Washington honorary French citizenship on August 26, 1792, during the early stages of the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGeorge_Washington's_Mount_Vernon,_Essay,_citizenship_323-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGeorge_Washington's_Mount_Vernon,_Essay,_citizenship-323">[308]</a></sup> Hamilton formulated the <a href="/wiki/Jay_Treaty" title="Jay Treaty">Jay Treaty</a> to normalize trade relations with Great Britain while removing them from western forts, and also to resolve financial debts remaining from the Revolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEElkinsMcKitrick1995ch._9_324-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEElkinsMcKitrick1995ch._9-324">[309]</a></sup> Chief Justice <a href="/wiki/John_Jay" title="John Jay">John Jay</a> acted as Washington's negotiator and signed the treaty on November 19, 1794; critical Jeffersonians, however, supported France. Washington deliberated, then supported the treaty because it avoided war with Britain,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010730_325-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010730-325">[310]</a></sup> but was disappointed that its provisions favored Britain.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009340_326-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009340-326">[311]</a></sup> He mobilized public opinion and secured ratification in the Senate<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEstes2000393–422Estes2001127–158_327-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEstes2000393–422Estes2001127–158-327">[312]</a></sup> but faced frequent public criticism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009344_328-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009344-328">[313]</a></sup>
</p><p>The British agreed to abandon their forts around the <a href="/wiki/Great_Lakes" title="Great Lakes">Great Lakes</a>, and the United States modified the boundary with Canada. The government liquidated numerous pre-Revolutionary debts, and the British opened the <a href="/wiki/British_West_Indies" title="British West Indies">British West Indies</a> to American trade. The treaty secured peace with Britain and a decade of prosperous trade. Jefferson claimed that it angered France and "invited rather than avoided" war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009343_329-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009343-329">[314]</a></sup> Relations with France deteriorated afterward, leaving succeeding president <a href="/wiki/John_Adams" title="John Adams">John Adams</a> with prospective war.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrizzard2005263Lengel2005357_330-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrizzard2005263Lengel2005357-330">[315]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/James_Monroe" title="James Monroe">James Monroe</a> was the American Minister to France, but Washington recalled him for his opposition to the Treaty. The French refused to accept his replacement <a href="/wiki/Charles_Cotesworth_Pinckney" title="Charles Cotesworth Pinckney">Charles Cotesworth Pinckney</a>, and the French Directory declared the authority to seize American ships two days before Washington's term ended.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAkers200227_331-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAkers200227-331">[316]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Native_American_affairs">Native American affairs</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States" title="Native Americans in the United States">Native Americans in the United States</a>, <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Fallen_Timbers" title="Battle of Fallen Timbers">Battle of Fallen Timbers</a>, <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_New_York_(1790)" title="Treaty of New York (1790)">Treaty of New York (1790)</a>, <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Greenville" title="Treaty of Greenville">Treaty of Greenville</a>, <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Territory" title="Northwest Territory">Northwest Territory</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Ohio_Country" title="Ohio Country">Ohio Country</a></div>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Red_Jacket_2.jpg"><img alt="Portrait of Seneca Chief Sagoyewatha, Washington's peace emissary" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="3985" data-file-width="2900" decoding="async" height="247" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Red_Jacket_2.jpg/180px-Red_Jacket_2.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Red_Jacket_2.jpg/270px-Red_Jacket_2.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1e/Red_Jacket_2.jpg/360px-Red_Jacket_2.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Red_Jacket_2.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Seneca_people" title="Seneca people">Seneca</a> chief <a href="/wiki/Red_Jacket" title="Red Jacket">Red Jacket</a> was Washington's peace emissary with the <a href="/wiki/Northwestern_Confederacy" title="Northwestern Confederacy">Northwestern Confederacy</a>.</div></div></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Ron_Chernow" title="Ron Chernow">Ron Chernow</a> describes Washington as always trying to be even-handed in dealing with the Natives. He states that Washington hoped they would abandon their itinerant hunting life and adapt to fixed agricultural communities in the manner of white settlers. He also maintains that Washington never advocated outright confiscation of tribal land or the forcible removal of tribes and that he berated American settlers who abused natives, admitting that he held out no hope for pacific relations with the natives as long as "frontier settlers entertain the opinion that there is not the same crime (or indeed no crime at all) in killing a native as in killing a white man."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010666_332-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010666-332">[317]</a></sup>
</p><p>By contrast, <a href="/wiki/Colin_G._Calloway" title="Colin G. Calloway">Colin G. Calloway</a> writes that "Washington had a lifelong obsession with getting Indian land, either for himself or for his nation, and initiated policies and campaigns that had devastating effects in Indian country."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECalloway201838_333-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECalloway201838-333">[318]</a></sup> "The growth of the nation," Galloway has stated, "demanded the dispossession of Indian people. Washington hoped the process could be bloodless and that Indian people would give up their lands for a "fair" price and move away. But if Indians refused and resisted, as they often did, he felt he had no choice but to "extirpate" them and that the expeditions he sent to destroy Indian towns were therefore entirely justified."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-334"><a href="#cite_note-334">[319]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the Fall of 1789, Washington had to contend with the British refusing to evacuate their forts in the Northwest frontier and their <a href="/wiki/Northwest_Indian_War" title="Northwest Indian War">concerted efforts</a> to incite hostile Indian tribes to attack <a href="/wiki/European_Americans" title="European Americans">American</a> settlers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1936523Cooke20029–10Chernow2010665_335-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1936523Cooke20029–10Chernow2010665-335">[320]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-336"><a href="#cite_note-336">[p]</a></sup> The Northwest tribes under <a href="/wiki/Miami_people" title="Miami people">Miami</a> chief <a href="/wiki/Little_Turtle" title="Little Turtle">Little Turtle</a> allied with the British Army to resist American expansion, and killed 1,500 settlers between 1783 and 1790.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWaldmanBraun2009149_337-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWaldmanBraun2009149-337">[321]</a></sup>
</p><p>As documented by Harless (2018), Washington declared that "The Government of the United States are determined that their Administration of Indian Affairs shall be directed entirely by the great principles of Justice and humanity",<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarless2018_338-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarless2018-338">[322]</a></sup> and provided that treaties should negotiate their land interests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHarless2018_338-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHarless2018-338">[322]</a></sup> The administration regarded powerful tribes as foreign nations, and Washington even smoked a <a href="/wiki/Ceremonial_pipe" title="Ceremonial pipe">peace pipe</a> and drank wine with them at the <a href="/wiki/President%27s_House_(Philadelphia)" title="President's House (Philadelphia)">Philadelphia presidential house</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECalloway20182_339-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECalloway20182-339">[323]</a></sup> He made numerous attempts to conciliate them;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlexner1969304Taylor2016406_340-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlexner1969304Taylor2016406-340">[324]</a></sup> he equated killing indigenous peoples with killing whites and sought to integrate them into <a href="/wiki/European_Americans" title="European Americans">European American</a> culture.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke200210_341-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke200210-341">[325]</a></sup> Secretary of War <a href="/wiki/Henry_Knox" title="Henry Knox">Henry Knox</a> also attempted to encourage agriculture among the tribes.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlexner1969304Taylor2016406_340-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlexner1969304Taylor2016406-340">[324]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the Southwest, negotiations failed between federal commissioners and raiding Indian tribes seeking retribution. Washington invited <a href="/wiki/Muscogee" title="Muscogee">Creek</a> Chief <a href="/wiki/Alexander_McGillivray" title="Alexander McGillivray">Alexander McGillivray</a> and 24 leading chiefs to New York to negotiate a treaty and treated them like foreign dignitaries. Knox and McGillivray concluded the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_New_York_(1790)" title="Treaty of New York (1790)">Treaty of New York</a> on August 7, 1790, in <a href="/wiki/Federal_Hall" title="Federal Hall">Federal Hall</a>, which provided the tribes with agricultural supplies and McGillivray with a rank of Brigadier General Army and a salary of $1,500.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGrizzard2002256–257Puls2008207–208_342-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGrizzard2002256–257Puls2008207–208-342">[326]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Fallen_timbers.jpg"><img alt="A R.F. Zogbaum scene of the Battle of Fallen Timbers includes Native Americans aiming as cavalry soldiers charge with raised swords and one soldier is shot and loses his mount" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1946" data-file-width="2939" decoding="async" height="146" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Fallen_timbers.jpg/220px-Fallen_timbers.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Fallen_timbers.jpg/330px-Fallen_timbers.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ad/Fallen_timbers.jpg/440px-Fallen_timbers.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Fallen_timbers.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Battle of Fallen Timbers</i> by R. F. Zogbaum, 1896. The <a href="/wiki/Ohio_Country" title="Ohio Country">Ohio Country</a> was ceded to America in its aftermath.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1790, Washington sent Brigadier General <a href="/wiki/Josiah_Harmar" title="Josiah Harmar">Josiah Harmar</a> to pacify the Northwest tribes, but Little Turtle routed him twice and forced him to withdraw.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010667–678Gaff2004xviiWaldmanBraun2009149_343-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010667–678Gaff2004xviiWaldmanBraun2009149-343">[327]</a></sup> The <a href="/wiki/Northwestern_Confederacy" title="Northwestern Confederacy">Northwestern Confederacy</a> of tribes used guerrilla tactics and were an effective force against the sparsely manned American Army. Washington sent Major General <a href="/wiki/Arthur_St._Clair" title="Arthur St. Clair">Arthur St. Clair</a> from <a href="/wiki/Fort_Washington_(Ohio)" title="Fort Washington (Ohio)">Fort Washington</a> on an expedition to restore peace in the territory in 1791. On November 4, St. Clair's forces were ambushed and <a href="/wiki/St._Clair%27s_defeat" title="St. Clair's defeat">soundly defeated</a> by tribal forces with few survivors,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-344"><a href="#cite_note-344">[328]</a></sup> despite Washington's warning of surprise attacks. Washington was outraged over what he viewed to be excessive Native American brutality and execution of captives, including women and children.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGaff20043–6Ferling2009340_345-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaff20043–6Ferling2009340-345">[329]</a></sup>
</p><p>St. Clair resigned his commission, and Washington replaced him with the Revolutionary War hero General <a href="/wiki/Anthony_Wayne" title="Anthony Wayne">Anthony Wayne</a>. From 1792 to 1793, Wayne instructed his troops on Native American warfare tactics and instilled discipline which was lacking under St. Clair.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke200210Chernow2010668_346-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke200210Chernow2010668-346">[330]</a></sup> In August 1794, Washington sent Wayne into tribal territory with authority to drive them out by burning their villages and crops in the <a href="/wiki/Maumee,_Ohio" title="Maumee, Ohio">Maumee Valley</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETaylor2016406Chernow2010668_347-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETaylor2016406Chernow2010668-347">[331]</a></sup> On August 24, the American army under Wayne's leadership defeated the western confederacy at the <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Fallen_Timbers" title="Battle of Fallen Timbers">Battle of Fallen Timbers</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Treaty_of_Greenville" title="Treaty of Greenville">Treaty of Greenville</a> in August 1795 opened up two-thirds of the <a href="/wiki/Ohio_Country" title="Ohio Country">Ohio Country</a> for American settlement.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke200214Taylor2016406_348-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke200214Taylor2016406-348">[332]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Second_term">Second term</span></h3>
<p>Originally, Washington had planned to retire after his first term, while many Americans could not imagine anyone else taking his place.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010674_349-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010674-349">[333]</a></sup> After nearly four years as president, and dealing with the infighting in his own cabinet and with partisan critics, Washington showed little enthusiasm in running for a second term, while Martha also wanted him not to run.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010675,_678Ferling2009362Randall1997484_350-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010675,_678Ferling2009362Randall1997484-350">[334]</a></sup> James Madison urged him not to retire, that his absence would only allow the dangerous political rift in his cabinet and the House to worsen. Jefferson also pleaded with him not to retire and agreed to drop his attacks on Hamilton, or he would also retire if Washington did.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling1988421Randall1997482Chernow2010675,_678_351-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling1988421Randall1997482Chernow2010675,_678-351">[335]</a></sup> Hamilton maintained that Washington's absence would be "deplored as the greatest evil" to the country at this time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2005403_352-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2005403-352">[336]</a></sup> Washington's close nephew George Augustine Washington, his manager at Mount Vernon, was critically ill and had to be replaced, further increasing Washington's desire to retire and return to Mount Vernon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010687_353-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010687-353">[337]</a></sup>
</p><p>When the <a href="/wiki/1792_United_States_presidential_election" title="1792 United States presidential election">election of 1792</a> neared, Washington did not publicly announce his presidential candidacy. Still, he silently consented to run to prevent a further political-personal rift in his cabinet. The <a href="/wiki/United_States_Electoral_College" title="United States Electoral College">Electoral College</a> unanimously elected him president on February 13, 1793, and <a href="/wiki/John_Adams" title="John Adams">John Adams</a> as vice president by a vote of 77 to 50.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke200210_341-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke200210-341">[325]</a></sup> Washington, with nominal fanfare, arrived alone at <a href="/wiki/Presidency_of_George_Washington" title="Presidency of George Washington">his inauguration</a> in his carriage. Sworn into office by Associate Justice <a href="/wiki/William_Cushing" title="William Cushing">William Cushing</a> on March 4, 1793, in the Senate Chamber of <a href="/wiki/Congress_Hall" title="Congress Hall">Congress Hall</a> in Philadelphia, Washington gave a brief address and then immediately retired to his Philadelphia presidential house, weary of office and in poor health.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010687Cooke200210–11_354-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010687Cooke200210–11-354">[338]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Constitution1803.jpg"><img alt="Painting of the frigate USS Constitution with three masts" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="5578" data-file-width="7200" decoding="async" height="170" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Constitution1803.jpg/220px-Constitution1803.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Constitution1803.jpg/330px-Constitution1803.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/Constitution1803.jpg/440px-Constitution1803.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Constitution1803.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/USS_Constitution" title="USS Constitution">USS <i>Constitution</i></a>: Commissioned and named by President Washington in 1794</div></div></div>
<p>On April 22, 1793, during the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolution" title="French Revolution">French Revolution</a>, Washington issued his famous <a href="/wiki/Proclamation_of_Neutrality" title="Proclamation of Neutrality">Neutrality Proclamation</a> and was resolved to pursue "a conduct friendly and impartial toward the belligerent Powers" while he warned Americans not to intervene in the international conflict. <sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009299,_304,_308–311Banning19742Cooke200211–12_355-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009299,_304,_308–311Banning19742Cooke200211–12-355">[339]</a></sup> Although Washington recognized France's revolutionary government, he would eventually ask French minister to America <a href="/wiki/Edmond-Charles_Gen%C3%AAt" title="Edmond-Charles Genêt">Citizen Genêt</a> be recalled over the Citizen Genêt Affair.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke200212–13_356-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke200212–13-356">[340]</a></sup> Genêt was a diplomatic troublemaker who was openly hostile toward Washington's neutrality policy. He procured four American ships as privateers to strike at Spanish forces (British allies) in <a href="/wiki/Florida" title="Florida">Florida</a> while organizing militias to strike at other British possessions. However, his efforts failed to draw America into the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolutionary_Wars" title="French Revolutionary Wars">foreign campaigns</a> during Washington's presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010692Cooke200212_357-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010692Cooke200212-357">[341]</a></sup> On July 31, 1793, Jefferson submitted his resignation from Washington's cabinet.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECooke200213_358-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECooke200213-358">[342]</a></sup> Washington signed the <a href="/wiki/Naval_Act_of_1794" title="Naval Act of 1794">Naval Act of 1794</a> and commissioned the first six federal frigates to combat <a href="/wiki/Barbary_pirates" title="Barbary pirates">Barbary pirates</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010713_359-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010713-359">[343]</a></sup>
</p><p>In January 1795, Hamilton, who desired more income for his family, resigned office and was replaced by Washington appointment <a href="/wiki/Oliver_Wolcott_Jr." title="Oliver Wolcott Jr.">Oliver Wolcott, Jr.</a> Washington and Hamilton remained friends. However, Washington's relationship with his Secretary of War Henry Knox deteriorated. Knox resigned office on the rumor he profited from construction contracts on U.S. Frigates.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010726–727Cooke200215_360-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010726–727Cooke200215-360">[344]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the final months of his presidency, Washington was assailed by his political foes and a partisan press who accused him of being ambitious and greedy, while he argued that he had taken no salary during the war and had risked his life in battle. He regarded the press as a disuniting, "diabolical" force of falsehoods, sentiments that he expressed in his <a href="/wiki/George_Washington%27s_Farewell_Address" title="George Washington's Farewell Address">Farewell Address</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall1997491–492Chernow2010752–754_361-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall1997491–492Chernow2010752–754-361">[345]</a></sup> At the end of his second term, Washington retired for personal and political reasons, dismayed with personal attacks, and to ensure that a truly contested presidential election could be held. He did not feel bound to a two-term limit, but his retirement set a significant precedent. Washington is often credited with setting the principle of a two-term presidency, but it was Thomas Jefferson who first refused to run for a third term on political grounds.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKorzi201143Peabody2001439–453_362-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKorzi201143Peabody2001439–453-362">[346]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Farewell_Address">Farewell Address</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/George_Washington%27s_Farewell_Address" title="George Washington's Farewell Address">George Washington's Farewell Address</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Washington%27s_Farewell_Address.jpg"><img alt="Newspaper showing Washington's Farewell Address" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="557" data-file-width="931" decoding="async" height="132" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Washington%27s_Farewell_Address.jpg/220px-Washington%27s_Farewell_Address.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Washington%27s_Farewell_Address.jpg/330px-Washington%27s_Farewell_Address.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f0/Washington%27s_Farewell_Address.jpg/440px-Washington%27s_Farewell_Address.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Washington%27s_Farewell_Address.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/George_Washington%27s_Farewell_Address" title="George Washington's Farewell Address">Washington's Farewell Address</a> (September 19, 1796)</div></div></div>
<p>In 1796, Washington declined to run for a third term of office, believing his death in office would create an image of a lifetime appointment. The precedent of a two-term limit was created by his retirement from office.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpaldingGarrity199658Lurie2018_363-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpaldingGarrity199658Lurie2018-363">[347]</a></sup> In May 1792, in anticipation of his retirement, Washington instructed <a href="/wiki/James_Madison" title="James Madison">James Madison</a> to prepare a "<a href="/wiki/Valedictorian" title="Valedictorian">valedictory address</a>", an initial draft of which was entitled the "Farewell Address".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpaldingGarrity199646–47_364-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpaldingGarrity199646–47-364">[348]</a></sup> In May 1796, Washington sent the manuscript to his Secretary of Treasury <a href="/wiki/Alexander_Hamilton" title="Alexander Hamilton">Alexander Hamilton</a> who did an extensive rewrite, while Washington provided final edits.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlexner1972292Chernow2010752–753SpaldingGarrity19964744Hayes2017287–298_365-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlexner1972292Chernow2010752–753SpaldingGarrity19964744Hayes2017287–298-365">[349]</a></sup> On September 19, 1796, David Claypoole's <i><a href="/wiki/Pennsylvania_Packet" title="Pennsylvania Packet">American Daily Advertiser</a></i> published the final version of the address.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010754Lurie2018_366-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010754Lurie2018-366">[350]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington stressed that national identity was paramount, while a united America would safeguard freedom and prosperity. He warned the nation of three eminent dangers: regionalism, partisanship, and foreign entanglements, and said the "name of AMERICAN, which belongs to you, in your national capacity, must always exalt the just pride of patriotism, more than any appellation derived from local discriminations."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010755Lurie2018_367-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010755Lurie2018-367">[351]</a></sup> Washington called for men to move beyond partisanship for the common good, stressing that the United States must concentrate on its own interests. He warned against foreign alliances and their influence in domestic affairs, and bitter partisanship and the dangers of political parties.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall1997492Boller196347_368-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall1997492Boller196347-368">[352]</a></sup> He counseled friendship and commerce with all nations, but advised against involvement in European wars.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFishmanPedersonRozell2001119–120GreggSpalding1999199–216_369-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFishmanPedersonRozell2001119–120GreggSpalding1999199–216-369">[353]</a></sup> He stressed the importance of religion, asserting that "religion and morality are indispensable supports" in a republic.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010133_370-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010133-370">[354]</a></sup> Washington's address favored Hamilton's Federalist ideology and economic policies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall1997492Cooke200218–19Flexner1972292–297Avlon2017223Boller196347_371-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall1997492Cooke200218–19Flexner1972292–297Avlon2017223Boller196347-371">[355]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington closed the address by reflecting on his legacy:
</p>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r996844942">.mw-parser-output .templatequote{overflow:hidden;margin:1em 0;padding:0 40px}.mw-parser-output .templatequote .templatequotecite{line-height:1.5em;text-align:left;padding-left:1.6em;margin-top:0}</style><blockquote class="templatequote"><p>Though in reviewing the incidents of my Administration I am unconscious of intentional error, I am nevertheless too sensible of my defects not to think it probable that I may have committed many errors. Whatever they may be, I fervently beseech the Almighty to avert or mitigate the evils to which they may tend. I shall also carry with me the hope that my country will never cease to view them with indulgence, and that, after forty-five years of my life dedicated to its service with an upright zeal, the faults of incompetent abilities will be consigned to oblivion, as myself must soon be to the <a href="/wiki/John_14" title="John 14">mansions of rest</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEAvlon2017280_372-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEAvlon2017280-372">[356]</a></sup></p></blockquote>
<p>After initial publication, many Republicans, including Madison, criticized the Address and believed it was an anti-French campaign document. Madison believed Washington was strongly pro-British. Madison also was suspicious of who authored the Address.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESpaldingGarrity1996143_373-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESpaldingGarrity1996143-373">[357]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1839, Washington biographer <a href="/wiki/Jared_Sparks" title="Jared Sparks">Jared Sparks</a> maintained that Washington's "...<span class="nowrap"> </span>Farewell Address was <a href="/wiki/Early_American_publishers_and_printers" title="Early American publishers and printers">printed and published</a> with the laws, by order of the legislatures, as an evidence of the value they attached to its political precepts, and of their affection for its author."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESparks1839444_374-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESparks1839444-374">[358]</a></sup> In 1972, Washington scholar <a href="/wiki/James_Thomas_Flexner" title="James Thomas Flexner">James Flexner</a> referred to the Farewell Address as receiving as much acclaim as Thomas Jefferson's <a href="/wiki/United_States_Declaration_of_Independence" title="United States Declaration of Independence">Declaration of Independence</a> and <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln" title="Abraham Lincoln">Abraham Lincoln</a>'s <a href="/wiki/Gettysburg_Address" title="Gettysburg Address">Gettysburg Address</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlexner1972292SpaldingGarrity1996142_375-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlexner1972292SpaldingGarrity1996142-375">[359]</a></sup> In 2010, historian <a href="/wiki/Ron_Chernow" title="Ron Chernow">Ron Chernow</a> reported the <i>Farewell Address</i> proved to be one of the most influential statements on Republicanism.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010752–754_376-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010752–754-376">[360]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Post-presidency_.281797.E2.80.931799.29"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Post-presidency_(1797–1799)">Post-presidency (1797–1799)</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Post-presidency_of_George_Washington" title="Post-presidency of George Washington">Post-presidency of George Washington</a></div>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Retirement">Retirement</span></h3>
<p>Washington retired to Mount Vernon in March 1797 and devoted time to his plantations and other business interests, including his <a href="/wiki/File:George_Washington%27s_Distillery.JPG" title="File:George Washington's Distillery.JPG">distillery</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBreenWhite2006209–220_377-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBreenWhite2006209–220-377">[361]</a></sup> His plantation operations were only minimally profitable,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201053_51-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201053-51">[46]</a></sup> and his lands in the west (<a href="/wiki/Piedmont_(United_States)" title="Piedmont (United States)">Piedmont</a>) were under Indian attacks and yielded little income, with the squatters there refusing to pay rent. He attempted to sell these but without success.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllis2004255–261_378-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllis2004255–261-378">[362]</a></sup> He became an even more committed Federalist. He vocally supported the <a href="/wiki/Alien_and_Sedition_Acts" title="Alien and Sedition Acts">Alien and Sedition Acts</a> and convinced Federalist <a href="/wiki/John_Marshall" title="John Marshall">John Marshall</a> to run for Congress to weaken the Jeffersonian hold on <a href="/wiki/Virginia" title="Virginia">Virginia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlexner1974386_379-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlexner1974386-379">[363]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington grew restless in retirement, prompted by tensions with France, and he wrote to Secretary of War <a href="/wiki/James_McHenry" title="James McHenry">James McHenry</a> offering to organize President Adams' army.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall1997497_380-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall1997497-380">[364]</a></sup> In a continuation of the <a href="/wiki/French_Revolutionary_Wars" title="French Revolutionary Wars">French Revolutionary Wars</a>, French privateers began seizing American ships in 1798, and relations deteriorated with France and led to the "<a href="/wiki/Quasi-War" title="Quasi-War">Quasi-War</a>". Without consulting Washington, Adams nominated him for a lieutenant general commission on July 4, 1798, and the position of commander-in-chief of the armies.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlexner1974376–377Bell199264_381-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlexner1974376–377Bell199264-381">[365]</a></sup> Washington chose to accept, replacing <a href="/wiki/James_Wilkinson" title="James Wilkinson">James Wilkinson</a>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBell199264_382-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBell199264-382">[366]</a></sup> and he served as the commanding general from July 13, 1798, until his death 17 months later. He participated in planning for a provisional army, but he avoided involvement in details. In advising McHenry of potential officers for the army, he appeared to make a complete break with Jefferson's Democratic-Republicans: "you could as soon scrub the blackamoor white, as to change the principles of a profest Democrat; and that he will leave nothing unattempted to overturn the government of this country."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1936474vol._36_383-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1936474vol._36-383">[367]</a></sup> Washington delegated the active leadership of the army to Hamilton, a major general. No army invaded the United States during this period, and Washington did not assume a field command.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEKohn1975225–242Grizzard2005264_384-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKohn1975225–242Grizzard2005264-384">[368]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington was known to be rich because of the well-known "glorified façade of wealth and grandeur" at Mount Vernon,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010708_385-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010708-385">[369]</a></sup> but nearly all his wealth was in the form of land and slaves rather than ready cash. To supplement his income, he erected a <a href="/wiki/File:George_Washington%27s_Distillery.JPG" title="File:George Washington's Distillery.JPG">distillery</a> for substantial whiskey production.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirschfeld199744–45Ferling2009351_386-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirschfeld199744–45Ferling2009351-386">[370]</a></sup> Historians estimate that the estate was worth about $1<span class="nowrap"> </span>million in 1799 dollars,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEDalzellDalzell1998219_387-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDalzellDalzell1998219-387">[371]</a></sup> equivalent to $15,967,000 in 2021. He bought land parcels to spur development around the new <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Federal City</a> named in his honor, and he sold individual lots to middle-income investors rather than multiple lots to large investors, believing they would more likely commit to making improvements.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010704–705_388-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010704–705-388">[372]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Final_days_and_death">Final days and death</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Life_of_George_Washington,_Deathbed.jpg"><img alt="Washington on his deathbed, with doctors and family surrounding" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1970" data-file-width="2845" decoding="async" height="152" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Life_of_George_Washington%2C_Deathbed.jpg/220px-Life_of_George_Washington%2C_Deathbed.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Life_of_George_Washington%2C_Deathbed.jpg/330px-Life_of_George_Washington%2C_Deathbed.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/ba/Life_of_George_Washington%2C_Deathbed.jpg/440px-Life_of_George_Washington%2C_Deathbed.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Life_of_George_Washington,_Deathbed.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Washington on his Deathbed</i><br/><a href="/wiki/Junius_Brutus_Stearns" title="Junius Brutus Stearns">Junius Brutus Stearns</a> 1799</div></div></div>
<p>On December 12, 1799, Washington inspected his farms on horseback. He returned home late and had guests over for dinner. He had a sore throat the next day but was well enough to mark trees for cutting. That evening, he complained of chest congestion but was still cheerful.<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTE"The_Death_of_George_Washington"_389-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTE"The_Death_of_George_Washington"-389'>[373]</a></sup> On Saturday, he awoke to an inflamed throat and difficulty breathing, so he ordered estate overseer George Rawlins to remove nearly a pint of his blood; <a href="/wiki/Bloodletting" title="Bloodletting">bloodletting</a> was a common practice of the time. His family summoned Doctors <a href="/wiki/James_Craik" title="James Craik">James Craik</a>, <a href="/wiki/Gustavus_Richard_Brown" title="Gustavus Richard Brown">Gustavus Richard Brown</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Elisha_C._Dick" title="Elisha C. Dick">Elisha C. Dick</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010806–810Morens19991845–1849_390-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010806–810Morens19991845–1849-390">[374]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/William_Thornton" title="William Thornton">Dr. William Thornton</a> arrived some hours after Washington died.<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTE"Death_Defied"_391-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTE"Death_Defied"-391'>[375]</a></sup>
</p><p>Dr. Brown thought Washington had <a href="/wiki/Peritonsillar_abscess" title="Peritonsillar abscess">quinsy</a>; Dr. Dick thought the condition was a more serious "violent inflammation of the throat".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010806–807Lear1799257_392-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010806–807Lear1799257-392">[376]</a></sup> They continued the process of bloodletting to approximately five pints, and Washington's condition deteriorated further. Dr. Dick proposed a <a href="/wiki/Tracheotomy" title="Tracheotomy">tracheotomy</a>, but the others were not familiar with that procedure and therefore disapproved.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010806–810FelisatiSperati200555–58_393-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010806–810FelisatiSperati200555–58-393">[377]</a></sup> Washington instructed Brown and Dick to leave the room, while he assured Craik, "Doctor, I die hard, but I am not afraid to go."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllis2004269_394-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllis2004269-394">[378]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington's death came more swiftly than expected.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009365_395-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009365-395">[379]</a></sup> On his deathbed, he instructed his private secretary <a href="/wiki/Tobias_Lear" title="Tobias Lear">Tobias Lear</a> to wait three days before his burial, out of fear of being entombed alive.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010808_396-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010808-396">[380]</a></sup> According to Lear, he died between 10 and 11 p.m. on December 14, 1799, with Martha seated at the foot of his bed. His last words were "'Tis well", from his conversation with Lear about his burial. He was 67.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlexner1974401–402Chernow2010808–809_397-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlexner1974401–402Chernow2010808–809-397">[381]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:GeorgeWashingtonByRobertField.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1903" data-file-width="1643" decoding="async" height="197" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/GeorgeWashingtonByRobertField.jpg/170px-GeorgeWashingtonByRobertField.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/GeorgeWashingtonByRobertField.jpg/255px-GeorgeWashingtonByRobertField.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/GeorgeWashingtonByRobertField.jpg/340px-GeorgeWashingtonByRobertField.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:GeorgeWashingtonByRobertField.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Portrait_miniature" title="Portrait miniature">Miniature</a> of George Washington by <a href="/wiki/Robert_Field_(painter)" title="Robert Field (painter)">Robert Field</a> (1800)</div></div></div>
<p>Congress immediately adjourned for the day upon news of Washington's death, and the Speaker's chair was shrouded in black the next morning.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIrving1857359_398-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIrving1857359-398">[382]</a></sup> The funeral was held four days after his death on December 18, 1799, at Mount Vernon, where his body was interred. Cavalry and foot soldiers led the procession, and six colonels served as the pallbearers. The Mount Vernon funeral service was restricted mostly to family and friends.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010808–810_399-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010808–810-399">[383]</a></sup> Reverend Thomas Davis read the funeral service by the vault with a brief address, followed by a ceremony performed by various members of Washington's Masonic lodge in <a href="/wiki/Alexandria,_Virginia" title="Alexandria, Virginia">Alexandria, Virginia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIrving1857374–375_400-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIrving1857374–375-400">[384]</a></sup> Congress chose <a href="/wiki/Henry_Lee_III" title="Henry Lee III">Light-Horse Harry Lee</a> to deliver the eulogy. Word of his death traveled slowly; church bells rang in the cities, and many places of business closed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010810–811_401-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010810–811-401">[385]</a></sup> People worldwide admired Washington and were saddened by his death, and memorial processions were held in major cities of the United States. Martha wore a black mourning cape for one year, and she burned their correspondence to protect their privacy. Only five letters between the couple are known to have survived: two from Martha to George and three from him to her.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010814_402-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010814-402">[386]</a></sup>
</p><p>The diagnosis of Washington's illness and the immediate cause of his death have been subjects of debate since the day he died. The published account of Drs. Craik and Brown<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-404"><a href="#cite_note-404">[q]</a></sup> stated that his symptoms had been consistent with <i>cynanche trachealis</i> (tracheal inflammation), a term of that period used to describe severe inflammation of the upper windpipe, including quinsy. Accusations have persisted since Washington's death concerning medical malpractice, with some believing he had been bled to death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010806–810FelisatiSperati200555–58_393-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010806–810FelisatiSperati200555–58-393">[377]</a></sup> Various modern medical authors have speculated that he died from a severe case of <a href="/wiki/Epiglottitis" title="Epiglottitis">epiglottitis</a> complicated by the given treatments, most notably the massive blood loss which almost certainly caused <a href="/wiki/Hypovolemia" title="Hypovolemia">hypovolemic shock</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010809_405-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010809-405">[388]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-409"><a href="#cite_note-409">[r]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span id="Burial.2C_net_worth.2C_and_aftermath"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Burial,_net_worth,_and_aftermath">Burial, net worth, and aftermath</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Washington_Tomb.jpg"><img alt="A picture of the two sarcophagi of George (at right) and Martha Washington at the present tomb at Mount Vernon." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="768" data-file-width="576" decoding="async" height="293" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Washington_Tomb.jpg/220px-Washington_Tomb.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Washington_Tomb.jpg/330px-Washington_Tomb.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c5/Washington_Tomb.jpg/440px-Washington_Tomb.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Washington_Tomb.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>The sarcophagi of George (right) and Martha Washington at the present tomb's entrance</div></div></div>
<p>Washington was buried in the old Washington family vault at Mount Vernon, situated on a grassy slope overspread with willow, juniper, cypress, and chestnut trees. It contained the remains of his brother Lawrence and other family members, but the decrepit brick vault needed repair, prompting Washington to leave instructions in his will for the construction of a new vault.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010810–811_401-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010810–811-401">[385]</a></sup> Washington's estate at the time of his death was worth an estimated $780,000 in 1799, approximately equivalent to $17.82<span class="nowrap"> </span>million in 2021.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEGardner2013_410-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGardner2013-410">[392]</a></sup> Washington's peak net worth was $587.0 million, including his 300 slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-411"><a href="#cite_note-411">[393]</a></sup> Washington held title to more than 65,000 acres of land in 37 different locations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Lehrman_Institute_(June_22,_2021)_96-2"><a href="#cite_note-Lehrman_Institute_(June_22,_2021)-96">[88]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1830, a disgruntled ex-employee of the estate <a href="/wiki/Attempted_theft_of_George_Washington%27s_skull" title="Attempted theft of George Washington's skull">attempted to steal</a> what he thought was Washington's skull, prompting the construction of a more secure vault.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECraughwell200977–79_412-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECraughwell200977–79-412">[394]</a></sup> The next year, the new vault was constructed at Mount Vernon to receive the remains of George and Martha and other relatives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE&quot;Mount_Vernon_Ladies'_Association,_New_Tomb&quot;_413-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE&quot;Mount_Vernon_Ladies'_Association,_New_Tomb&quot;-413">[395]</a></sup> In 1832, a joint Congressional committee debated moving his body from Mount Vernon to a crypt in the Capitol.
