The crypt had been built by architect <a href="/wiki/Charles_Bulfinch" title="Charles Bulfinch">Charles Bulfinch</a> in the 1820s during the reconstruction of the burned-out capital, after the <a href="/wiki/Burning_of_Washington" title="Burning of Washington">Burning of Washington</a> by the British during the <a href="/wiki/War_of_1812" title="War of 1812">War of 1812</a>. Southern opposition was intense, antagonized by an ever-growing rift between North and South; many were concerned that Washington's remains could end up on "a shore foreign to his native soil" if the country became divided, and Washington's remains stayed in Mount Vernon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoorstin2010349–350_414-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoorstin2010349–350-414">[396]</a></sup>
</p><p>On October 7, 1837, Washington's remains were placed, still in the original lead coffin, within a marble sarcophagus designed by <a href="/wiki/William_Strickland_(architect)" title="William Strickland (architect)">William Strickland</a> and constructed by John Struthers earlier that year.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStrickland184011–14Carlson2016chapter_1_415-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStrickland184011–14Carlson2016chapter_1-415">[397]</a></sup> The sarcophagus was sealed and encased with planks, and an outer vault was constructed around it.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEStrickland184011–14_416-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEStrickland184011–14-416">[398]</a></sup> The outer vault has the sarcophagi of both George and Martha Washington; the inner vault has the remains of other Washington family members and relatives.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE&quot;Mount_Vernon_Ladies'_Association,_New_Tomb&quot;_413-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE&quot;Mount_Vernon_Ladies'_Association,_New_Tomb&quot;-413">[395]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Personal_life">Personal life</span></h2>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Edward_Savage_-_The_Washington_Family_-_Google_Art_ProjectFXD.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="7398" data-file-width="9911" decoding="async" height="164" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Edward_Savage_-_The_Washington_Family_-_Google_Art_ProjectFXD.jpg/220px-Edward_Savage_-_The_Washington_Family_-_Google_Art_ProjectFXD.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Edward_Savage_-_The_Washington_Family_-_Google_Art_ProjectFXD.jpg/330px-Edward_Savage_-_The_Washington_Family_-_Google_Art_ProjectFXD.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/36/Edward_Savage_-_The_Washington_Family_-_Google_Art_ProjectFXD.jpg/440px-Edward_Savage_-_The_Washington_Family_-_Google_Art_ProjectFXD.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Edward_Savage_-_The_Washington_Family_-_Google_Art_ProjectFXD.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i><a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Family" title="The Washington Family">The Washington Family</a></i> by <a href="/wiki/Edward_Savage_(artist)" title="Edward Savage (artist)">Edward Savage</a> (c. 1789–1796) George and Martha Washington with her grandchildren. <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/National_Art_Gallery" title="National Art Gallery">National Art Gallery</a><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-417"><a href="#cite_note-417">[399]</a></sup></div></div></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_Washington%E2%80%99s_bookplate._Sotheby%27s.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="384" data-file-width="295" decoding="async" height="286" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/17/George_Washington%E2%80%99s_bookplate._Sotheby%27s.jpg/220px-George_Washington%E2%80%99s_bookplate._Sotheby%27s.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/17/George_Washington%E2%80%99s_bookplate._Sotheby%27s.jpg 1.5x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_Washington%E2%80%99s_bookplate._Sotheby%27s.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>George Washington's bookplate with the <a href="/wiki/Coat_of_arms_of_the_Washington_family" title="Coat of arms of the Washington family">Coat of arms of the Washington family</a></div></div></div>
<p>Washington was somewhat reserved in personality, but he generally had a strong presence among others. He made speeches and announcements when required, but he was not a noted orator or debater.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200216Randall199734,_436Chernow201029–30_418-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200216Randall199734,_436Chernow201029–30-418">[400]</a></sup> He was taller than most of his contemporaries;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200216_419-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200216-419">[401]</a></sup> accounts of his height vary from 6 ft (1.83 m) to 6 ft 3.5 in (1.92 m) tall,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010122_87-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010122-87">[80]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-420"><a href="#cite_note-420">[402]</a></sup> he weighed between 210–220 pounds (95–100 kg) as an adult,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling200216Chernow201029–30_421-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling200216Chernow201029–30-421">[403]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-422"><a href="#cite_note-422">[404]</a></sup> and he was known for his great strength.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010123–125_423-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010123–125-423">[405]</a></sup> He had grey-blue eyes and long reddish-brown hair. He did not wear a <a href="/wiki/Wig#19th_and_20th_centuries" title="Wig">powdered wig</a>;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-424"><a href="#cite_note-424">[406]</a></sup> instead he wore his hair curled, powdered and tied in a queue in the <a href="/wiki/1775%E2%80%931795_in_Western_fashion#Men's_fashion" title="1775–1795 in Western fashion">fashion of the day</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201030_425-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201030-425">[407]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington frequently suffered from severe <a href="/wiki/Tooth_decay" title="Tooth decay">tooth decay</a> and ultimately lost all <a href="/wiki/George_Washington%27s_teeth" title="George Washington's teeth">his teeth</a> but one. He had several sets of false teeth, which he wore during his presidency, made using a variety of materials including both animal and human teeth, but wood was not used despite common lore.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-426"><a href="#cite_note-426">[408]</a></sup> These dental problems left him in constant pain, for which he took <a href="/wiki/Laudanum" title="Laudanum">laudanum</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201030,_290,_437–439,_642–643_427-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201030,_290,_437–439,_642–643-427">[409]</a></sup> As a public figure, he relied upon the strict confidence of his dentist.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010642–643_428-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010642–643-428">[410]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington was a talented equestrian early in life. He collected thoroughbreds at Mount Vernon, and his two favorite horses were <a href="/wiki/Blueskin_(horse)" title="Blueskin (horse)">Blueskin</a> and <a href="/wiki/Nelson_(horse)" title="Nelson (horse)">Nelson</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010124,_469_429-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010124,_469-429">[411]</a></sup> Fellow Virginian <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Jefferson" title="Thomas Jefferson">Thomas Jefferson</a> said Washington was "the best horseman of his age and the most graceful figure that could be seen on horseback";<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010124_430-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010124-430">[412]</a></sup> he also hunted foxes, deer, ducks, and other game.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010469_431-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010469-431">[413]</a></sup> He was an excellent dancer and attended the theater frequently. He drank in moderation but was morally opposed to excessive drinking, smoking tobacco, gambling, and profanity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010134_432-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010134-432">[414]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Religion_and_Freemasonry">Religion and Freemasonry</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/Religious_views_of_George_Washington" title="Religious views of George Washington">Religious views of George Washington</a> and <a href="/wiki/American_Enlightenment" title="American Enlightenment">American Enlightenment</a></div>
<p>Washington was descended from Anglican minister <a href="/wiki/Lawrence_Washington_(1602%E2%80%931652)" title="Lawrence Washington (1602–1652)">Lawrence Washington</a> (his great-great-grandfather), whose troubles with the <a href="/wiki/Church_of_England" title="Church of England">Church of England</a> may have prompted his heirs to emigrate to America.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETsakiridis2018_433-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETsakiridis2018-433">[415]</a></sup> Washington was baptized as an infant in April 1732 and became a devoted member of the Church of England (the Anglican Church).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow20106Morrison2009136Alden19962,_26Randall199717Tsakiridis2018_434-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow20106Morrison2009136Alden19962,_26Randall199717Tsakiridis2018-434">[416]</a></sup> He served more than 20 years as a <a href="/wiki/Vestryman" title="Vestryman">vestryman</a> and churchwarden for <a href="/wiki/Fairfax_Parish,_Virginia" title="Fairfax Parish, Virginia">Fairfax Parish</a> and <a href="/wiki/Truro_Parish,_Virginia" title="Truro Parish, Virginia">Truro Parish, Virginia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010130Thompson200840Tsakiridis2018_435-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010130Thompson200840Tsakiridis2018-435">[417]</a></sup> He privately prayed and read the Bible daily, and he publicly encouraged people and the nation to pray.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrazer2012198–199Chernow2010119,_132Tsakiridis2018_436-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrazer2012198–199Chernow2010119,_132Tsakiridis2018-436">[418]</a></sup> He may have taken communion on a regular basis prior to the Revolutionary War, but he did not do so following the war, for which he was admonished by Pastor <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/James_Abercrombie_(Episcopal_priest)" title="James Abercrombie (Episcopal priest)">James Abercrombie</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010131,_470Johnstone191987–195Frazer2012201–203Tsakiridis2018_437-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010131,_470Johnstone191987–195Frazer2012201–203Tsakiridis2018-437">[419]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:172px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Washington_Masonic_print.jpg"><img alt="Washington is shown presiding as Master Mason over a lodge meeting." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1414" data-file-width="936" decoding="async" height="257" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Washington_Masonic_print.jpg/170px-Washington_Masonic_print.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Washington_Masonic_print.jpg/255px-Washington_Masonic_print.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/96/Washington_Masonic_print.jpg/340px-Washington_Masonic_print.jpg 2x" width="170"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Washington_Masonic_print.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>George Washington as Master of his Lodge, 1793</div></div></div>
<p>Washington believed in a "wise, inscrutable, and irresistible" Creator God who was active in the Universe, contrary to <a href="/wiki/Deism" title="Deism">deistic thought</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETsakiridis2018_433-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETsakiridis2018-433">[415]</a></sup> He referred to God by the Enlightenment terms <i><a href="/wiki/Divine_providence" title="Divine providence">Providence</a></i>, the <i>Creator</i>, or the <i>Almighty</i>, and also as the <i>Divine Author</i> or the <i>Supreme Being</i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall199767Tsakiridis2018_438-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall199767Tsakiridis2018-438">[420]</a></sup> He believed in a divine power who watched over battlefields, was involved in the outcome of war, was protecting his life, and was involved in American politics—and specifically in the creation of the United States.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010131Tsakiridis2018_439-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010131Tsakiridis2018-439">[421]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-441"><a href="#cite_note-441">[s]</a></sup> Modern historian <a href="/wiki/Ron_Chernow" title="Ron Chernow">Ron Chernow</a> has posited that Washington avoided evangelistic Christianity or hellfire-and-brimstone speech along with communion and anything inclined to "flaunt his religiosity". Chernow has also said Washington "never used his religion as a device for partisan purposes or in official undertakings".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010131–132_442-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010131–132-442">[423]</a></sup> No mention of <a href="/wiki/Jesus" title="Jesus">Jesus</a> Christ appears in <a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Papers" title="The Washington Papers">his private correspondence</a>, and such references are rare in his public writings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENovak200795Tsakiridis2018_443-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENovak200795Tsakiridis2018-443">[424]</a></sup> He frequently quoted from the Bible or paraphrased it, and often referred to the Anglican <i><a href="/wiki/Book_of_Common_Prayer" title="Book of Common Prayer">Book of Common Prayer</a></i>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010131–132Morrison2009136Tsakiridis2018_444-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010131–132Morrison2009136Tsakiridis2018-444">[425]</a></sup> There is debate on whether he is best classed as a Christian or a <a href="/wiki/Theistic_rationalism" title="Theistic rationalism">theistic rationalist</a>—or both.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFrazer2012197–198,_201–203Novak2007158–161_445-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFrazer2012197–198,_201–203Novak2007158–161-445">[426]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington emphasized religious toleration in a nation with numerous denominations and religions. He publicly attended services of different Christian denominations and prohibited anti-Catholic celebrations in the Army.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBoller1963125_446-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBoller1963125-446">[427]</a></sup> He engaged workers at Mount Vernon without regard for religious belief or affiliation. While president, he acknowledged major religious sects and gave speeches on religious toleration.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010131_447-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010131-447">[428]</a></sup> He was distinctly rooted in the ideas, values, and modes of thinking of the Enlightenment,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWood2001313_448-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWood2001313-448">[429]</a></sup> but he harbored no contempt of organized Christianity and its clergy, "being no bigot myself to any mode of worship".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWood2001313_448-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWood2001313-448">[429]</a></sup> In 1793, speaking to members of the <a href="/wiki/The_New_Church_(Swedenborgian)" title="The New Church (Swedenborgian)">New Church</a> in Baltimore, Washington proclaimed, "We have abundant reason to rejoice that in this Land the light of truth and reason has triumphed over the power of bigotry and superstition."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENovak2007117,_n._52_449-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENovak2007117,_n._52-449">[430]</a></sup>
</p><p><a href="/wiki/Freemasonry" title="Freemasonry">Freemasonry</a> was a widely accepted institution in the late 18th century, known for advocating moral teachings.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010132,_500Morrison2009136Stavish2007XIX,_XXIImmekus2018_450-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010132,_500Morrison2009136Stavish2007XIX,_XXIImmekus2018-450">[431]</a></sup> Washington was attracted to the Masons' dedication to the Enlightenment principles of rationality, reason, and brotherhood. The American Masonic lodges did not share the anti-clerical perspective of the <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Anticlericalism_and_Freemasonry" title="Anticlericalism and Freemasonry">controversial European lodges</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow201027,_704_451-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow201027,_704-451">[432]</a></sup> A Masonic lodge was established in Fredericksburg in September 1752, and Washington was initiated two months later at the age of 20 as one of its first Entered Apprentices. Within a year, he progressed through its ranks to become a Master Mason.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall199767Chernow201027_452-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall199767Chernow201027-452">[433]</a></sup> Washington had high regard for the Masonic Order, but his personal lodge attendance was sporadic. In 1777, a convention of Virginia lodges asked him to be the Grand Master of the newly established <a href="/wiki/Grand_Lodge_of_Virginia" title="Grand Lodge of Virginia">Grand Lodge of Virginia</a>, but he declined due to his commitments leading the Continental Army. After 1782, he frequently corresponded with Masonic lodges and members,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEImmekus2018_453-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEImmekus2018-453">[434]</a></sup> and he was listed as Master in the Virginia charter of <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_Masonic_National_Memorial" title="George Washington Masonic National Memorial">Alexandria Lodge No. 22</a> in 1788.<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTE"A_Brief_History"_(GWMNMA)_454-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTE"A_Brief_History"_(GWMNMA)-454'>[435]</a></sup>
</p>
<div style="clear:both;"></div>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Slavery">Slavery</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main articles: <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_and_slavery" title="George Washington and slavery">George Washington and slavery</a>, <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Slavery_in_the_colonial_United_States" title="Slavery in the colonial United States">Slavery in the colonial United States</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States" title="Slavery in the United States">Slavery in the United States</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:282px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Junius_Brutus_Stearns_-_George_Washington_as_Farmer_at_Mount_Vernon.jpg"><img alt="Washington the farmer is shown standing on his plantation talking to an overseer as children play and slaves work. Work is by Junius Stearns." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="828" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="193" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Junius_Brutus_Stearns_-_George_Washington_as_Farmer_at_Mount_Vernon.jpg/280px-Junius_Brutus_Stearns_-_George_Washington_as_Farmer_at_Mount_Vernon.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Junius_Brutus_Stearns_-_George_Washington_as_Farmer_at_Mount_Vernon.jpg/420px-Junius_Brutus_Stearns_-_George_Washington_as_Farmer_at_Mount_Vernon.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Junius_Brutus_Stearns_-_George_Washington_as_Farmer_at_Mount_Vernon.jpg/560px-Junius_Brutus_Stearns_-_George_Washington_as_Farmer_at_Mount_Vernon.jpg 2x" width="280"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Junius_Brutus_Stearns_-_George_Washington_as_Farmer_at_Mount_Vernon.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Washington as Farmer at Mount Vernon</i><br/><a href="/wiki/Junius_Brutus_Stearns" title="Junius Brutus Stearns">Junius Brutus Stearns</a>, 1851</div></div></div>
<p>In Washington's lifetime, slavery was <a href="/wiki/History_of_slavery_in_Virginia" title="History of slavery in Virginia">deeply ingrained</a> in the economic and social fabric of Virginia.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHenriques2006146_455-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHenriques2006146-455">[436]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillcoxArnstein198841–42_456-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillcoxArnstein198841–42-456">[437]</a></sup> Slavery was <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_the_colonial_history_of_the_United_States" title="Slavery in the colonial history of the United States">legal in all of the Thirteen Colonies</a> prior to the American Revolution.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Maloy_(April_6,_2021)_457-0"><a href="#cite_note-Maloy_(April_6,_2021)-457">[438]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span id="Washington.27s_slaves"></span><span class="mw-headline" id="Washington's_slaves">Washington's slaves</span></h3>
<p>Washington owned and rented <a href="/wiki/Slavery_in_the_United_States" title="Slavery in the United States">enslaved</a> <a href="/wiki/African_Americans" title="African Americans">African Americans</a>, and during his lifetime over 577 slaves lived and worked at Mount Vernon.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mount_Vernon_Slaves_458-0"><a href="#cite_note-Mount_Vernon_Slaves-458">[439]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000279Ellis200445_459-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000279Ellis200445-459">[440]</a></sup> He acquired them through inheritance, gaining control of 84 <a href="/wiki/Dowry" title="Dowry">dower</a> slaves upon his marriage to Martha, and purchased at least 71 slaves between 1752 and 1773.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000279–280Morgan2005405,_407_n7Hirschfeld199712_460-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000279–280Morgan2005405,_407_n7Hirschfeld199712-460">[441]</a></sup> From 1786 he rented slaves, at his death he was renting 41.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-461"><a href="#cite_note-461">[442]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Mount_Vernon_Slaves_458-1"><a href="#cite_note-Mount_Vernon_Slaves-458">[439]</a></sup> His early views on slavery were no different from any Virginia <a href="/wiki/Planter_class" title="Planter class">planter</a> of the time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETwohig2001116_462-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETwohig2001116-462">[443]</a></sup> From the 1760s his attitudes underwent a slow evolution. The first doubts were prompted by his transition from tobacco to grain crops, which left him with a costly surplus of slaves, causing him to question the system's economic efficiency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005413_463-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005413-463">[444]</a></sup> His growing disillusionment with the institution was spurred by the principles of the American Revolution and revolutionary friends such as Lafayette and Hamilton.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETwohig2001121Morgan2005426_464-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETwohig2001121Morgan2005426-464">[445]</a></sup> Most historians agree the Revolution was central to the evolution of Washington's attitudes on slavery;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFurstenberg2011260_465-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFurstenberg2011260-465">[446]</a></sup> "After 1783", Kenneth Morgan writes, "...[Washington] began to express inner tensions about the problem of slavery more frequently, though always in private..."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000299_466-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000299-466">[447]</a></sup>
</p><p>The many contemporary reports of slave treatment at Mount Vernon are varied and conflicting.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWiencek2003348_467-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWiencek2003348-467">[448]</a></sup> Historian Kenneth Morgan (2000) maintains that Washington was frugal on spending for clothes and bedding for his slaves, and only provided them with just enough food, and that he maintained strict control over his slaves, instructing his overseers to keep them working hard from dawn to dusk year-round.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000286–287_468-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000286–287-468">[449]</a></sup> However, historian Dorothy Twohig (2001) said: "Food, clothing, and housing seem to have been at least adequate".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETwohig2001_469-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETwohig2001-469">[450]</a></sup> Washington faced growing debts involved with the costs of supporting slaves. He held an "engrained sense of racial superiority" towards African Americans but harbored no ill feelings toward them.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000283,_285,_286_470-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000283,_285,_286-470">[451]</a></sup> Some enslaved families worked at different locations on the plantation but were allowed to visit one another on their days off.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000282,_283–285Chernow2010112–113_471-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000282,_283–285Chernow2010112–113-471">[452]</a></sup> Washington's slaves received two hours off for meals during the workday and were given time off on Sundays and religious holidays.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010111Ferling200246Schwarz200127,_83Slave_Labor_(Mount_Vernon_Ladies'_Association_Essay)_472-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010111Ferling200246Schwarz200127,_83Slave_Labor_(Mount_Vernon_Ladies'_Association_Essay)-472">[453]</a></sup>
</p><p>Some accounts report that Washington opposed flogging but at times sanctioned its use, generally as a last resort, on both men and women slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirschfeld199736Slave_Control_(Mount_Vernon_Ladies'_Association_Essay)_473-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirschfeld199736Slave_Control_(Mount_Vernon_Ladies'_Association_Essay)-473">[454]</a></sup> Washington used both reward and punishment to encourage discipline and productivity in his slaves. He tried appealing to an individual's sense of pride, gave better blankets and clothing to the "most deserving", and motivated his slaves with cash rewards. He believed "watchfulness and admonition" to be often better deterrents against transgressions but would punish those who "will not do their duty by fair means". Punishment ranged in severity from demotion back to fieldwork, through whipping and beatings, to permanent separation from friends and family by sale. Historian Ron Chernow maintains that overseers were required to warn slaves before resorting to the lash and required Washington's written permission before whipping, though his extended absences did not always permit this.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010113–114_474-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010113–114-474">[455]</a></sup> Washington remained dependent on slave labor to work his farms and negotiated the purchase of more slaves in 1786 and 1787.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETwohig2001122–123Morgan2000283,_289_475-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETwohig2001122–123Morgan2000283,_289-475">[456]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:192px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Oney_Judge_Runaway_Ad.jpg"><img alt="Runaway advertisement from the May 24, 1796, Pennsylvania Gazette, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="758" data-file-width="753" decoding="async" height="191" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Oney_Judge_Runaway_Ad.jpg/190px-Oney_Judge_Runaway_Ad.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Oney_Judge_Runaway_Ad.jpg/285px-Oney_Judge_Runaway_Ad.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/50/Oney_Judge_Runaway_Ad.jpg/380px-Oney_Judge_Runaway_Ad.jpg 2x" width="190"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Oney_Judge_Runaway_Ad.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>Runaway advertisement for <a href="/wiki/Oney_Judge" title="Oney Judge">Oney Judge</a>, enslaved servant in Washington's presidential household</div></div></div>
<p>Washington brought several of his slaves with him and his family to the federal capital during his presidency. When the capital moved from New York City to Philadelphia in 1791, the president began rotating his slave household staff periodically between the capital and Mount Vernon. This was done deliberately to circumvent Pennsylvania's <a href="/wiki/An_Act_for_the_Gradual_Abolition_of_Slavery" title="An Act for the Gradual Abolition of Slavery">Slavery Abolition Act</a>, which, in part, automatically freed any slave who moved to the state and lived there for more than six months.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-476"><a href="#cite_note-476">[457]</a></sup> In May 1796, Martha's personal and favorite slave <a href="/wiki/Oney_Judge" title="Oney Judge">Oney Judge</a> escaped to <a href="/wiki/Portsmouth,_New_Hampshire" title="Portsmouth, New Hampshire">Portsmouth</a>. At Martha's behest, Washington attempted to capture Ona, using a Treasury agent, but this effort failed. In February 1797, Washington's personal slave <a href="/wiki/Hercules_Posey" title="Hercules Posey">Hercules</a> escaped to Philadelphia and was never found.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010759–763_477-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010759–763-477">[458]</a></sup>
</p><p>In February 1786, Washington took a census of Mount Vernon and recorded 224 slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000279–287_478-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000279–287-478">[459]</a></sup> By 1799, slaves at Mount Vernon totaled 317, including 143 children.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000281–282_479-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000281–282-479">[460]</a></sup> Washington owned 124 slaves, leased 40, and held 153 for his wife's dower interest.<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000298"Ten_Facts_About_Washington_&amp;_Slavery"_480-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000298"Ten_Facts_About_Washington_&amp;_Slavery"-480'>[461]</a></sup> Washington supported many slaves who were too young or too old to work, greatly increasing Mount Vernon's slave population and causing the plantation to operate at a loss.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWiencek2003319,_348–349Flexner1974386Hirschfeld19972Ellis2004167Morgan2000283_481-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWiencek2003319,_348–349Flexner1974386Hirschfeld19972Ellis2004167Morgan2000283-481">[462]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Abolition_and_manumission">Abolition and manumission</span></h3>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Main article: <a href="/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States" title="Abolitionism in the United States">Abolitionism in the United States</a></div>
<p>Based on his letters, diary, documents, accounts from colleagues, employees, friends, and visitors, Washington slowly developed a cautious sympathy toward <a href="/wiki/Abolitionism_in_the_United_States" title="Abolitionism in the United States">abolitionism</a> that eventually ended with his will <a href="/wiki/Manumission" title="Manumission">freeing</a> his military/war valet <a href="/wiki/William_Lee_(valet)" title="William Lee (valet)">Billy Lee</a>, and then subsequently freeing the rest of his personally-owned slaves outright upon Martha's death.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHirschfeld19973Morgan200029Washington1799b_482-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHirschfeld19973Morgan200029Washington1799b-482">[463]</a></sup> As president, he remained publicly silent on the topic of slavery, believing it was a nationally divisive issue which could destroy the union.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllis2004202Twohig2001_483-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllis2004202Twohig2001-483">[464]</a></sup>
</p><p>During the American Revolutionary War, Washington began to change his views on slavery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Maloy_(April_6,_2021)_457-1"><a href="#cite_note-Maloy_(April_6,_2021)-457">[438]</a></sup> In a 1778 letter to <a href="/wiki/Lund_Washington" title="Lund Washington">Lund Washington</a>, he made clear his desire "to get quit of Negroes" when discussing the exchange of slaves for the land he wanted to buy.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005416–417_484-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005416–417-484">[465]</a></sup> The next year, Washington stated his intention not to separate enslaved families as a result of "a change of masters".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005417_485-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005417-485">[466]</a></sup> During the 1780s, Washington privately expressed his support for the gradual emancipation of slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllis2004201_486-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllis2004201-486">[467]</a></sup> Between 1783 and 1786, he gave moral support to a plan proposed by Lafayette to purchase land and free slaves to work on it, but declined to participate in the experiment.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETwohig2001_469-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETwohig2001-469">[450]</a></sup> Washington privately expressed support for emancipation to prominent Methodists <a href="/wiki/Thomas_Coke_(bishop)" title="Thomas Coke (bishop)">Thomas Coke</a> and <a href="/wiki/Francis_Asbury" title="Francis Asbury">Francis Asbury</a> in 1785 but declined to sign their petition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000292_487-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2000292-487">[468]</a></sup> In personal correspondence the next year, he made clear his desire to see the institution of slavery ended by a gradual legislative process, a view that correlated with the mainstream antislavery literature published in the 1780s that Washington possessed.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005418–419Furstenberg2011273–274,_284–285_488-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005418–419Furstenberg2011273–274,_284–285-488">[469]</a></sup> He significantly reduced his purchases of slaves after the war but continued to acquire them in small numbers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETwohig2001122–123Morgan2005419Morgan2000289_489-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETwohig2001122–123Morgan2005419Morgan2000289-489">[470]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tleft"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Tobias_Lear.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="435" data-file-width="359" decoding="async" height="218" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Tobias_Lear.jpg/180px-Tobias_Lear.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/Tobias_Lear.jpg/270px-Tobias_Lear.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/b/bf/Tobias_Lear.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Tobias_Lear.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>In 1794, Washington privately expressed to <a href="/wiki/Tobias_Lear" title="Tobias Lear">Tobias Lear</a>, his secretary, that he found slavery to be repugnant.</div></div></div>
<p>In 1788, Washington declined a suggestion from a leading French abolitionist, <a href="/wiki/Jacques_Pierre_Brissot" title="Jacques Pierre Brissot">Jacques Brissot</a>, to establish an abolitionist society in Virginia, stating that although he supported the idea, the time was not yet right to confront the issue.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFurstenberg2011280_490-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFurstenberg2011280-490">[471]</a></sup> The historian <a href="/wiki/Henry_Wiencek" title="Henry Wiencek">Henry Wiencek</a> (2003) believes, based on a remark that appears in the notebook of his biographer <a href="/wiki/David_Humphreys_(soldier)" title="David Humphreys (soldier)">David Humphreys</a>, that Washington considered making a public statement by freeing his slaves on the eve of his presidency in 1789.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWiencek2003272–275_491-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWiencek2003272–275-491">[472]</a></sup> The historian <a href="/wiki/Philip_D._Morgan" title="Philip D. Morgan">Philip D. Morgan</a> (2005) disagrees, believing the remark was a "private expression of remorse" at his inability to free his slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005422–423_492-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005422–423-492">[473]</a></sup> Other historians agree with Morgan that Washington was determined not to risk national unity over an issue as divisive as slavery.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETwohig2001126–127Morgan2000290,_299Ellis2004202_493-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETwohig2001126–127Morgan2000290,_299Ellis2004202-493">[474]</a></sup> Washington never responded to any of the antislavery petitions he received, and the subject was not mentioned in either his last address to Congress or his Farewell Address.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTETwohig2001126–127Morgan2000297Ferling2009363_494-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTETwohig2001126–127Morgan2000297Ferling2009363-494">[475]</a></sup>
</p><p>The first clear indication that Washington seriously intended to free his slaves appears in a letter written to his secretary, <a href="/wiki/Tobias_Lear" title="Tobias Lear">Tobias Lear</a>, in 1794.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEllis2004257_495-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllis2004257-495">[476]</a></sup> Washington instructed Lear to find buyers for his land in western Virginia, explaining in a private coda that he was doing so "to liberate a certain species of property which I possess, very repugnantly to my own feelings".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWiencek2003274_496-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWiencek2003274-496">[477]</a></sup> The plan, along with others Washington considered in 1795 and 1796, could not be realized because he failed to find buyers for his land, his reluctance to break up slave families, and the refusal of the Custis heirs to help prevent such separations by freeing their dower slaves at the same time.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005423–424_497-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005423–424-497">[478]</a></sup>
</p><p>On July 9, 1799, Washington finished making his last will; the longest provision concerned slavery. All his slaves were to be freed after the death of his wife, Martha. Washington said he did not free them immediately because his slaves intermarried with his wife's dower slaves. He forbade their sale or transportation out of Virginia. His will provided that old and young freed people be taken care of indefinitely; younger ones were to be taught to read and write and placed in suitable occupations.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005404_498-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005404-498">[479]</a></sup> Washington freed more than 160 slaves, including about 25 he had acquired from his wife's brother <a href="/wiki/Bartholomew_Dandridge" title="Bartholomew Dandridge">Bartholomew Dandridge</a> in payment of a debt.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005404–405_499-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMorgan2005404–405-499">[480]</a></sup> He was among the few large slave-holding Virginians during the Revolutionary Era who emancipated their slaves.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWiencek2003352–354_500-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWiencek2003352–354-500">[481]</a></sup>
</p><p>On January 1, 1801, one year after George Washington's death, Martha Washington signed an order to free his slaves. Many of them, having never strayed far from Mount Vernon, were naturally reluctant to try their luck elsewhere; others refused to abandon spouses or children still held as dower slaves (the Custis estate)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010802_501-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010802-501">[482]</a></sup> and also stayed with or near Martha. Following George Washington's instructions in his will, funds were used to feed and clothe the young, aged, and infirm slaves until the early 1830s.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010815_502-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010815-502">[483]</a></sup>
</p>
<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="Historical_reputation_and_legacy">Historical reputation and legacy</span></h2>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Legacy_of_George_Washington" title="Legacy of George Washington">Legacy of George Washington</a>, <a href="/wiki/Cultural_depictions_of_George_Washington" title="Cultural depictions of George Washington">Cultural depictions of George Washington</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Historical_rankings_of_presidents_of_the_United_States" title="Historical rankings of presidents of the United States">Historical rankings of presidents of the United States</a></div>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:182px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Stuart-george-washington-constable-1797.jpg"><img alt="portrait of Washington seated facing left by Gilbert Stuart" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1080" data-file-width="845" decoding="async" height="230" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Stuart-george-washington-constable-1797.jpg/180px-Stuart-george-washington-constable-1797.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Stuart-george-washington-constable-1797.jpg/270px-Stuart-george-washington-constable-1797.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/82/Stuart-george-washington-constable-1797.jpg/360px-Stuart-george-washington-constable-1797.jpg 2x" width="180"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Stuart-george-washington-constable-1797.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><i>Washington, the Constable</i> by <a href="/wiki/Gilbert_Stuart" title="Gilbert Stuart">Gilbert Stuart</a> (1797)</div></div></div>
<p>Washington's legacy endures as one of the most influential in American history since he served as commander-in-chief of the <a href="/wiki/Continental_Army" title="Continental Army">Continental Army</a>, a hero of the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolution" title="American Revolution">Revolution</a>, and the first <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_United_States" title="President of the United States">president of the United States</a>. Various historians maintain that he also was a dominant factor in America's founding, the <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">Revolutionary War</a>, and the <a href="/wiki/Constitutional_Convention_(United_States)" title="Constitutional Convention (United States)">Constitutional Convention</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009xviii_503-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009xviii-503">[484]</a></sup> <a href="/wiki/American_Revolutionary_War" title="American Revolutionary War">Revolutionary War</a> comrade <a href="/wiki/Henry_Lee_III" title="Henry Lee III">Light-Horse Harry Lee</a> <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/The_Father_of_His_Country" title="s:The Father of His Country">eulogized him</a> as "First in war—first in peace—and first in the hearts of his countrymen".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling20093–4_504-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling20093–4-504">[485]</a></sup> Lee's words became the hallmark by which Washington's reputation was impressed upon the American memory, with some biographers regarding him as the great exemplar of republicanism. He set many precedents for the national government and the presidency in particular, and he was called the "Father of His Country" as early as 1778.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEUnger2013236–237ParryAllison1991xiHindle201792_505-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEUnger2013236–237ParryAllison1991xiHindle201792-505">[486]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-507"><a href="#cite_note-507">[t]</a></sup>
</p><p>In 1879, Congress proclaimed <a href="/wiki/Presidents%27_Day" title="Presidents' Day">Washington's Birthday</a> to be a federal holiday.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling20094_508-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling20094-508">[488]</a></sup> Twentieth-century biographer <a href="/wiki/Douglas_Southall_Freeman" title="Douglas Southall Freeman">Douglas Southall Freeman</a> concluded, "The great big thing stamped across that man is character." Modern historian <a href="/wiki/David_Hackett_Fischer" title="David Hackett Fischer">David Hackett Fischer</a> has expanded upon Freeman's assessment, defining Washington's character as "integrity, self-discipline, courage, absolute honesty, resolve, and decision, but also forbearance, decency, and respect for others".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFischer2004446_509-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFischer2004446-509">[489]</a></sup>
</p>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:222px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:George_Washington_battling_a_tiger.jpg"><img alt="" class="thumbimage" data-file-height="933" data-file-width="1200" decoding="async" height="171" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/George_Washington_battling_a_tiger.jpg/220px-George_Washington_battling_a_tiger.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/George_Washington_battling_a_tiger.jpg/330px-George_Washington_battling_a_tiger.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a6/George_Washington_battling_a_tiger.jpg/440px-George_Washington_battling_a_tiger.jpg 2x" width="220"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:George_Washington_battling_a_tiger.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div>A drawing from a Japanese manuscript of Washington fighting a tiger.</div></div></div>
<p>Washington became an international symbol for liberation and nationalism as the leader of the first successful revolution against a colonial empire. The <a href="/wiki/Federalist_Party" title="Federalist Party">Federalists</a> made him the symbol of their party, but the <a href="/wiki/Democratic-Republican_Party" title="Democratic-Republican Party">Jeffersonians</a> continued to distrust his influence for many years and delayed building the <a href="/wiki/Washington_Monument" title="Washington Monument">Washington Monument</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECunliffe195824–26_510-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECunliffe195824–26-510">[490]</a></sup> Washington was elected a member of the <a href="/wiki/American_Academy_of_Arts_and_Sciences" title="American Academy of Arts and Sciences">American Academy of Arts and Sciences</a> on January 31, 1781, before he had even begun his presidency.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWillard2017_511-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWillard2017-511">[491]</a></sup> He was posthumously appointed to the grade of General of the Armies of the United States during the <a href="/wiki/United_States_Bicentennial" title="United States Bicentennial">United States Bicentennial</a> to ensure he would never be outranked; this was accomplished by the congressional joint resolution <a class="extiw" href="https://en.wikisource.org/wiki/Public_Law_94-479" title="s:Public Law 94-479">Public Law 94-479</a> passed on January 19, 1976, with an effective appointment date of July 4, 1976.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBell199252,_66_512-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBell199252,_66-512">[492]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-515"><a href="#cite_note-515">[u]</a></sup> On March 13, 1978, Washington was militarily promoted to the rank of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/General_of_the_Armies_of_the_United_States" title="General of the Armies of the United States">General of the Armies</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-Army_1978_516-0"><a href="#cite_note-Army_1978-516">[495]</a></sup>
</p><p><span class="anchor" id="Cherry_tree"></span><a href="/wiki/Mason_Locke_Weems" title="Mason Locke Weems">Parson Weems</a> wrote a <a href="/wiki/Hagiography" title="Hagiography">hagiographic</a> biography in 1809 to honor Washington.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWeems191822_517-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWeems191822-517">[496]</a></sup> Historian Ron Chernow maintains that Weems attempted to humanize Washington, making him look less stern, and to inspire "patriotism and morality" and to foster "enduring myths", such as Washington's refusal to lie about damaging his father's cherry tree.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010813–814Levy20136,_217Weems191822Delbanco1999_518-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010813–814Levy20136,_217Weems191822Delbanco1999-518">[497]</a></sup> Weems' accounts have never been proven or disproven.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELevy20136_519-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELevy20136-519">[498]</a></sup> Historian John Ferling, however, maintains that Washington remains the only founder and president ever to be referred to as "godlike", and points out that his character has been the most scrutinized by historians, past and present.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009xviii–xix_520-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009xviii–xix-520">[499]</a></sup> Historian <a href="/wiki/Gordon_S._Wood" title="Gordon S. Wood">Gordon S. Wood</a> concludes that "the greatest act of his life, the one that gave him his greatest fame, was his resignation as commander-in-chief of the American forces."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWood1992205_521-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWood1992205-521">[500]</a></sup> Chernow suggests that Washington was "burdened by public life" and divided by "unacknowledged ambition mingled with self-doubt".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010547_522-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010547-522">[501]</a></sup> A 1993 review of presidential polls and surveys consistently ranked Washington number 4, 3, or<span class="nowrap"> </span>2 among presidents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEMurrayBlessing19937–9,_15_523-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMurrayBlessing19937–9,_15-523">[502]</a></sup> A 2018 <a href="/wiki/Siena_College_Research_Institute" title="Siena College Research Institute">Siena College Research Institute</a> survey ranked him number<span class="nowrap"> </span>1 among presidents.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESiena_Expert_Poll_1982–2018_524-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESiena_Expert_Poll_1982–2018-524">[503]</a></sup>
</p><p>In the 21st century, Washington's reputation has been critically scrutinized. Along with various other Founding Fathers, he has been condemned for holding enslaved human beings. Though he expressed the desire to see the abolition of slavery come through legislation, he did not initiate or support any initiatives for bringing about its end. This has led to calls from some activists to remove his name from public buildings and his statue from public spaces.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-525"><a href="#cite_note-525">[504]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-526"><a href="#cite_note-526">[505]</a></sup> Nonetheless, Washington maintains his place among the highest-ranked U.S. Presidents, listed second (after <a href="/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln" title="Abraham Lincoln">Lincoln</a>) in a 2021 <a href="/wiki/C-SPAN" title="C-SPAN">C-SPAN</a> poll.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-527"><a href="#cite_note-527">[506]</a></sup>
</p>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Memorials">Memorials</span></h3>
<div class="thumb tright"><div class="thumbinner" style="width:132px;"><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Washington_Monument_Dusk_Jan_2006.jpg"><img alt="A dusk picture of the Washington Monument obelisk with flags around the base, in Washington, D.C." class="thumbimage" data-file-height="1826" data-file-width="1093" decoding="async" height="217" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Washington_Monument_Dusk_Jan_2006.jpg/130px-Washington_Monument_Dusk_Jan_2006.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Washington_Monument_Dusk_Jan_2006.jpg/195px-Washington_Monument_Dusk_Jan_2006.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c1/Washington_Monument_Dusk_Jan_2006.jpg/260px-Washington_Monument_Dusk_Jan_2006.jpg 2x" width="130"/></a> <div class="thumbcaption"><div class="magnify"><a class="internal" href="/wiki/File:Washington_Monument_Dusk_Jan_2006.jpg" title="Enlarge"></a></div><a href="/wiki/Washington_Monument" title="Washington Monument">Washington Monument</a>, Washington, D.C.</div></div></div>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/The_Washington_Papers" title="The Washington Papers">The Washington Papers</a>, <a href="/wiki/List_of_memorials_to_George_Washington" title="List of memorials to George Washington">List of memorials to George Washington</a>, and <a href="/wiki/Presidents_of_the_United_States_on_U.S._postage_stamps" title="Presidents of the United States on U.S. postage stamps">Presidents of the United States on U.S. postage stamps</a></div>
<p><a href="/wiki/Jared_Sparks" title="Jared Sparks">Jared Sparks</a> began collecting and publishing Washington's documentary record in the 1830s in <i>Life and Writings of George Washington</i> (12 vols., 1834–1837).<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTESparks1839Title_page_528-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTESparks1839Title_page-528">[507]</a></sup> <i>The Writings of George Washington from the Original Manuscript Sources, 1745–1799</i> (1931–1944) is a 39-volume set edited by <a href="/wiki/John_Clement_Fitzpatrick" title="John Clement Fitzpatrick">John Clement Fitzpatrick</a>, whom the George Washington Bicentennial Commission commissioned. It contains more than 17,000 letters and documents and is available online from the <a href="/wiki/University_of_Virginia" title="University of Virginia">University of Virginia</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1931–1944Lengel2011_529-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFitzpatrick1931–1944Lengel2011-529">[508]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Educational_institutions">Educational institutions</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Washington_(disambiguation)#Education" title="Washington (disambiguation)">Washington (disambiguation) § Education</a></div>
<p>Numerous <a href="/wiki/Secondary_school" title="Secondary school">secondary schools</a> are named in honor of Washington, as are many universities, including <a href="/wiki/George_Washington_University" title="George Washington University">George Washington University</a> and <a href="/wiki/Washington_University_in_St._Louis" title="Washington University in St. Louis">Washington University in St. Louis</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-530"><a href="#cite_note-530">[509]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-531"><a href="#cite_note-531">[510]</a></sup>
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Places_and_monuments">Places and monuments</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a class="mw-redirect mw-disambig" href="/wiki/Washington_(disambiguation)#Places" title="Washington (disambiguation)">Washington (disambiguation) § Places</a></div>
<p>Many places and monuments have been named in honor of Washington, most notably the capital of the United States, <a href="/wiki/Washington,_D.C." title="Washington, D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a> The state of <a href="/wiki/Washington_(state)" title="Washington (state)">Washington</a> is the only US state to be named after a president.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-532"><a href="#cite_note-532">[511]</a></sup>
</p><p>Washington appears as one of four U.S. presidents in a colossal statue by <a href="/wiki/Gutzon_Borglum" title="Gutzon Borglum">Gutzon Borglum</a> on <a href="/wiki/Mount_Rushmore" title="Mount Rushmore">Mount Rushmore</a> in South Dakota.
</p>
<h4><span class="mw-headline" id="Currency_and_postage">Currency and postage</span></h4>
<link href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1033289096" rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style"/><div class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable" role="note">Further information: <a href="/wiki/Presidents_of_the_United_States_on_U.S._postage_stamps" title="Presidents of the United States on U.S. postage stamps">Presidents of the United States on U.S. postage stamps</a></div>
<p>George Washington appears on contemporary U.S. currency, including the <a href="/wiki/United_States_one-dollar_bill" title="United States one-dollar bill">one-dollar bill</a>, the <a href="/wiki/Presidential_dollar_coins" title="Presidential dollar coins">Presidential one-dollar coin</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Quarter_(United_States_coin)" title="Quarter (United States coin)">quarter-dollar coin</a> (the <a href="/wiki/Washington_quarter" title="Washington quarter">Washington quarter</a>). Washington and <a href="/wiki/Benjamin_Franklin" title="Benjamin Franklin">Benjamin Franklin</a> appeared on the <a href="/wiki/File:First_US_Postage_stamps_of_1847.tiff" title="File:First US Postage stamps of 1847.tiff">nation's first postage stamps</a> in 1847. Washington has since appeared on many postage issues, more than any other person.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEShapiro2006_533-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShapiro2006-533">[512]</a></sup>
</p>
<ul class="gallery mw-gallery-packed">
<li class="gallerybox" style="width: 82.666666666667px"><div style="width: 82.666666666667px">

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="See_also">See also</span></h2>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1093669538">.mw-parser-output .portalbox{padding:0}.mw-parser-output .portalborder{border:solid #aaa 1px}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tleft{margin:0.5em 1em 0.5em 0}.mw-parser-output .portalbox.tright{margin:0.5em 0 0.5em 1em}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul{display:table;box-sizing:border-box;max-width:175px;font-size:85%;line-height:110%;font-style:italic;font-weight:bold}.mw-parser-output .portalborder>ul{padding:0.1em;background:#f9f9f9}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li{display:table-row}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:first-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em;vertical-align:middle;text-align:center}.mw-parser-output .portalbox>ul>li>span:last-child{display:table-cell;padding:0.2em 0.2em 0.2em 0.3em;vertical-align:middle}</style><div aria-label="Portals" class="noprint plainlist portalbox portalborder tright" role="navigation">
<ul>
<li><span><img alt="" class="noviewer thumbborder" data-file-height="3847" data-file-width="6004" decoding="async" height="21" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze%2C_MMA-NYC%2C_1851.jpg/32px-Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze%2C_MMA-NYC%2C_1851.jpg" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze%2C_MMA-NYC%2C_1851.jpg/48px-Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze%2C_MMA-NYC%2C_1851.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze%2C_MMA-NYC%2C_1851.jpg/64px-Washington_Crossing_the_Delaware_by_Emanuel_Leutze%2C_MMA-NYC%2C_1851.jpg 2x" width="32"/></span><span><a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Portal:American_Revolution" title="Portal:American Revolution">American Revolution portal</a></span></li>
<li><span><img alt="" class="noviewer" data-file-height="360" data-file-width="400" decoding="async" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/P_history.svg/31px-P_history.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/P_history.svg/47px-P_history.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/P_history.svg/62px-P_history.svg.png 2x" width="31"/></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:History" title="Portal:History">History portal</a></span></li>
<li><span><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:Yellow_flag_waving.svg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer" data-file-height="268" data-file-width="249" decoding="async" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Yellow_flag_waving.svg/26px-Yellow_flag_waving.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Yellow_flag_waving.svg/39px-Yellow_flag_waving.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/1b/Yellow_flag_waving.svg/52px-Yellow_flag_waving.svg.png 2x" width="26"/></a></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Liberalism" title="Portal:Liberalism">Liberalism portal</a></span></li>
<li><span><img alt="coin" class="noviewer" data-file-height="1762" data-file-width="1770" decoding="async" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/2006_AEGold_Proof_Obv.png/28px-2006_AEGold_Proof_Obv.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/2006_AEGold_Proof_Obv.png/42px-2006_AEGold_Proof_Obv.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/76/2006_AEGold_Proof_Obv.png/56px-2006_AEGold_Proof_Obv.png 2x" width="28"/></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Libertarianism" title="Portal:Libertarianism">Libertarianism portal</a></span></li>
<li><span><a class="image" href="/wiki/File:A_coloured_voting_box.svg"><img alt="icon" class="noviewer thumbborder" data-file-height="160" data-file-width="160" decoding="async" height="28" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/01/A_coloured_voting_box.svg/28px-A_coloured_voting_box.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/01/A_coloured_voting_box.svg/42px-A_coloured_voting_box.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/0/01/A_coloured_voting_box.svg/56px-A_coloured_voting_box.svg.png 2x" width="28"/></a></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:Politics" title="Portal:Politics">Politics portal</a></span></li>
<li><span><img alt="flag" class="noviewer thumbborder" data-file-height="650" data-file-width="1235" decoding="async" height="17" src="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/32px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png" srcset="//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/48px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/a/a4/Flag_of_the_United_States.svg/64px-Flag_of_the_United_States.svg.png 2x" width="32"/></span><span><a href="/wiki/Portal:United_States" title="Portal:United States">United States portal</a></span></li></ul></div>

<h2><span class="mw-headline" id="References">References</span></h2>
<h3><span class="mw-headline" id="Notes">Notes</span></h3>
<style data-mw-deduplicate="TemplateStyles:r1011085734">.mw-parser-output .reflist{font-size:90%;margin-bottom:0.5em;list-style-type:decimal}.mw-parser-output .reflist .references{font-size:100%;margin-bottom:0;list-style-type:inherit}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-2{column-width:30em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns-3{column-width:25em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns{margin-top:0.3em}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns ol{margin-top:0}.mw-parser-output .reflist-columns li{page-break-inside:avoid;break-inside:avoid-column}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-alpha{list-style-type:upper-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-upper-roman{list-style-type:upper-roman}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-alpha{list-style-type:lower-alpha}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-greek{list-style-type:lower-greek}.mw-parser-output .reflist-lower-roman{list-style-type:lower-roman}</style><div class="reflist reflist-lower-alpha">
<div class="mw-references-wrap mw-references-columns"><ol class="references">
<li id="cite_note-2"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-2">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Congress counted the votes of the Electoral College and certified a president on April 6. Washington was sworn in on April 30.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFerling2009274Taylor2016395,_494_1-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFerling2009274Taylor2016395,_494-1">[1]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-calendar-11"><span class="mw-cite-backlink">^ <a href="#cite_ref-calendar_11-0"><sup><i><b>a</b></i></sup></a> <a href="#cite_ref-calendar_11-1"><sup><i><b>b</b></i></sup></a></span> <span class="reference-text">Contemporaneous records used the <a href="/wiki/Old_Style_and_New_Style_dates" title="Old Style and New Style dates">Old Style</a> Julian calendar and the <a href="/wiki/New_Year#Historical_European_new_year_dates" title="New Year">Annunciation Style</a> of enumerating years, recording his birth as February 11, 1731. The British <a href="/wiki/Calendar_(New_Style)_Act_1750" title="Calendar (New Style) Act 1750">Calendar (New Style) Act 1750</a> implemented in 1752 altered the official British dating method to the Gregorian calendar with the start of the year on January<span class="nowrap"> </span>1 (it had been March 25). These changes resulted in dates being moved forward 11 days and an advance of one year for those between January<span class="nowrap"> </span>1 and March 25. For a further explanation, see <a href="/wiki/Old_Style_and_New_Style_dates" title="Old Style and New Style dates">Old Style and New Style dates</a>.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEEngber2006_10-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEngber2006-10">[9]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-26"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-26">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Washington received his license through the college, whose charter gave it the authority to appoint Virginia county surveyors. There is no evidence that he actually attended classes there.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTE&quot;George_Washington's_Professional_Surveys&quot;2nd_prgh_25-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTE&quot;George_Washington's_Professional_Surveys&quot;2nd_prgh-25">[23]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-34"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-34">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Thirty years later, Washington reflected "that so young and inexperienced a person should have been employed".<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTERandall199774Chernow201026–27,_31_33-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTERandall199774Chernow201026–27,_31-33">[30]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-44"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-44">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The mid-16th-century word <b>Indian</b> described the Indigenous Peoples of the Americas. More modern terms for Indians include American Indian and Native American and Indigenous Peoples.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECresswell2010222_43-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECresswell2010222-43">[39]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-61"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-61">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A second Virginia regiment was raised under Colonel William Byrd III and also allocated to the expedition.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFlexner1965206–207_60-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFlexner1965206–207-60">[55]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-72"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-72">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Some descendants of <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/West_Ford_(slave)" title="West Ford (slave)">West Ford</a>, a slave of <a href="/wiki/John_Augustine_Washington" title="John Augustine Washington">John Augustine Washington</a>'s, maintain (based on family <a href="/wiki/Oral_history" title="Oral history">oral history</a>) that Ford was fathered by George Washington, though historians dispute his paternity.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-70"><a href="#cite_note-70">[64]</a></sup><sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-71"><a href="#cite_note-71">[65]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-94"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-94">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In a letter of September 20, 1765, Washington protested to "Robert Cary &amp; Co." the low prices he received for his tobacco and for the inflated prices he was forced to pay on second-rate goods from London.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010138Ferling200968_93-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010138Ferling200968-93">[86]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-121"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-121">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Historian <a href="/wiki/Garry_Wills" title="Garry Wills">Garry Wills</a> noted, "before there was a nation—before there was any symbol of that nation (a flag, a Constitution, a national seal)—there was Washington."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010193_120-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010193-120">[112]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-132"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-132">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Congress initially directed the war effort in June 1776 with the committee known as "Board of War and Ordnance"; this was succeeded by the <a href="/wiki/Board_of_War" title="Board of War">Board of War</a> in July 1777, which eventually included members of the military.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEFreedman200842_131-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFreedman200842-131">[122]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-154"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-154">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">This painting has received both acclaim and criticism;<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEHowat1968290,_293,_297Nowlan201466_153-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEHowat1968290,_293,_297Nowlan201466-153">[143]</a></sup> see <a href="/wiki/Emanuel_Leutze" title="Emanuel Leutze">Emanuel Leutze</a> article for details.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-239"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-239">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Thomas Jefferson praised Washington for his "moderation and virtue" in relinquishing command. King George III reportedly praised him for this act.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010454Taylor2016319–320_238-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010454Taylor2016319–320-238">[227]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-242"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-242">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Society of the Cincinnati was formed by Henry Knox in May 1783, to carry on the memory of the War of Independence and to establish a fraternity of officers. The Society was named after <a class="mw-redirect" href="/wiki/Lucius_Quintus_Cincinnatus" title="Lucius Quintus Cincinnatus">Cincinnatus</a>, a famous Roman military leader who relinquished his position after his Roman victory at <a href="/wiki/Battle_of_Mount_Algidus" title="Battle of Mount Algidus">Algidus (458 BC)</a>. However, he had reservations about some of the society's precepts, including heredity requirements for membership and receiving money from foreign interests.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEChernow2010444,_461,_498Ferling2009xxParsons189896Brumwell2012412_241-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEChernow2010444,_461,_498Ferling2009xxParsons189896Brumwell2012412-241">[229]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-265"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-265">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Starting in 1774, 14 men served as <a href="/wiki/President_of_the_Continental_Congress" title="President of the Continental Congress">President of the Continental Congress</a> but bore no relationship to the presidency established under Article II of the Constitution. Under the Articles of Confederation, Congress called its presiding officer "President of the United States in Congress Assembled", but this position had no national executive powers.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEJensen1948178–179Unger201361,_146JillsonWilson199477_264-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEJensen1948178–179Unger201361,_146JillsonWilson199477-264">[251]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-272"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-272">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">There has been debate over whether Washington added "so help me God" to the end of the oath.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEIrving1857475Alden1996236_271-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEIrving1857475Alden1996236-271">[257]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-336"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-336">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">A modern term for Indian is Native American.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECresswell2010222_43-1"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECresswell2010222-43">[39]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-404"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-404">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The first account of Washington's death was written by Doctors Craik and Brown, published in <i>The Times</i> of Alexandria five days after his death on December 19, 1799. The complete text can be found in <i>The Eclectic Medical Journal</i> (1858)<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTENewtonFreemanBickley1858273–274_403-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTENewtonFreemanBickley1858273–274-403">[387]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-409"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-409">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">Modern experts have concluded that Washington probably died from acute bacterial <a href="/wiki/Epiglottitis" title="Epiglottitis">epiglottitis</a> complicated by the administered treatments, including Morens and Wallenborn in 1999,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWallenborn1999Morens19991845–1849_406-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWallenborn1999Morens19991845–1849-406">[389]</a></sup> Cheatham in 2008,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTECheatham2008_407-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTECheatham2008-407">[390]</a></sup> and Vadakan in 2005.<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEVadakan2005_408-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEVadakan2005-408">[391]</a></sup> These treatments included multiple doses of <a href="/wiki/Mercury(I)_chloride" title="Mercury(I) chloride">calomel</a> (a cathartic or purgative) and extensive bloodletting.</span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-441"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-441">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The Constitution came under attack in Pennsylvania, and Washington wrote to Richard Peters, "It would seem from the public Gazettes that the minority in your State are preparing for another attack of the now adopted Government; how formidable it may be, I know not. But that Providence which has hitherto smiled on the honest endeavours of the well meaning part of the People of this Country will not, I trust, withdraw its support from them at this crisis."<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEWashington1788b_440-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWashington1788b-440">[422]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-507"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-507">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">The earliest known <i>image</i> in which Washington is identified as the Father of His Country is in the frontispiece of a 1779 German-language almanac, with calculations by <a href="/wiki/David_Rittenhouse" title="David Rittenhouse">David Rittenhouse</a> and published by Francis Bailey in Lancaster County Pennsylvania. <i>Der Gantz Neue Verbesserte Nord-Americanische Calendar</i> has a personification of Fame holding a trumpet to her lips juxtaposed with an image of Washington and the words "<i>Der Landes Vater</i>" ("the father of the country" or "the father of the land").<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTELightnerReeder1953133_506-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTELightnerReeder1953133-506">[487]</a></sup></span>
</li>
<li id="cite_note-515"><span class="mw-cite-backlink"><b><a href="#cite_ref-515">^</a></b></span> <span class="reference-text">In <i>Portraits &amp; Biographical Sketches of the United States Army's Senior Officer</i>,<sup class="reference" id="cite_ref-FOOTNOTEBell199252_513-0"><a href="#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBell199252-513">[493]</a></sup> William Gardner Bell states that Washington was recalled to military service from his retirement in 1798, and "Congress passed legislation that would have made him General of the Armies of the United States, but his services were not required in the field, and the appointment was not made until the Bicentennial in 1976 when it was bestowed posthumously as a commemorative honor." In 1976, President <a href="/wiki/Gerald_Ford" title="Gerald Ford">Gerald Ford</a> specified that Washington would "rank first among all officers of the Army, past and present".<sup class="reference" id='cite_ref-FOOTNOTE"Five-star_Generals"2017_514-0'><a href='#cite_note-FOOTNOTE"Five-star_Generals"2017-514'>[494]</a></sup></span>
</li>
</ol></div></div>
